title: No Notes Is Good Notes
description: Having once worked as a newspaper reporter, I am worried about a squad of judges, cops and lawyers bursting in some night while I am slumbering through Poldark and demanding to see my notes.

title: Notes on People
description: PERHAPS IF IT is your first try, you don't deserve it, said a ruefully philosophic Maj. Christopher Davey, one of two Britons who failed  by 140 miles to make the first balloon crossing of the Atlantic. He and Donald Cameron returned to England yesterday, fighting back tears and finally admitting that they were quite disgust. ed and absolutely miserable over having to ditch their yellow, helium and hot air balloon in the Atlantic Sunday. French fishermen picked them up and took them to the port of Concarneau in Brittany. Yesterday they took a private plane to Bracknell, England. Their $300,000 adventure, which came closer to success than any of the 18 known previous attempts, began in Newfoundland last Wednesday.

title: Crime Toll Grows 6.3% in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 31 (AP)  The number of crimes in Japan increased 6.3 percent during the first six months of 1978, totaling 631,929, the National Police Agency reported. The number of assaults decreased 4.2 percent, to 4,717 cases, but the number of people injured in robberies rose 4.1 percent and attacks on women increased 21.7 percent.

title: Washington Journal
description: WASHINGTON IN THE PARLANCE of his profession, Peter J. Flaherty was working the room, a wellappointed, dimly lighted salon at a local hotel. Smiling broadly for more than two hours, the former Mayor of Pittsburgh and former Deputy Attorney General of the United States moved with no apparent haste from one group of people to another, stepping casually into the flow of their small talk to offer his big hand, call them all by their first names, drape an arm around waiting male shoulders, drop kisses on expectant female cheeks, laugh heartily at this or that and, then, his face properly serious, assess optimistically his gubernatorial campaign in Pennsylvania before shaking hands all around again and heading to the next little clutch.

title: Market Place
description: BACK in 1974, the Aircraft Lockheed Corporation was in a tailspin. The company's main new product, the L1011, a widebody commercial aircraft, was doing poorly, making almost no headway against the McDonnell Douglas DC10, which had captured most of the market for aircraft in the 270passenger class.

title: Apples Defeat Lobsters In W.T.T. Match, 2524
description: SOUTH YARMOUTH, Mass., July 31 (AP)  The New York Apples scored 2524 triumph over the Boston Lobsters in a World Team Tennis match tonight at the Cape Cod Coliseum.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Rainbearing clouds are drifting slowly across the mid and northAtlantic States and pass out to sea later today and tonight. The remains of tropical storm  Amelia  can seen over south Texas. There is still a weak cyclonic circulation as depicted by the swirl of the clouds. Some moisture is moving northward from Baja. A new cold front is forming clouds across southern Canada.

title: Moynihan in 1980? A Chimera, He Retorts
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan regards the notion, raised in a national magazine, that he might run for President in 1980 as chimera conjured up by the Democratic left. The specter does not visibly frighten him.

title: Congress Is Urged to Put New Curbs on Liquefied Gas
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) Government report to Congress, warning that liquefied energy gas posed serious dangers, called today for immediate new safety restrictions, including a ban on the transportation and bulk storage of explosive gas in highly populated areas.

title: Corporations Report Earnings and Sales Statistics
description: For periods as (.310v41. (N) indicates stack is listed on the New York Stock Exchatiele.(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) ewer-theca:tinter.

title: Restive Youth Is Worrying East Germany
description: WARNEMUNDE, East Germany The 7 P.M. sky darkened, the wind chopped little white nicks into the Baltic Sea, and suddenly there were a half dozen young men kneeling on the floor of an openair discotheque and pounding the concrete with their bare hands.

title: Mexicans Expecting Loans Shift
description: MEXICO CITY, July 31  Mexican officials are expressing confidence that the United States Comptroller of the Currency has quietly shelved a controversial plan to curb loans by American banks to developing nations with heavy debt burdens.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Russian Found Spying in France
description: PARIS, July 31 (Reuters)  A Soviet diplomat has left France after being caught spying, official French sources said today. They said Col. Victor Penkov, assistant military attache at the Soviet Embassy, was detained by French cowl-terespionage authorities on July I and left the country shortly afterward. No further details were available.

title: Dibbs Defeats Hewitt In New Hampshire Tennis
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., July 31 (AP)  Eddie Dibbs, the topseeded player, scored a 63, 63 triumph over Bob Hewitt in the opening round of $175,000 international tennis tournament at Mount Cranmore Stadium today.

title: Local Stockbrokers Spar With Giants
description: In St. Louis, A.G. Edwards & Sons is the preeminent local brokerage firm. Similarly, by all accounts, Atlanta's preinier local firm is the RobinsonHumphrey Company, and in Minneapolis it is Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood.

title: 2 Slain at Terrorist Siege in Paris Embassy
description: PARIS, July 31  An Arabicspeaking gunman shot his way into the Iraqi Embassy here this morning, held hostages through most of the day before surrendering to French policemen, and then was shot by Iraqi security officials as he was led away by the French officers.

title: Two Prisoners in Mississippi Jail Recover From Hanging Attempt
description: NATCHEZ, Miss., July 31 (AP) Two prisoners, upset over not being transferred to the state penitentiary, apparently tried to hang themselves from makeshift ropes in their cells at the Adams County Jail, the authorites said.

title: U.S. REBUKES SADAT OVER HIS REJECTION OF ISRAELI MEETING; BUT VANCE WILL VISIT MIDEAST In Absence of a Foreign Ministers Session, He Will Confer With Both Sides Individually
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The United States, in a public rebuke of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, said today that it was very disappointed at his seeming rejection of an Americansponsored meeting with Israel at the foreign ministers level to revive the mace talks.

title: Senate Votes to Require Balanced Budget in 81
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  The Senate, in an unexpected move today, voted 58 to 29 to require a balanced budget by the beginning of the fiscal year 1981, a goal once espoused by President Carter.

title: New Flooring for White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)  The White House East Room will be reopened to the public tomorrow with a new parquet floor. The ballroom has been closed since July 5 for replacement of the flooring, worn thin by the millions of visitors passing through since the last restoration in 1953.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Detective's Car Seized

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY .JULY 31. 1978

title: GOING CUT Guide
description: SILVER SCREENINGS Today: Judgment at Nuremberg (1961) at Cinema Village (WA 43363). Two French classics, Rene Clair's A Nous La Liberte (1932) and Julien Duvivier's Pepe Le Moko (1937), at the Thalia (2223370). A new John Barrymore retrospective at the Carnegie Hall Cinema (7572131) on Tuesdays and Wednesdays today combines Twentieth Century (1934) and World Premiere (1941) and tomorrow Don Juan(1929) with Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde (1920).

title: Parents Help Parents With Newborn Problems
description: LOS ANGELES  Nine months ago, Debbie Stevenson, a 27-year-old medical technologist, gave birthto her first child, Amanda. Because they had attended prenatal classes, childbirth was a pleasant experience for Mrs. Stevenson and her husband, Jim, a 28-year-old representative for a pharmaceutical company. The first few days at home were dreadful, however.

title: Choir: Shaw- Leads Brahms Requiem
description: THE meditations on death and transfiguration that Brahms culled from the. Bible as a text for his A German Requiem are not unrelievedly grim or funereal. At one point we are assured, for instance, that when the redeemed return to Zion joy everlasting upon their heads shall be.- But somber senti- ments do predominate, as they probably should in a requiem, and that presents grave problems, so to speak, for the interpreter. Treated imaginatively, the solemn speculations of Brahms can give the susceptible listener the illusion of glimpsing eternity. Handled in a more dogged, plodding manner, the sevenmovement work can suggest the reality of eternity rather than the illusion.

title: Egypt an Oasis for Soft Drinks
description: CAIRO, July 31  In hot, dusty Egypt, where devout Moslems are not supposed to touch alcoholic beverages, softdrink companies are scrambling to Quench the nation's thirst

title: National Drive Is Begun By Dissident Teamsters
description: CLEVELAND, July 31 (UPI)  Teamsters union dissidents from around the nation  held the charter meeting this weekend of a group called the Majority Contract Coalition and demonstrated their opposition to the union leadershop of Frank Fitzsimmons_

title: SPOFFORD DIRECTOR RESIGNS FROM POST
description: Citing the city's frustratingly slow response to the needs of its troubled juvenilejustice system, Maurice Nixon, director of the Spofford Juvenile Detention Center, said yesterday that he was resigning.

title: Dog Cleanup Law Begins Today
description: Beginhing today, dog owners will have to pick up or pay up.

title: No Clues Found Yet in Slaying of Medical Student
description: Connecticut state troopers employed three bloodhounds and trackers, three scuba divers and a helicopter yesterday in a search for a weapon and other clues in the stabbing murder of a Columbia University medical student on his uncle's wooded estate in New Hartford. But nothing of significance was reported found.

title: Enoch Light, Leader of a Big Band, Stereo Recording Innovator, Dead
description: Enoch Light, a prominent band leader in the days of big bands and a pioneer in stereophonic recording, died yesterday afternoon at Mount Sinai Hospital. He lived at 860 Fifth Avenue and in West Redding, Conn., and was 71 years old.

title: Egyptians Watch as Sadat Revises System
description: CAIRO, July 31  President Anwar elSadat's recent decision to revise Egypt's political system, to put it on the basis of what he called ethical democracy, has raised many questions. The main one is: will it mean more democracy or less for the Egyptian people?

title: Restaurant Manager Is Accused Of Plotting to Murder the Owner
description: Stefanos Zachariadis, manager of an East Side restaurant, has been arrested and charged with conspiring to murder the restaurant's owner, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan announced yesterday.

title: Two Suspects in Kidnappings and Robberies Are Believed to Be Hiding in the Atlanta Area
description: ATLANTA, July 31 (AP)  Two escapees sought in connection with a series of kidnappings and robberies in Georgia and Florida are believed hiding in the Atlanta area, the police said today.

title: Cost-of-Living Adjustments Create Difficulties in Controlling Inflation
description: The cost-of-living adjustment, COLA in the language of labor contracts, is designed to protect workers pay from inflation. But it is also making inflation more difficult to control.

title: 2 Tennessee Democrats in Close Race for Governorship Nomination
description: NASHVILLE, July 31  Jacob F. Butcher, a millionaire banker,and Robert N. Clement, chairman of the Tennessee Public Service Commission, appear locked in a close contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor in the most carefully followed race in the Tennessee primary election Thursday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph in the Headliners column in Sunday's Week in Review was erroneously identified as that of Sir Albert Henry, Prime Minister of the Cook Islands. The photograph was that of of Sir Kamisese Mara, Prime Minister of Flit The Times regrets the error.

title: Navy Making Drug Abusers Face Reality
description: SAN DIEGO, July 29  In a corner room on the third floor of the treatment center, they sit in a circle and talk. A Navy counselor listens in silence.

title: Steel Output Declines 1.5%
description: Steel production for the week ended July 29 fell to 2.55 million tons, down 1.5 percent from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.6 million tons the week before.

title: Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 31 Tom Perry stood on the sideline in the rain today, watching the Giants practice and wondering whether he would be allowed to join them. The Giants were wondering, too.

title: Short on Final Resting Places, Trinity Builds a Mausoleum
description: When the two children were young, they used to visic Trinity Church Cemetery every Christmas Eve to stand by the grave of Clement Clarke Moore as his poem, 'Twas the Night Before Christmas, was recited.

title: For Galanos, Formality Can Be Dazzling
description: James Galanos always manages to have the last word on fashion. The Los Angelesbased designer rode out of the west with his fall collection, shown yesterday in churchly silence at the Plaza Hotel. It reiterated the dominant themes of the Paris couture collections that opened last week and of the New York collections presented in April.

title: Rain Ruins Loire Vineyard Crop
description: NEVERS, France, July 31 (AP) storm destroyed an estimated 80 percent of the crop in the Loire Valley's famed Pouilly vineyards yesterday. Some vintners lost all their grapes.

title: Yankees Subdue Rangers
description: Reggie Jackson returned to the fourth spot in the Yankee lineup last night and now he has to wait only two more days to learn if he will return to the waiver list.

title: 2 Slain at Terrorist Siege in Paris Embassy
description: PARIS, July 31  An Arabicspeaking gunman shot his way into the Iraqi Embassy here this morning, held hostages through most of the day before surrendering to French policemen, and then was shot by Iraqi security officials as he was led away by the French officers.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The rules of the International Olympic Committee require that arrangements to stage the Olympic Games be made only with officials of the site. When Los Angeles was chosen for the 1989 Summer Games, controversy, arose about the financial obligations involved, and proposals were made to have privatesector sponsors  among them a television network  underwrite the cost. But I.O.C. regulations specifically prohibit such a procedure, and the whole question of holding the games in Los Angeles was in doubt.

title: Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, 1.1., July 31  For a linebacker, Mark Merrill is outsized  6feet 4 inches, 235 pounds and he also owns a black belt in judo. Coach Walt Michaels is grooming his No.2 draft choice to he the Jets middle linebacker some day.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: Outgoing

title: JASCALEVICH SEEKS DIRECTED ACQUITTAL
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 31The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich argued today for a directed judgment of acquittal on the ground that the passage of 12.years since the deaths for which Dr. Jascalevich was charged had made it impossible for him to present an effective defense, because much evidence had been lost and many witnesses either had died or could no longer remember the events.

title: EUROPE AIR TRAVEL HURT BY SLOWDOWN
description: LONDON, July 31 (AP)  Hundreds of thousands of travelers jammed Western European airports today as a slowdown by French air traffic controllers and flood of American and Canadian passengers fighting for standby seats across the Atlantic threw air travel facilities into chaos.

title: Mixer of Music and Drink
description: STANDING behind the bar in the First Ring lobby of the New York State Theater, he is more than just a dispenser of libations. The critics critic, nonchalant familiar of greats and a connoisseur who can hum his way through the score of any ballet or opera in the repertories of the New York City Ballet and Opera companies, Bob Ross has been tending bar at the State Theater since it opened. This week, as the opera and dance year drew to a close there, Mr. Ross celebrated his 14th anniversary at the theater.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph in the Headliners column in Sundays Week in Review was erroneously identified as that of Sir Albert Henry, Prime Minister of the Cook Islands. The photograph was that of of Sir Kamisese Mara, Prime Minister of Fiji. The Times regrets the error.

title: Prologue to the New Recession
description: If, as is highly probable, the United States is, by this time next year, in the early stages of the decade's third recession, the fault will be located neither in the mysterious inevitabilities of the business cycle, the profusion of sun spots, nor even the person of lovable Howard Jarvis and the effects of his infamous Proposition 13.

title: Clamours Spur Dow Advance
description: Led by International Business Machines and other glamour issues, Wall Street prices kept rolling ahead yesterday to bring stocks within range of the high reached during the spectacular spring rally.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: 6 Vehicles Crash in Secaucus
description: SECAUCUS, July 31  A sixvehicle crash on a heavily traveled bridge over the Hackensack River here injured 30 persons during this morning's rush hour. and caused a sevenmile, twohour traffic jam that stretched back through the Lincoln Tunnel and into the side streets around the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan.

title: Incoming Chief Of CBS News Describes Plans
description: In a business world strongly oriented to youth, William A. Leonard has had the unusual fortune of receiving a major promotion at the age of 62. He is to become president of CBS News next April, with the retirement of Richard S. Salant, who except for a twoyear gap has headed the division since 1961.

title: BRIDGEPORT IS TOLD TO PLACE MINORITIES IN FIRE DEPARTMENT; FEDERAL JUDGE SETS A QUOTA Decision Follows Voiding by Court of an Exam Failed by All Black and Hispanic Applicants
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31  A Federal judge today ordered this city to hire all 84 black and Hispanic applicants who had failed the written exam for firefighter, provided that they pass medical and agility tests.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, July 31  The world's biggest bridge tournament ended here last night with a table count of 16,408 but, fora select few, action continues in the Spingold knockout team championship, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League Summer Nationals.

title: Detective Loses Auto To a Man He Arrests
description: FORT LEE, July 31  The unmarked radio patrol car of an Englewood Cliffs detective was stolen early today after the detective was overpowered by a man who had just attempted to illicitly purchase some drugs from phamacist with a forged prescription and then tried to commandeer a vehicle driven by are elderly woman, the police said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 31 (AP)  Mike Morris, an 18-year-old New York Athletic Club competitor, won the Amateur Athletic Union junior national racewalking championship yesterday the record time of 1 hour 47 minutes 10 seconds for 20 kilometers.

title: Common Market Output
description: LUXEMBOURG, July 31 (Reuters)  Industrial production in the European Economic Community fell 0.9 percent from April to May, but the output of consumer goods rose 2.5 percent, the Common Market's statistics office said today. The industrial production index (1970=100) stood at 118.3 in May, compared with 118.2 in May 1977.

title: Youth Plan Impresses Williams
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 31  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. today toured the A. Chester Redshaw Junior High School, a 35-year-old building here that 110 boys and girls are refurbishing as part of Federal youthemployment program.

title: Zadroga Leads Qualifying
description: DES MOINES, July 31 (UPI)  Al Zadroga of Elizabethtown, Pa., is leading the qualifiers in the men's Class A division of the world horseshoe pitching championship with 558 of 600 possible points here. Elmer Hohl of Wellesley, Ontario, returned to defend his title and did not have to qualify.

title: Lebanese Army Moves Into South, But Is Blocked by Christian Units
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31  Units of the Lebanese Army moved into southern Lebanon today and took up positions alongside United Nations contingents, but failed to reach their final destination because of objections by Israelibacked Christian militia forces.

title: VW Continues Diesel Output
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, July 31 (Reuters)  Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, said today that it would continue producing diesel cars despite tears expressed by the United States Environmental Protection Agency about the danger of cancer.

title: Health Insurance in Installments
description: President Carter has finally issued his principles for a national health insurance program.mere downpayment, and a belated one, on his campaign promise to act swiftly in this area. The principles are broad enough, and vague enough, to satisfy many citizens. Yet even before they were issued, Senator Kennedy and other advocates of broad health coverage for all denounced the President for a failure of leadership. The issue between them is how much how soon.

title: TestTube Case Hears Evidence On Dr. Shettles
description: A lawyer for ColUmbiaPresbyterian Medical Center maintained yesterday that the hospital's chief of gynecology, who had halted Dr. Landrum B. Shettles's 1973 attempt to fertilize, in a test tube, an ovum from Doris Del Zio with sperm from her husband, had not been alone in questioning Dr. Shettles's professional abilities.

title: U.S. REBUKES SADAT OVER HIS REJECTION OF ISRAELI MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The United States, in a public rebuke of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, said today that it was very disappointed at his seeming rejection of an Americansponsored meeting with Israel at the foreign ministers level to revive the peace talks.

title: 22 Pacers Enter $560,000 Race
description: EAST RUTHERFORD,N.J.,July 31  Five plastic bags bulging with green backs, legal tender for all debts public and private, were carted through the New Jersey mud this morning, the bait that lured 22 horses to Thursday night's $560.000 Meadowlands Pace. The halfmillion dollars in $10 and $20 bills was taken out of the First National State Bank of Newark for two hours to emphasize that this would be the nation's biggest purse for both harness and thorou,;:thred racing.

title: Thailand Agrees to Study Return Of Vietnamese Who Fled in 40's
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 (Reuters)  Thailand has agreed to consider the repatriation of 40,000 Vietnamese who fled 30 years ago during the first Indochina war, a Thai minister said today.

title: BRIDGEPORT IS TOLD TO PLACE MINORITIES IN FIRE DEPARTMENT
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31  A Federal judge today ordered this city to hire all 84 black and Hispanic applicants who had failed the written exam for firefighter, provided that they pass medical and agility tests.

title: Ballet: Canadians Offer Dream
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)  To welcome the dean of modern sculpture into his ninth decade, the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden has opened a take-another-look exhibition of its 55 works by Henry Moore.

title: Gold Price Dips Slightly
description: LONDON, July 31(AP)  Gold closed today above the psychologically important $200-an-ounce mark for the second consecutive session in active trading on the European bullion markets although prices were lower than Friday's record quotation of $201.30 throughout today's trading.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sauro
description: NO SHELTER HERE: The Isamu Noguchi sculpture at 140 Broadway offered little protection to passersby from yesterday's rain. Sunny and breezy weather was forecast for today, however, with only a few fairweather clouds.

title: Federal Judge Warns Postal Union In the New York Area Not to Strike
description: A Federal judge in Newark said yesterday that he could not forbid individual postal workers to take a strike vote because it was their constitutional right, but he warned that a strike would be illegal under Federal statutes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AlabamaTennessee Natural Gas Company, Florence, Ala., has elected M.D. Prouty Jr. president and chief operating officer.

title: Milwaukee Photographer Seized While Covering a Confrontation
description: MILWAUKEE, July 31 (UPI)  A newspaper photographer was arrested last night while covering a confrontation between policemen and a bottlethrowing crowd of 250 to 300 people, the police said.

title: Tax Break Leads to Saratoga Records
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31  With a new deal tax structure taking effect, New York horseplayers turned out in record numbers today for the start of Saratoga's 29day thoroughbred meeting.

title: EARNINGS
description: The nation's two largest copper companies, the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Phelps Dodge Corporation, reported yesterday that their earnings had suffered from lower copper prices and reduced shipments in the second quarter.

title: 41 Hurt in West German Crash
description: DORTMUND, West Germany (AP) Two passenger trains collided today between Dortmund and Lunen in West Germany, injuring 91 persons, railway authorities said. There was no explanation about why the two trains, an express and a local, were on the same track.

title: Not Cool, Not Slick
description: FISHKILL, N.Y.  In an echoing meeting hall at the Fishkill Correctional Center here, an inmate called Duke glared menacingly around a halfcircle of 12 teenaged youths, white and black. They stared back at him with blank faces, somehow more defiant in their apparent boredom than they might have been in anger.

title: Around the Nation
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 31 (UPI)  The Federal Government now has no choice but to sue Maine on behalf of two Indian tribes claiming the northern twothirds of the state, Deputy United States Attorney General James Moorman said today.

title: New Market Plan To Start
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The composite quotation system, regarded as a key component of the national securities market mandated by Congress, will begin operating tomorrow.

title: 4 TaxFree Offerings Are Priced
description: Four major issues of taxexempt bonds totaling $975 million were tentatively priced yesterday as investment bankers began an extremely active week of raising money for states and cities. Altogether, $1.24 billion of taxexempt bond financing is scheduled between now and Friday.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: KEY NAMIBIA LEADER FACING OPPOSITION
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 31  With acceptance of the United Nations plan for majority rule in SouthWest Africa, the South African Government will open the possibility of a militant black state on its borders ruled by a man who once worked as a sweeper for South African Railways.

title: ArsonTrial Jury Being Picked
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 31 (AP)  Jury selection began today in the trial of Peter Leonard of Greenwich, Conn., who is charged with setting a fire in a Port Chester discotheque that killed 24 persons in 1974. Mr. Leonard had pleaded guilty to the charge, but the plea was later dismissed by an appeals court on the ground that the admission had been forced by the police.Two and a half years ago, Mr. Leonard pleaded guilty to setting fire to bowling alley to cover up a burglary there. The flames spread to the discotheque.

title: A Window On World Of Suspect In a Siege
description: Wladyslaw Fraczek's inability to speak English turned what might have been a minor incident into a bizarre 10hour psychodrama, with 9,000 office workers being evacuated from a World Trade Center tower as the police laid careful plans to free four hostages.

title: Puerto Rico Auto Plant Canceled by DeLorean
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., July 31  In move that stunned the Puerto Rican business community today, John Z. DeLorean, a former General Motors executive, abruptly canceled plans to build an automobile assembly plant in Aguadilla after winning United States Government loan guarantees for the project only last Thursday.

title: Economic Index Rise Discounted
description: WASHINGTON, July 31- The Government's index of leading economic indicators advanced by fourtenths of percent in June, but there was less to the rise than met the eye, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 1,1978

title: Bond Prices Off Slightly In Light Trading Activity
description: Bond Prices Off Slightly In Light Trading Activity

title: Louisiana's Stringent New Abortion Law Termed StandardBearer
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 31  With scarcely any public notice, the Louisiana Legislature has passed a law restricting abortions that is believed to be the strongest in the nation.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Securities and Exchange Commission this month proposed a wideranging series of changes in proxy rules that would require companies to disclose tc shareholders new information about the quality and effectiveness of corporate boards of directors. If adopted, the proposals would constitute the first substantive overhaul of proxy-disclosure requirements since they were established 40 years ago.

title: Rose Hits in 44th And Ties Keeler
description: ATLANTA, July 31 (AP)  Pete Rose extended his consecutivegame hitting streak to a National League recordtying 44 tonight, but admitted later he was rather anxious.

title: Tension Building as Dominicans Await Transfer of Power
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 30  Two weeks from now, barring a lastminute military takeover, political power will be peacefully transferred for the first time in the tangled history of the Dominican Republican.

title: 5 Years
description: A 33-year-old Marine Corps sergeant and Vietnam War veteran who spent five years in jail while the Brooklyn District Attorneys office tried vainly to convict him of murder filed suit yesterday for $20 million in compensation.

title: SurViving Siamese Twin Stable
description: FRESNO, Calif., July'31 (AP)  The survivor of Siamese twin boys born just over a week ago remained very stable at a hospital here today. The infant, identified only as Brian, was separated Friday from his brother, Thomas. They had been joined from the chest to the abdomen and the operation to separate them took five hours.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Airlines Ask U.S. Funds For Quiet
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The airline industry is telling Congressional staff members that, despite record profits, it needs an estimated $2 billion in Federal funds to pay for airplane noise reduction.

title: Middle Class Thinks Itself Hit Most by Taxes and Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Rose family of Washington, Ill., bought their first house last year. The couple figured that deducting the taxes and interest in their mortgage payments would bring them an income tax refund. When they made out their return, though, they had to shell out a sizable amount of cash.

title: The Bidding on Reggie Begins
description: All last week, the telephones in Yankee Stadium kept ringing with threats to cancel tickets, switch loyalties or even bomb the ball park because Billy Martin was gone. So the Yankees, ever sensitive to the pulse and purse of the public, brought him back. And now the phones are ringing with different messages: What do you want for Reggie Jackson?

title: American Mutual Fined On Charges of Redlining
description: BALTIMORE, July 31 (AP)  Maryland's insurance commisioner has fined the American Mutual Insurance Company of Boston $150,000 on charges that the company refused to sell policies to residents of 10 innercity Baltimore neighborhoods.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 31 (UPI) The General Foods Corporation, the country's largest coffee roaster, today followed the lead of other roasters last week and cut the wholesale price of ground coffee by 10 cents a pound to $2.63. This is the tenth drop in wholesale coffee prices by leading roasters since May 1977,

title: MARY SCOTT PIERREPONT
description: Mary Adelaide Scott Pierrepont, socially prominent here and in Charleston, S.C., died Sunday in her home in Ridgefield, Conn., after a short illness. Mrs. Pierrepont, 74 years old, also had a home in Charleston.

title: Company Sues Goldin Over BusShelter Franchise
description: Bustop Shelters Inc. filed suit yesterday against City Comptroller Harrison .1. Goldin, charging that he had defamed the corporation deliberately to give its competitors a better chance of winning the .city's lucrative busstop shelter franchise.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, AUGUST 1,1978

title: Trenton Topics Top State Democrat May Direct Sports Complex
description: TRENTON, July 31- A trial balloon was launched here today, and sent in the direction of the Meadowlands Sports Complex when aides of Richard J. Coffee, the state Democratic chairman, said he was line to become executive director of the sports authority.

title: South Africans Delay Approval In Namibia Plan
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 31 South Africa decided after a daylong Cabinet meeting today to withhold final approval of the United Nations plan for black majority rule in SouthWest Africa.

title: Studios Are Giddy With Surprise As Summer Crowds Jam Movies

description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 31South Africa decided after a daylong Cabinet meeting today to withhold final approval of the United Nations plan for black majority rifle in SouthWest Africa.

title: Books: Tarben,
description: IN Hannah Arendt's conception, Eichmann, the SS functionary, ii- . rustrates the banality of evil. But Joseph Borkin's powerful study of I.G. Farben, the huge German chemical combine that provided Hitler with the synthetic oil, gasoline, nitrogen and tuna rubber he needed to wage World War II, and the ZyklonB poison gas for the Nazi murder camps, demonstrates not the banality but the venality of evil.

title: State High Court, by 43, Restricts LowCost and Free School Lunches
description: IRENTON, July 31  Several thousand New Jersey pupils from needy families could lose their free or lowcost school lunches under a ruling today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Mets Suffer 4th Defeat In Row, 61
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31  The New York Mets appeared at Veterans Stadium tonight hoping to attain a goal they had reached only once in their previous 15 appearances in the Philadelphia Phillies stronehold: a victory.

title: Red Paper in London Is Bombed
description: LONDON, July 31 (Reuters)  A package bomb exploded today in the offices of the British Communist Party's daily newspaper, Morning Star, slightly injuring a secretary, the police said. The police said the bomb had been left on a desk for about Iwo hours and exploded when secretary picked it up.

title: Playboy International Gains in Casino Plans
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 31 Playboy International cleared the last major obstacle today in its plans to build a $75 million hotel casino here and will probably begin construction before the end of August.

title: The Closet, a Violent and Subtle Prison
description: In high school I sat next to a pretty boy named Jack who went down to Greenwich Village on weekends and beat up queers. That's how he referred to it, beating up queers. He and his friends lured homosexuals into dark alleys and doorways with the promise of sex, which they sometimes performed for money, and then they stomped them with motorcycle boots and whipped them with chains.

title: MOTIONS ARE MADE IN SUIT ON TV MOVIE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31  The lawyer for the child victim of a sex crime who is suing the National Broadcasting Company for $11 million because of its broadcast of a controversial movie asked the judge today to bar all reference to the First Amendment during the jury trial that is beginning this week.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IN Chesapeake, his 21st book, James A. Michener does for Maryland's Eastern Shore what he did for Colorado in Centennial. By telling the story of dozens of fictional characters who live in a partly imaginary locale, he tries to capture the real history of the area  in the case of the Chesapeake Bay, from the time in the 16th century when Indians and crabs were its chief inhabitants.

title: TwinPlant Concept Catches On

title: Homosexual Periodicals Are Proliferating

Little wonder, then, that when David Goodstein gets around to writing a book on The Advocate, he says he intends to call it, Out of the Porn Stores. The Advocate, which Mr. Goodstein owns, is a homosexual newspaper.

title: Scribner's and Atheneum Plan Merger to Prevent a Takeover

title: How Many Votes Do Reactors Cast?
description: Governor Carey's dramatic vow to block construction of nuclear power plants in New York State until the Federal Government comes up with an adequate waste disposalprogram seems to be primarily an exercise in electionyear posturing. The problem of nuclear wastes  radioactive material that must be kept isolated for hundreds of thousands of years  is real enough and has received insufficient attention. But the Governor's gesture will contribute little to the search far a solution.

title: Republicans courting Black Voters In South After Years of Inactivity

title: Dollar Continues To Decline

Within half an hour of today's opening, the United States currency sank to 187.50 yen as selling pressure built up.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Recently, an elderly woman in Reston, Va., the planned community south of Washington, D.C., needed some work done on her patio. Enter Henry Ware, founder of USE, or the Useful Services Exchange. USE found another Restonian who was willing to fix the patio in his spare time.

title: Ten Rebel Bases Hit As Rhodesian Troops Strike in Mozambique
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 31 (Reuters)  Rhodesian military headquarters announced tonight that its troops had completed a successful assault against guerrilla bases in Mozambique, putting 10 guerrilla bases out of action.

York State.

title: Cuban Refugee Saved at Sea
description: MIAMI, July 31 (UPI)  A 27-year-oldi refugee who fled Cuba in a homemade raft on July 23 was plucked out of the sea near Key Largo yesterday by the crew of a pleasure boat, the Xtabay. Ramon Estevez Cardova, the refugee, said that he planned to join his parents, who live in New York.

title: Help Asked in Locating Assassination Witnesses
description: The House Committee on Assassinations has asked the public to help identify five potential witnesses it wants to question about the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: 3 Drown in Florida Cave
description: LIVE OAK, Fla., July 31 (AP) Three scuba divers on an outing from Albany, Ga., died while diving in a cave near here where dozens of lives have been lost in recent years, sheriff's officials said today. A spokesman for the sheriff's office, Bill Maxwell, said the three were diving in large pool called Peacock's Slough, which is posted against diving and has a history of fatal accidents. He said they apparently became lost in a large underwater cave and their air supply ran out.

Jascalevich argued today for a directed judgment of acquittal on the ground that the passage of 12 years since the deaths for which Dr. Jascalevich was charged had made it impossible for him to present an effective defense, because much evidence had been lost and many witnesses either had died or could no longer remember the events.

In the sum- . mer of 1941, every pitcher worthy of his trade yearned for a chanc'e to confront and defeat DiMaggio. Those who faced him summoned extra energy and grit and bore down on him even more than they did on other batters.

The new law, according to Norman E. Auerbach, chairman of Coopers & Lybrand, is in many ways the most important act affecting accounting since the Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934. However, it has gone almost unnoticed and largely ill understood, Mr. Auerbach adds.

Klein, would stretch out the retirement of the debt, cutting the annual costs to taxpayers over the next two decades but thereafter adding $20 million to the nroiect's costs.

The knife for recutting the pie was to be the Federal procurement program of the Small Business Administration, a portion of whose contracts were to be set aside for black firms without the customary competitive bidding.

Each Wednesday, starting tonight at 5:30 P.M., an entrance fee of $10 covers all you can eat and drink until closing. In addition to the regular ballroom spinning to two bands, there will be a 9:15 dance class, then a dance show and, finally, disco dancing starting at midnight (as it also does on Fridays and Saturdays).

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  A Carter Administration official said today that the United States and the Soviet Union were within hailing distance of a set of principles to limit sales of conventional weapons to other countries.

title: 6 Killed in French Copter Crash
description: TOULON, France, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Six French officers were killed when helicopter exploded today after being struck by lightning off this Mediterranean naval base today, a military spokesman said.

title: EARNINGS
description: BERN, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  The steady fall of most currencies against the Swiss franc did not discourage foreign tourists from spending their cash in Switzerland last year, statistics showed today. The Economics Ministry reported that foreign tourists spent more than $3.4 billion in this country in 1977, according to current exchange rates. That was a 10 percent increase over the previous year. Tourism and banking traditionally give Switzerland a balance-of-payments surplus despite its usual trade deficit  $960 million last year  caused by importing essential raw materials.

title: Postal Union Chief Reaffirms His Support for Contract
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1  J. Joseph Vacca, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, vowed today to continue working for the acceptance by the union's 175,000 members of the tentative contract agreement with the United State Postal Service.

title: Market Maintains Firm Tone
description: Selected goldmining issues, responding to record prices for bullion abroad, moved ahead yesterday while stock prices generally showed only small changes after a strong fiveday rally

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Funds were removed from a Brooklyn summer youth program for disadvantaged youths and the program was taken over by the Human Resources Administration's employment department because of the alleged wasting of funds and serious management problems.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: ABRESCHIda. On July 30, 1978. Be loved wife of the late James. Dear aunt of Gladys Robertson, Iris Hot ner and Msgr. Pio Abresch of Rome. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch anc Son Funeral Home, 4307 Queen: Blvd, Sunnyside, L.I. Mass of Chris Ilan Burial St. Sebastian's R.0 Church, Thursday, 9:45AM. Inter ment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Sri Lanka Investigating Regime Ousted in 1977
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Aug. I  A presidential commission began an inquiry today into the misuse and abuse of power, corruption, fraud and nepotism during the sevenyear government of former Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike.

title: 2 of 5 Murder Charges Dismissed By Judge in the Jascalevich Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 1  The presiding judge in the trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich dismissed two of the five murder charges against the surgeon today because, he said, the state had not proved that curare was present in two of the bodies.

title: Newsprint Price
description: Bowater Sales Inc., a unit of the Bowater Corporation of Londort,said it was increasing United States newsprint prices by $15 a ton, effective Oct. 1. That will bring the price of newsprint to $335 a short ton for 30pound basis weight.

title: Market Place
description: WOULD you buy shares in Company X, selling at 12 times next year's earnings and yielding 4.4 percent, if the company were about to become a leading factor in the fastgrowing communications industry, was soundly financed, observed conservative accounting principles and had doubled its earninas in the last five years?

title: CBS Promotes William Small
description: In a move that appears to position him as the leading prospect to head CBS News three years from now, William J. Small, senior vice president of the news division, yesterday was named Washington vice president for CBS Inc. The position is otherwise defined as chief governmental liaison, or lobbyist for the corporation.

title: Billions at Stake As U.S. Weighs CleanAir Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The question of how much cleansing to require of the sulfurous smoke that will be emitted by new generation of electric power plants has become a subject of intense debate among Government agencies and special interest groups. Billions of dollars, as well as considerations of clean air, are at stake.

title: Colonial Stores Agrees To Grand Union Merger
description: Colonial Stores, which has vigorously opposed merger overtures from the Grand Union Company for more than a month, agreed yesterday to be taken over in a move that will create the nation's eighthlamest food chain

title: Excerpts From Brief Filed by Jascalevich Lawyers
description: Following are excerpts from the statement filed with Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday by lawyers for Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich opposing the application for a stay of civil-contempt penalties by The New York Times Company and M. A. Farber:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which operates 16 department store organizations in the United States, has appointed Carrick A. Hill chairman and chief executive officer of the Stix, Baer & Fuller Division.

title: Council Committee Head and City Disagree Over Changes at Spofford
description: A City Council committee chairman asserted yesterday that only cosmetic changes have been taking place at the longcriticized Spofford Juvenile Center.- The city administration contenaea, meanwhile, that it had toughened security measures and had started last week round-the-clock screening to divert lessserious cases from the Bronx facility.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 1 (UN)  The Boise Cascade Corporation said it would invest nearly $250 million in its Rumford, Me., mill, eventually creating 120 permanent jobs and making Maine the leader of paper making states.

title: Rhodesia Says Raid Was Aimed at Guerrilla Recruits
description: SALISBURY, RhodeSia, Aug. 1  Rhodesia's military commanders said today that the country's military strike into Mozambique this week was aimed in part at 2,700 freshly trained guerrillas who had instructions to disrupt a ceasefire. under which proGovernment guerrillas have switched sides to assist in administering the country.

title: 10 Accused of Odometer Altering
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1 (AP)  Ten usedcar salesmen and their dealerships throughout New Jersey were charged today with rolling back mileage on about 565 autos, according to United States Attorney Robert J. Del Tufo.

title: The Day Mother Food
description: Make no mistake. At age 6 I was not in the least unalert to my having residence in a home where history of a kind was being made. I admit it  I'm typing from memory now, but you could found an M.I.T. on the lustrous factuality of my decadesold observations.

title: Wine Talk
description: PARIS

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Texas International Airlines, the guppy trying to swallow National Airlines, one of the whales of the airline business, may have more trouble than it expected in trying to digest Bud Maytag.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: I.B.M. and Xerox said they had settled their legal dispute over patents in the officecopier, informationhandling and data-processing fields, apparently resolving a clash between two of the modern era's most successful corporations. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will pay Xerox $25 million and each company will gain rights to the other's existing patents in the fields as well as to patents applied for during the next five years. [Page Dl.]

title: United Press International
description: TERRORIST SUSPECT ARRAIGNED: Kristina Berster being lead Federal marshals from courthouse in Burlington, Vt., yesterday, after her arraignment on charges of entering country illegally. She is wanted by West German officials for suspected terrorist activities there.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration /UPI

title: Personal Health
description: THE examination of Eli's coronary arteries indicated that he was a prime candidate for a heart attack. At age 52, with one child entering college and another starting high school, Eli was hardly ready ro consiaer nis me over so, when his internist recommended an operation to bypass the partly obstructed arteries feeding the right side of his heart, Eli was ready to go ahead with it.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Aug.1,1978

title: Joseph C. Waddy, Federal Judge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Judge Joseph C. Waddy, who had served on the Federal District Court here since 1967, died today. He had long suffered from emphysema and heart disease. He was 67 years old.,

title: Gold Hits A Record
description: LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP)  Gold prices hit a new peak today, reaching $207.50 an ounce at the morning fixing here  more than $7 higher than the overnight level  and ending the day at $204.65, record closing level.

title: MT.A.'s Head Getting Reports on Decline ofLIR.R.
description: Harold L. Fisher, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has been receiving monthly reports this year from his chief operations officer detailing the decline of the Long Island Rail Road. The Door nerformance was cited by Mr. Fisher last week, when Governor Carey dismissed the railroad's president, Robert K. Pattison. He also said Mr. Pattison's plans for the future of the troubled commuter line, previewed last week, were disappointing.

title: BROOKE WON'T FACE CHARGE OF PERJURY
description: BOSTON, Aug. 1 Senator Edward W. Brooke will not face perjury charges for false financial statements filed in connection with his recent divorce, Garrett H. Byrne, the Suffolk County District Attorney, decided today.

title: Capitalist Bride in Moscow
description: ATHENS, Aug. 1 Five months ago a close friend of Christina Onassis said here that the shipping heiress had at last settled down and outgrown the willfulness, and impulsive behavior that had so often disturbed and outraged her family.

title: Publisher to Drop Fiction
description: The BobbsMerrill Company, the 150yearold publishing house owned by the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, has decided to stop publishing mysteries, Gothic novels and general fiction, Stanley S. Sills, Bobbs; Merrill's chairman, said yesterday.

title: Inspectors General, New York Style
description: Like many recent American Presidents, New York's Mayor Koch has learned that it is as hard to control his own administration as it is to influence an independently elected legislature. To bring some order into the farflung city establishment and to root out corrupt practices, the Mayor has ordered each department to set up an inspector general's office. For 11 of the 25 departments, this was nothing new. They have had them and they have not worked too well. But the Mayor believes that by placing his Commissioner of Investigation in overall charge, he can control the inspectors while they monitor the rank-and-file city workers.

title: Berger's Campaign Ads Attack Veracity of Goldin
description: Stephen Berger, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for State Comptroller, yesterday began television commercials accusing his opponent, Harrison J. Goldin, the New York City Comptroller, of not telling the truth.

title: Noted Texas HonkyTonk Strip Is Becoming Merely a Memory
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug.1  Just past the Trinity River west of downtown, a faded neon sign heralds the start of stretch of highway that for years symbolized the temptations of sin in Texas.

title: I.B.M. and Xerox End Patent Suit
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 1 (AP) Federal court jury today began weighing the SCM Corporation's claim for $111 million in damages from the Xerox Corporation because of SCM's exclu-

title: ]Office Workers in the Meadowlands Get Noontime Music
description: LYNDHURST, Aug. 1  A little noontime music came to the Hackensack Meadowlands today to enliven the lunch hour for clerks, secretaries and businessmen who have no diversionary cultural, recreational or shopping outlets for their free time near their new offices in the develonine Meadowlands.

title: Panel in House Favors Repealing of Smith Act
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  The House Criminal Justice Subcommittee voted today to go along with the Senate and recommend repeal of the Smith Act, which prohibits advocating the overthrow of the Government.

title: Antitrust Study Of Exchange
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The Justice Department's antitrust division has begun what a spokesman described today as a preliminary inquiry into commission rates charged by independent brokers in the New York City foreignexchange market

title: Canada's Offer to Ford Draws Criticism in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Treasury complained today that Canada was offering an excessive financial incentive to the Ford Motor Company to induce it to locate a new engine plant in Ontario rather than in Lima, Ohio.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Moorehead Out 4 Weeks; Hoping to Play Opener
description: Emery Moorehead, one of the three wide receivers rotated as starters by the Giants last season, underwent knee surgery Monday night and will be lost to the National Football League team for four to six weeks.

title: Concert: Peter Serkin
description: NO one is immune to the shifts of fashion, not even Beethoven. In recent years, pianists have been toying with the idea that performances of his music should reflect more clearly his 18thcentury roots. The heavenstorming, breastclutching manner that came to be standara Beetnoven for interpreters reared in the Romantic tradition being reexamined, and lightertoned instruments are being tried.

title: Ballet: New Bayaderka
description: WHEN Soviet ballet troupes first brought Bayaderka to America, the work seemed to pose such fiendish technical problems that many people could not imagine its ever being done by a Western company. Today it is danced everywhere by companies that can at least struggle valiantly with its problems, even though they may not invariably solve all of them.

title: Higher Yields Spur Sales
description: Yields on some of the large tax-exempt bond issues being marketed this week on a noncompetitive basis were increased slightly yesterday to speed orders from investors. The maneuver apparently worked.

title: SpitRoasting A Whole Lamb
description: Here are the steps for William Broscovak's SpitRoasted Whole Lamb Carcass:.

title: United Pees International
description: ASSEMBLY TIME: At Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant in Dearborn, Mich., workers assemble the first of the 1979 model year Mustangs. The 1979 Mustang has more of an European appearance than previous models.

title: Envoys Meeting in Bonn On Air Pirate Sanctuary
description: BONN, Aug. 1 (AP)  Envoys from the United States and six other Western nations began a twoday conference today to work out details of a pledge to impose an aviation boycott on countries that aid airline hijackers, the Government said.

title: Jazz: Guitarist in Concert
description: THE perennial problem of the jazz musician of finding an audience has no pat solutions. He may scuffle in obscure clubs for years hoping that someone may notice him. Or he may take the bull by the horns and invest some money  his or friends  in a showcase for his talents.

title: U.S. ImageMakers Put Stamp on Venezuelan Campaign
description: CARACAS, VenezuelaThe campaign for the presidency, once fought as a conventional battle of speechmaking, backslapping, walking tours and huge openair rallies, has developed into a major contest among rival American media experts and imagemakers. For the first time they have been imported by competing parties in this showcase Latin American democracy.

title: Lamb: A Rocky Mountain Roast
description: DURANGO, Colo.

title: Dog Owners Cope With Cleanup Law
description: New Yorkers were their customary obliging, lawabiding, imaginative, evasive, rebellious and somewhat violent selves yesterday as they began dealing creatively with the new ordinance requiring dog owners to clean up after their pets.

title: Immunization Plan for Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The nation's black doctors will conduct a major immunization effort in 15 areas throughout the nation to vaccinate children who are members of minority groups and are unprotected against childhood diseases.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ON occasion someone asks how a professional chef goes about preparing menu when he cooks at home for a small group of friends. The answer that with the exception of special dishes that are family favorites or are requested by friends, I plan these menus just as I would professionally. go to the market and the menus follow logically.

title: Best Buys
description: FLUCTUATING food prices took one of their upward swings last week, when the cost of feeding family of four in New York City jumped 1.5 percent, bringing the cost of the Department of Consumer Affairs market basket to $84.46 from the previous week's level of $83.23.

title: TV: Dramas of Six Pioneer Women
description: OUT OF OUR FATHERS HOUSE, which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on PBS's Great Performances series over WNETTV, is a powerful hour that dramatically tells, in the words of the people involved, what it was like to be a woman of character who had to fit into American society of the 1800's.

title: Real Estate
description: POSTWAR office buildings are no longer necessarily modern. Despite conventional definitions, even they can be thoroughly modernized.

title: Controlling the Wiretapping
description: Wiretapping by Government for purposes of foreign intelligence and national security ought to be under the control of law. The House of Representatives now faces the challenge  and opportunity of enactment. The Senate's version of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act 011978 passed by a vote of 95 to 1, but harder fight against the measure is promised by the House Republican Policy Committee. We hope the House will recognize the national interest in ending the abuses of wiretapping that have occurred under eight Presidentsand pass this important bill.

title: PROCEDURE STUDIED IN LINCOLN HOSPITAL
description: An accidental perforation of a patient's liver by a house staff physician at Lincoln Hospital caused the death on July 12 of a 50-year-old man under treatment for cirrhosis and other ailments, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation reported yesterday.

title: Drip and Drone, Drip and Drone
description: Surely the time has come to reassess our obsession with perpetual air-conditioning.

title: Lebanon Charges Israelis Obstruct Deployment of Army in the South
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1 The Leba nese Government accused Israel today responsibility for disrupting deployment of regular army units in the south neat the Israeli border. The soldiers arrived at the town of Kawkaba yesterday and were prevented by artillery from going on, They came under more shelline today.

title: Radio Ads Aim at Aliens Who Can Legalize Their Status
description: EL PASO, Tex.  The Carter Administration will soon begin telling foreign nationals who have illegally entered this country where to go to learn whether they have a chance of becoming permanent, legal resident aliens.

title: Subway Slayer's Accomplice, 17, Is Sentenced to 8 Years in Prison
description: Herman Spates, the 17-year-old accomplice in one of two subway murders committed by 15-year-old Willie Bosket, pleaded guilty to manslaughter charges yesterday and was sentenced to 8 1/3 to 25 years in orison.

title: Albania Charges China With Using Blackmail
description: VIENNA, Aug. 1 (Reuters)  Albania renewed its attacks on China today, saying Albanian workers accuse Peking of blackmail, hostility and arbitrary acts against the Balkan country, once China's closest ally_

title: Careers
description: FASHIONS in engineering fields change, depending on where the best job opportunities and the most exciting research and develop. ment might be occurring at a given time.

title: Peter Darlington Marries Silvana R. Lubini Upstate
description: St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Silvana R. A. Lubini, daughter of Margherita Lubini of Geneva and Lueano. Switzerland and the late Stefano Lubini, to Peter Darlington, son of the late Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Darlington of New York. The rector, the Rev. William Hayes, performed the ceremony.

title: GasPrice Bill Faces Renewed Resistance
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, today resumed his battle against the removal of oil and naturalgas price controls by assailing President Carter, the Senate's Democratic leadership and the oil and gas industry.

title: Private Lives
description: THE story begins in a tavern outside Athens on a Saturday night. It will, I hope, never end, but if it is merely an anecdote, the punch line came 10 days later in Santorini, the southernmost of the Cycladic islands and, in my opinion, the most,beautiful place in the world, where the pure light burns straight through your skull and falls like a sword a thousand feet into the sea.

title: Vegetarians Find Their Faith Bearing Fruit
description: SELINSGROVE, PA.

title: Tristate Area's Votes On Lifting of Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  FoIlowihg are the'rollcall votes of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the House's approval, 208 to 205, of a measure to repeal the Congressional embargo on military aid to Turkey.

title: BROOKE WON'T FACE CHARGE OF PERJURY
description: BOSTON, Aug. 1 Senator Edward W. Brooke will not face perjury charges for false financial statements filed in connection with his recent divorce, Garrett H. Byrne, the Suffolk County District Attorney, decided today.

title: Lyttle Hits Pair in Japan
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 1 (AP)Jim Lyttle, formerly with the New York Yankees and Los Angeles Dodgers, hit his 22d and 23d home runs of the Japanese baseball season today and drove in five runs as the Hiroshima Toyo Carp beat the Chunichi Dragons, 117.

title: Miss Onassis Weds and Espouses the Simple Life
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1 Christina Onassis, the 27-year-old Greek shipping millionaire, joined fortunes today with Sergei Kauzov, a former official of the vast Soviet merchant marine, in a brief secular ceremony in a Moscow wedding palace.

title: Study Finds Suburbanites Displacing Poor in Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  Ernest Moore, slightly built and creased with age, fears he might have to join a new army of displaced Americans, urban nomads being forced from innercity homes by affluent people returning from the suburbs.

title: Byrne, in Combat Boots, Checks Guard, Fires Guns
description: FORT DRUM, N.Y., Aug. 1  For the first time since he took office more than four years ago, Governor Byrne today inspected the New Jersey National Guard on training maneuvers here.

title: Investors Take Refuge in Gold
description: With the dollar taking yet another beating on world currency markets, and with the American economy laboring under the twin burden of persistent trade deficits and relentless inflation, gold is once again emerging as a major shelter for skittish investors.

title: Testing Foreign Aid
description: WASHINGTONThe foreign aid bill is in serious trouble in Congress. It matters little that President Carter's budget request has already been slashed in committee by over $1 billion dollars (13 percent). Much deeper reductions are threatened because it is widely assumed that foreign aid has no constituency. That was not always the case.

title: The New York Times/ William E. Sauro
description: MAYORAL SENDOFF FOR YOUTH GAMES TEAM: Mayor Koch wading through the city's team of 76 boys and girls who are to compete in the United States Youth

title: The Clubs Where Aim Is the Game
description: OUTSIDE, the temperature is over 90 degrees and the city smells of car exhaust and hot knishes. Inside, deep underground below 20th Street and Fifth Avenue, the air is cool and smells of burnt elm- powder, hot oil and that nosetingling blend of lead, brass and gunsmoke that would tell you what's going on here even if you couldn't hear the reports from a dozen pistols being fired just the other side of a glass partition. The place the West Side Pistol and Rifle Range. It's Saturday morning, the weekly meeting of the Chelsea Gun Club, and the members are sitting around chatting and talking about guns before they take their turns on the range.

title: Vegetarian Sources
description: For more information on vegetarianism, write North American Vegetarian Society, 501 Old Harding Highway, Malaga, N.J. 08328 or telephone (609) 6942887.

description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 2, 1978

title: House Backs Award For Actions by Marine In 42 at Guadalcanal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)  The House today cleared the way for former Marine Cpl. Anthony Casamento to receive either the Medal of Honor or the Navy Cross for holding off a Japanese bayonet charge on Guadalcanal in World War II.

title: The Case of the Purloined Street
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1  Stone by stone, the Newark Police Department began assembling evidence today that a street had been stolen.

title: The Editorial Notebook Laetrile and the Law
description: Should a terminally ill cancer patient be allowed to take the drug of his choice even though medical authorities consider it worthless and perhaps even dangerous? A Federal appeals court in Denver believes so. In a case involving the controversial laetrile, it has ruled that laws requiring drugs to be proved safe and effective before they are sold in interstate commerce have no meaning for terminally ill cancer patients. If upheld on appeal, the decision could undermine the Food and Drug Administration's ability to protect consumers from fraud and possible hazard.

title: The Case of the Purloined Street
description: NEWARK, Aug. 1  Stone by stone, the Newark Police Department began assembling evidence today that a street had been stolen.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug.1 Following is the text of the opinion of Associate Justice Byron R; White of the United States Supreme, in which he denied an applicaion for a stay of civilcontempt penalties against M. A. Farber and The New York Times Company:

description: Roast Stuffed Shoulder of Lamh

title: EAST GERMANS
description: EAST BERLIN  East Germany's involvement in African conflicts is not only causing concern in the West but also being questioned at home.

title: Books: How to Look at Design
description: WE are used to being told how to cook, how to improve our emotional state, and how to fix a leaky faucet, but not how to see. Somehow it is assumed that the ability to make sophisticated judgments about the way things look comes naturally in a culture as full of visual images as ours, and that there is no more need to train the eyes to see than there is to train the nose to smell.

title: Dining What to Wear Where
description: SEVEN years ago it was reported in the press that the Italian couturier Valentino was refused a table at the Lafayette Restaurant for wearing a turtleneck sweater, that women in pants suits would not be admitted there either and, among other tidbits, that a gentleman with long hair and an actress sporting sunglasses had been denied service.

title: Israeli Reports on Negotiation
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 1  Shmuel MattoSharon, a member of the Israeli Parliament who reportedly was involved in previous prisoner exchange, said today that his secretary had visited Moscow recently and negotiated an exchange involving Anatoly B. Shcharansky.

title: $300 Million Amax Loan
description: Amax Inc., a diversified natural resources company, announced a $300 million financing with a group of 24 banks. The company said the transaction would take the form of a production payment to be repaid from coal mined at Amax's Belle Ayr and Eagle Butte mines in Campbell County, Wyo.

title: Benjamin Bass, 77, Was Founder Of the Strand UsedBook Store
description: Benjamin Bass, who founded the Strand Book Store in Manhattan spent 50 years turning it into one of New York City's largest purveyors of secondhand books, died last Friday while vacationing in Stowe, Vt. He was 77 years old and lived at 60 East End Avenue.

title: Strike Threat Perils Most New York Construction
description: A strike by 2,500 members of Teamsters Local 282 threatened for today would halt deliveries of concrete throughout New York City and stop nearly all major construction projects, according to contractor spokesmen.

title: Loanshark Tells Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP)  A convicted loanshark, testifying under Justice Department immunity, said today he once observed an exchange of over $40,000 between Anthony Scotto, a union leader, and a courier for a reputed organized crime fieure.

title: Treasury's 3Year Notes Sell to Bring 8.46% Yield
description: The Treasury sold $2.5 billion of threeyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 8.46 percent in a stiongerthanexpected auction that was the kickoff to the Government's $7 billion refinancing effort this week.

title: Philip Morris Says Airlines Terminal Building On E 42cl Will Be Replaced by Office Tower
description: The Airlines Terminal Building, once a thriving ticket and terminal headquarters for leading world airlines at 80 East 92d Street, will be demolished beginning later this week, Philip Morris Inc. announced yesterday.

title: ]HOUSE, BY 208
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The House of Representatives voted today, 208 to 205, to allow President Carter to end the embargo on arms sales to Turkey, accepting his contention that the ban was hindering a settlement in Cyprus and weakening the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Police Comb Woods In Slaying of Student In Connecticut Area
description: NEW HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 1State troopers combing the thickly wooded hills here have been unable to find any indication of hunters or other outsiders in the area where a Columbia University medical student, Michael Aranow, was found murdered with repeated stab wounds and his throat slashed.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: Outgoing

title: N.A.S.L.'s Last Week: 5 Playoff Spots to Fill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  This is the last week of action in the 24team North American Soccer League and five playoff spots are still waiting to be filled and the winners in two divisions are still to be decided.

title: House Unit Backs More Sugar Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The House Agriculture Committee has recommended a domestic sugar support level of 16 cents a pound and has called for a return to the muchmaligned countrybycountry imoortauota system.

title: Miss Costanza Resigns as Assistant To Carter, Citing Problems of Style
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Margaret Costanza resigned as an assistant to the President today, citing differences over her approach to issues with President Carter's inner circle of top assistants. She met yesterday with President Carter, who accepted her resignation with regret.

title: Boy Held as Cocaine Smuggler
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (UPI)  A 15yearold South American boy was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport yesterday with two and a half pounds of cocaine in his suitcase, the authorities said. United States customs inspectors said that the cocaine had a street value of $700,000. The unidentified teenager arrived at the airport from Lima, Peru, on his way to Vancouver, British Columbia. He was booked on suspicion of transporting narcotics. And turned over to the county probation department.

title: SHMARANSKY TRADE REPORTED IN ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  There were reports from Europe and Israel today that plans were under way for the exchange of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident; but United States officials said that they had no rea1 son to expect his early release.

title: Seven Indicted In U.S. Murder Of Chilean Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  The former chief of the Chilean secret police and six other persons, including four members of a Cuban nationalist group, were indicted today on charges of murdering Orlando Letelier, a strong critic of the Chilean military Government, who was killed in 1976 when his car was blown up on a public street here.

title: A Different World.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The contradictions and inconsistencies of the Carter Administration's foreign policy are real. But, could another President do much better? We judge the success of our diplomacy by reference to a golden age trial we taeatize: tne postwar years when the United States dominated the world stage. But two major revolutions have occurred.

title: Cascades Defeat Apples In Overtime Match, 2421
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1John McEnroe of Douglaston, Queens, and Peter Fleming of Chatham Borough, NJ., Wimbledon doubles finalists and among the singles favorites here, scored openinground victories today in the $75,000 Grand Prix tennis . championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: judge Says Jury Can Be Told Film Was Reedited
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1  The judge in the socalled Born Innocent trial today denied the National Broadcasting Company's request to keep the jury from learning that the controversial movie was edited before it was shown on television a second time.

title: Two Tough Cookies, Aged 112
description: Joe O'Brien drives a colt named Flight Director tomorrow night in the Meadowlands Pace, which has a purse 3560,000. At 61, O'Brien has lived through fractures of his neck, both arms, both legs ano Ix- nds. He says he feels great.

title: Rose's Streak Ends at 44 as He Goes Hitless in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA. Aug. 1 (AP)  Pete Rose's assault on Joe DiMaggio's major league record of hitting in 56 straight games ended tonight at 44.

title: Dowell To Dance At the Met
description: Anthony Dowell, a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet of England has been granted a leave of absence to perform with the American Ballet Theater during its fall season at the Metropolitan Opera House, Sept. 5 to 17. He will dance Giselle with Natalia Maka- rova on Sept. 8 and is expected to appear in a number of repertory roles during the company's spring season.

Although Mr. Parker has not flown space, he has worked in ground control and communications for the Skylab and Apollo missions. Their Spacelab one of the first missions slated for the space shuttle program, riding into space in the shuttle's cargo bay.

title: Housewife Slain in Her Apartment

description: MONTICELLO. N.Y.. Aug. 1Harness racing was canceled at Monticello Raceway at least through Thursday night as the management shut the track today in response to what it called an illegal boycott by horsemen.

title: Admiring the Fishes of Summer
description: DESPITE an everincreasing availability of creatures from the sea, Americans are not fish lovers. Last year, we consumed a mere 13 pounds of fish and seafood per person  compared with 52 pounds of chicken and 165 of red meat. And it is no wonder. The aquatic woria of fins, scales and shells can indeed be mysterious. And aside from familiarity with fish and chips dinners and an occasional lobster tail, many Americans would have difficulty describing the differences between a mullet and a mussel, a whiting and a weakfish. There are, of course, as many varieties of food of the deep as there are ways to prepare them. And to be at home with the soft brininess of a freshly opened oyster, to drink in the perfume of winesteamed mussels, to savor the essense of salmon in the form of faintly sweet, dillpungent gravlax, is to want to experiment with an even greater range of possibilities. Summer is an ideal time to experiment, to go fishing, since many types of fish and seafood are at their peak now, and can be served raw, lightly pickled or marinated, or cooked and then chilled. While raw fish dishes are common to the Japanese, some Western Indian tribes and the Eskimos, Americans, who have eaten steak tartare and fresh raw oysters for centuries, are just learning to like the delicate aroma and flavor of the Japanese sushi and sashimi. Caution should, of course, be exercised here, limiting raw fish to salt water, not fresh water, varieties. More familiar are the pickled or marinated fish and seafood, in the form or the classic Peruvian seviche, Spanish escabeche or Norwegian herring. Many kinds of fish and seafood can be cured by brief marination in a citric acid base combined with onions, red pepper, oil and spices for a sharp and piquant summer dish. Here, leaner fish are best, with many local varieties reaching peak production this month. Whiting, red snapper, floun- der, halibut and mackerel are all in season, and excellent for marinating. Sea scallops, used for the traditional seviche, also reach peak production in August. Finally there are the many dishes that, while delicious served hot during cool months, take on a totally different flavor in the summer. Among them are poached red snapper, steamed mussels and cooked squid.
