title: Screen: 'Interiors,' a Departure for Woody Allen:Culture Shock
description: TO describe "Interiors" as Woody Allen's first serious drama is to stress the irrelevant. Mostly, though, it's to overlook the earnestness of all his comedies, from "Take the Money and Run" to "Annie Hall," as well as the upside-down gravity of his familiar comic locutions that shrink Large Subjects to takeout size. "There is no question that there is an unseen world," he once wrote in a trenchant essay titled "Examining Psychic Phenomena." "The problem is, how far is it from midtown and how late is it open?"All of Mr. Allen's films have been serious to a certain degree, and they have been getting seriouser and seriouser as he has developed into one of America's most original, most personal, most audacious writer-directors. "Annie Hall" is a comedy of rare spirit, and it's as serious as any American film made in the last decade.Rather than describe "Interiors" as his first serious drama, I think it's more precise to say that it's the first Woody Allen film that doesn't care to be funny, That's something else entirely."Interiors," which opens today at the Baronet, is a culture shock. Not to be prepared for it is to embark on a Miami Beach vacation having just taken a total immersion course in 17th-century English literature."Interiors" looks beautiful. It has been photographed by Gordon Willis in cool colors that suggest civilization's precarious control of natural forces. Woody himself is nowhere to be seen. It actually looks very much like an Ingmar Bergman film, and even sounds like one  the specific flatness of the Allen dialogue, its fondness for the jargon of the analysand, being the spoken equivalent to the not always inspired but perfectly functional English subtitles for Mr. Bergman's Swedish dialogue.There is even something foreign about the members of the middle-class New York family who are the center of the drama. They seem as socially disconnected from the world around them as they are emotionally and psychically disconnected from themselves and from one another. It's not simply that the movie concentrates so intensely on its characters, but that there are virtually no other people in sight. We do see people passing in the street, in corridors, in cars on highways, and we see, one time each, a small child and a Protestant minister, but it still seems as if the family inhabited its own empty, very spooky universe."Interiors" is not inaptly titled. From the opening sequence, a series of shots looking out at the sea from the sparely furnished rooms of a large, handsome Long Island beach house, it's apparent that we are to be given a film about emotional drain, unfulfilled longings and vaguely defined fears  things that are never easy to describe and always difficult to dramatize. Mr. Allen's characters are in the furious grip of making do. They are seized  and sometimes overcome  by the need to accommodate the common-place.They are Renata (Diane Keaton), the eldest daughter who is identified as a successful poet, and her husband Frederick (Richard Jordan), who is an unsuccessful novelist; Joey (Marybeth Hurt), the youngest daughter, a failed artist and actress who'd like to write and who lives on scratchy terms with a film maker named Mike (Sam Waterston); Flyn (Kristin Griffith), the middle daughter, a successful actress who makes dopey television films; Eve (Geraldine Page), the mother of the girls, an interior decorator and a woman who remains on the edge of despair because her longtime marriage to Arthur (E.G. Marshall), a very rich lawyer, is coming apart, and Pearl (Maureen Stapleton), the buxom, warmhearted widow Arthur now wants to marry.My problem with "Interiors" is that although I admire the performances and isolated moments, as well as the techniques and the sheer, headlong courage of this great, comic, film-making philosopher, I haven't any real idea what the film is up to. It's almost as if Mr. Allen had set out to make someone else's movie, say a film in the manner of Mr. Bergman, without having any grasp of the material, or first-hand, gut feelings about the characters. They seem like other people's characters, known only through other people's art.Could it possibly be that "Interiors" is really a Brooklyn Jewish boy's fantasy about middle-class American Protestantism? But I'm not even sure whether the family in the movie is Protestant, Catholic or Jewish. They could be anything because they are placed in no identifiable social context, something that Mr. Bergman never has had to worry about (until "The Serpent's Egg") because he has always dealt with the terrors of a thoroughly homogenized society.Miss Page, looking a bit like a youthful Louise Nevelson with mink-lashed eyes, is marvelous  erratically kind, impossibly demanding, pathetic in her loneliness and desperate in her anger. Miss Stapleton beautifully projects the tone and feelings of a sweet, robust, coarse woman who is never, never ridiculous. Mr. Marshall is also fine as the husband whose desperation matches his wife's, though it is disciplined by purpose. The other roles are more difficult to judge because the material is so nebulous.Miss Hurt is very appealing as the youngest daughter who hates her mother and, thus, goes out of her way to convince herself she doesn't. Her feelings of creative impotence are also understandable, but I don't know what we are meant to feel for her when she writes in her diary, "Today I couldn't help experiencing a few nostalgic memories." She suddenly sounds like one of those humorless college types  a young woman who aspires to talk beyond her degree  that appear so frequently in Mr. Allen's written literature.Mr. Waterston's role doesn't make any outrageous demands on him, but Mr. Jordan's unsuccessful novelist  as written  is very much the bearded, hard-drinking, tough-talking novelist that's been a Hollywood clich since movies began to talk. He just writes for higher-toned periodicals (The New York Review of Books).The most difficult role is Miss Keaton's. It's probably impossible to write or act convincingly a character who's supposed to be a successful poet. Just what constitutes success for a poet? Being published in The New Yorker? Winning famous awards (never mentioned in the film)? Not combing your hair and still looking great? Being miserable? From the dialogue and insights Mr. Allen gives her, Renata sounds as if she might really be quite a bad poet, at least when she goes on about being "hyper-aware of her body."Though the movie looks beautiful, the elegant style occasionally works against it, showing it up. This happens in a striking close-up of Miss Keaton, sitting alone on a photogenically windswept ocean beach as she is supposed to be thinking sensitive poet-type thoughts. Yet the image is empty. It's not the actress. It's not the director, whose close-ups of Miss Keaton in "Annie Hall" burst with love, pride and affection. The movie that contains the image fails to invest it with any associations whatsoever.

title: 2 of 5 Murder Charges Dismissed By Judge in the Jascalevich Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 1  The presiding judge in the trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich dismissed two of the five murder charges against the surgeon today because, he said, the state had not proved that curare was present in two of the bodies.

A Chinese academic figure who confirmed the story said that within two years the figure may be as high as 10.000.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  Margaret Costanza resigned as an assistant to the President today, citing differences over her approach to issues with President Carter's inner circle of top assistants. She met yesterday with President Carter,. who accepted her resignation with re. gret.

title: America's Grain Reserve

Wheat holdings alone are at 370 million bushels, about twothirds of a year's domestic food use. Since addi- tions to the stock are still under way, is possible that the reserve eventually may approach the huge billionbushel stocks held in the early 1960's.

title: Carey Calls New York Ahead in Responding To Rising Crime Rate
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 2  Attempting to counter Republican charges that his administration is soft on crime, Governor Carey told a meeting of police chiefs tonight that New York leads the other states in its response to the skyrocketing crime rate.

title: James Robertson, a Labor Leader
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP) James R. Robertson, a former grocery warehouseman who helped found and organize the West Coast longshoremen's union, died here yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: Music: Serkin, Schneider and Ma at Mozart Festival
description: THE success of the Mostly Mozart concerts in Avery Fisher Hall is little short of a phenomenon. Night after night the hall is sold out, with an overflow on the stage, and so it was on Tuesday night for the program of chamber music. An eager audience, anticipatory and enthusiastic, was on hand to greet the three musicians of the eveningPeter Serkin, pianist, Alexander Schneider, violinist, and YoYo Ma, cellist. They played Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert.

title: Pressmen Gain Support Of 8 Newspaper Unions
description: Eight member unions of the Allied Printing Trades Council pledged support yesterday to New York Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 in its contract dispute with The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post, according to George E. McDonald, council president.

title: Jazz: A New McLaughlin
description: RMN fell steadily throughout a performance by the English jazzrock group Brand X at the Dr Pepper Festival in Central Park Tuesday evening. To com. pound the misery, the band was touring without its guitarist, who had acute tendinitis, and the reduced lineup of keyboards, bass, drums, and percussion left something to be desired.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Before moving into our turn-ofthecentury house a year ago we had refinished a large chest of drawers that has been in my family for many years . Of.course, none of the drawers or the chest itself were finished on the inside. Now all the drawers, which worked fine before, seem to be hard to open and close. A lubricant helped a little, but not enough. Do you think the refinishing affected the drawers in some way and do you have any suggestions about what to do?  H.P.K., Chicago, Ill.

description: LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters)  British flight controllers today demanded a big reduction, for safety reasons, in the number of planes bypassing French space by flying over the Atlantic.

title: F.B.I. Was Told a Missourian Paid Ray in King Murder, Report Shows
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Federal Bureau of Investigation received a report in 1979 that a Missouri businessman was the individual who made the payoff of James Earl Ray after the killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., according to documents made public today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Opens Higher, Reversing Tokyo Slide
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 3  The dollar. at least temporarily checked its precipitate slide on the foreign-exhange market here, opening today at 186.10 yen, up 1.5 yen from yesterday's close.

It's perched .on the shores of Lake Montauk, on the farthest tip of Long Island, and within reach are water sports, fishing and even such landlocked nursuits as golf and tennis.

description: BAGUIO, the Philippines, Aug. 2 Viktor Korchnoi produced a marvel of adjournment analysis to draw his apparently hopeless position against Anatoly Karpov in the seventh game of their world championship chess match here tonight.

description: HAVANA, Aug. 2  Cuba accused the United States Central Intelligence Agency today of fabricating evidence in order to,link Havana with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and thus justify further American efforts to overthrow the Castro Government.

title: Fire Department's Greatest Toll: 12 Died on 23d St. 12 Years Ago
description: Yesterday's death of six firemen was the city's most grievious loss of firefighters in a single incident since a dozen firemen were killed 12 years ago when a floor collapsed while they were fighting a fire in a drugstore on West 23d Street. The 12 deaths constituted the worst such tragedy ever in New York.

title: 4 NEW YORK BEACHES CLOSED BY OIL SPILL

title: Ithaca Crafts Fair To Open Saturday
description: ITHACA TWENTYFIVE years ago, some local craftsmen took the books off the shelves of the town library here and displayed their own works  and the town has never been the same. On Saturday, the customary tranquillity of the Ithaca College campus overlooking Lake Cayuga will be interrupted by the hustle and bustle of Craft Fair Ithaca. For a week, the works of more than 200 craftsmen from all over the state will be exhibited and sold at New York State's oldest craft fair.

title: Factories Orders Off 0.3% in June

description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday that it was unlikely that the industry or his company would seek another across-the-board price increase for the rest of this year.

title: Herbs in the City
description: For those just beginning to learn about herbs, Cornell Univer. sity has issued a 40page booklet, Gardening with Herbs, by Harriet B. Flannery and Robert G. Mower. Detailed instructions for growing and using 50 common herbs are provided.

title: Rutgers Report Urges Joint Action By U.S. and State to Aid Pinelands
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 2  A Rut. gers University research group warned today that immediate Federal and state action was needed if the delicate ecological balance in the 2 millionacre Pinelands was to be preserved.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FIVE KEYBOARDS Greenwich Village remains a music mecca, indoors and out, and visitors thronging the Sheridan Square area last weekend could have had a full evening of sidewalk listening alone. A Christopher Street crowd gathered for a woman cradling taperecorder accompaniment to her piercing Irish ballads. Over by the bank, two young men played Scott Joplin on a clarinet and flute. Down on Bleecker, a gospel quartet was drawing hearty applause, and up near 14th Street a student trio drew an ovation for Bach's second Brandenburg Concerto.

title: Venezuela Finding That Problems Come With Oil Wealth
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  As long as oil money has flowed in abundance, this nation of 12.5 million, with the highest per capita income in Latin America, has shown an enormous capacity for spending it.

title: A Mousse in the Face For Hamilton Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  It was not pie, or even mud, in the eye for Hamilton Jordan, a top Presidential assistant, last night. It was chocolate mousse in the face.

title: Bridge:
description: TORONTO, Aug. 2  The Spingold knockout team title was won here in the early hours of this morning by a quintet headed by Malcolm Bractunan of Dallas and including Bob Goldman and Mike Passell of Dallas and Paul Soloway and Eddie Kantar of Los Aneeles.

title: Brief Biographies of the Six Killed in Blaze
description: Several suitcases lined an otherwise empty hallway in the home of Harold F. Hastifigs last night, reminders of the vacation the family was planning to begin today at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla. Yesterday was to be Mr. Hastings last day at work at the 156th Ladder Company before leaving with his wife and three children for their eagerly awaited holiday.

title: Economic Scene
description: WITH inflation now back to doubledigit rates, pressure is mounting on the Administration to devise a quick fix. And that likely means a Taxbased Incomes Policy.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: On Tenants
description: In an effort to help tenants and landlords understand the numerous laws governing apartments in New York City, the Citizens Housing & Planning Council of New York has published a pamphlet, What Every Landlord and Tenant Should Know.

title: Shoemaker Banned on Coast
description: DEL MAR, Calif. (AP)  Bill Shoemaker, who has ridden more winners than any other jockey in the history of thoroughbred racing, was suspended today by the Del Mar Board of Stewards for careless riding. ShrwarnalePr mil be sidelined for five racing days starting Saturday as the result of his disqualification aboard firstfinishing Run Proud in Monday's seventh race at Del Mar.

description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: ACOSTAAmelia (nee Diaz), beloved wile of the late Eusebio, loving mother of Moses and Daniel, dear grandmother of Ricard, Douglas and Andrea. Reposing at Horne Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 W. 23 St. NYC. Chapel services Thurs. 7PM. Funeral services Fri 1PM.

title: Rev. George B. Ford, a Crusader For Civil Rights and Ecumenism
description: The Rev. George Barry Ford, one of New York's most widely known Roman --Catholic priests and a champion of civil rights, died Tuesday at the Mary Manning Walsh residence at 71st Street and York Avenue. He was 92 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: New Editor for House Beautiful
description: LESS than a year after she took over the reins as editor in chief of House Beautiful, Doris Shaw has had those reins taken from herand very suddenly.

title: Censured Judge In the Bay State Resigning Post
description: BOSTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)  Robert M. Bonin resigned today as head of the Massachusetts Superior Court, becoming the first Chief Justice in state history driven from the bench for judicial misconduct.

title: A Sect Leader in India Is Released in Killings Of 6 Former Disciples
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 2  Prabhat Ranjan Sarkar, a former railway clerk who heads a controversial and mysterious Indian religious sect, was released today on bail after nearly seven years imprisonment for the murders of several of his followers.

title: Trudeau Rejects an Early Election, Reveals $2 Billion Cut in Spending
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 2  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, ruling out the early national election that had been widely expected, announced last night a $2 billion cut in Government spending and reductions in taxes, among other measures to carry out decisions made at the recent economic summit conference in Bonn.

title: Chinaglia Falters but Cosmos Win, 21
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Upset early in the day with the Cosmos for not bringing all their regulars for the second year in a row to Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, the Washington Diplomats were even more upset after the game tonight when the outplayed Cosmos emerged with a 21 victory.

title: Factory Life: For Many, Payday's the Time for Grumbling
description: To a stranger wandering through the gray, dim expanses of the Angler's Company Ltd. factory, Wednesday morning would not seem much different from any other morning. The ma- chines continue to rise and fall, pressing and shaping vinyl into stationery

title: World Gold
description: WFDNFSDAY. AUG. 2. 1978

title: People In Sports
description: I'm not tired at all  I feel strong, said Mark (The Bird) Fidrych of the Lakeland Tigers yesterday after his third and longest effort in the Florida State League, where he is recuperating from tendinitis in his pitching shoulder. Fidrych threw 65 pitches Tuesday night, one more than his previous four- inning outing against Winter Haven, walked two and didn't allow a ball to be hit out of the infield. He is scheduled to pitch three innings on Saturday in Lakeland and return to Detroit on Sunday. If everything goes well, he'll start for the Tigers against the Texas Rangers next Wedenesday....Rivelino, the Brazilian soccer star, signed a twoyear contract with Al Hilal, a Saudi Arabian team. Although terms were not disclosed, Prince Halzoul Ibn Abdul Aziz, team president, said they were for $5 million to $9 million. He begins play on Sept.5.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Rep. Crane of Illinois Is the First In Republican Race for President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Representative Philip M. Crane, pledging to lead free people liberated from excessive government, announced his candidacy for President today as the first entrant in what may become the most crowded Republican field in decades.

title: E.P.A. Sues Ohio Utility Concern On Charges of Polluting the Air
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP) suit was filed in Federal court today by the Environmental Protection Agency against the Akronbased Ohio Edison Company, charging the utilitY with unacceptable air pollution at its Sammis plant in Jefferson County.

title: Prices Rise 3% On Mazda Cars
description: TOKYO, Aug. 2 (AP)  The Toyo Kogyo Company, the maker of Mazda cars, has announced an average 3 percent increase in the prices of autos exported to the United States, effective today.

title: Honest Money
description: WASHINGTONWe have been learning for some time that inflation damages the economy and all that live by it. But inflation does more than material damage.

title: The Dance: A Diamond Premiere
description: MATTHEW Diamond knows how to give performers lively material to dance. Yet that material doesn't always make good choreographic sense. He assembled some sleek. Dol- isned dancers tor 3 by Matthew Diamond, presented Tuesday night at the City University Graduate Center Mall as part of the Clark Center Dance Festival. But his choreography was merely slick.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Deborah Kerr Stars In Comedy Revival
description: Deborah Kerr will open in a revival of Frederick Lonsdale's hit comedy of the 1920's, The Last of Mrs. Cheyney, at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Aug. 26. Previews start Aug. 21. Frank Dunlop of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and London's Young Vic company will direct.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide. compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Terrorists Blow Up Ulster Office
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 2 (Reuters)  Provisional Irish Republican Army terrorists destroyed a tax office here today after forcing out security staff members at gunpoint and planting explosives, according to the police.

description: Acosta, Amelia

description: THURSDAY, AUGUST 3, 1978

title: IRAQIS AGAIN SUFFER RAID BY TERRORISTS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 2 (AP) Two Arab men opened fire today on officials entering the Iraqi Consulate General here, wounding an aide and a police guard. The police said guards killed one of the attackers with a bayonet and seized the other.

title: Panel Urges Transfer of Bergen Sewage Waste to the Hudson River
description: SECAUCUS, Aug. 2  The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission today stressed the need to transfer the bulk of Bergen County's treated sewage waste water to the Hudson River instead of continuing to dump it in the ecologically fragile northern stretches of the Hackensack River in the Meadowlands

title: 4 BEACHES IN QUEENS CLOSED BY OIL SPILL
description: Four New York City beaches  at Breezy Point, Riis Park, Rockaway Beach and Far Rockaway, all in Queens  were ordered closed to public bathing about 4:30 P.M. yesterday when the Coast Guard reported that a sudden shift in the wind had sent oil that had been spilled from a barge flowing toward them.

title: NEW &
description: Most miniature electric fans on the market today are those streamlined little things with a rotary blade that look just great but don't do much more than rustle the papers on one's desk. For those wanting more of a rush, Caframo Ltd., at Wiarton, Ontario, has come up with a new minifan guaranteed to really stir things up. Six inches high, six inches wide and 51/2 inches deep, the Caframo fan weighs only 1 pound, 10 ounces and has a twospeed motor housed in a small plastic case held aloft by a triangular wire frame. Although the blade of the fan is not covered, Caframo says that it is absolutely safe because it is made of a soft plastic. Available at Ad Hoc Housewares for $26.50.

title: Montreal Facing a Challenge on Airport
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 2  Ever since Montreal's big Mirabel International Airport began operations in November 1975, it has been called a white elephant.

title: State High Court Limits Use of Binding Arbitration
description: TRENTON, Aug. 2  The State Supreme Court, in a decision strengthening the bargaining position of school boards in contract negotiations, ruled today that not all labor issues were subject to bindInc arbitration.

title: 2 Accused in a $10 Million Swindle
description: Two persons were charged yesterday with swindling scores of residents of the Williamsburg and Borough Park sections of Brooklyn out of more than $10 million by promising part ownerships in several realestate ventures offering a return of 10 percent a year

title: A PLOT ON ONASSIS CHARGED IN ARTICLE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP)  Richard M. Nixon, who was then Vice President; Warren E. Burger, then a Justice Department employee, and Robert A. Maheu, onetime aide to Howard R. Hughes, were part of a 1959 plot directed against the late Aristotle Onassis because of his shipping power, according to an article in the September issue of Playboy magazine.

title: Negligence in '77 Nightclub Fire Held Not Criminal by Grand Jury
description: NEWPORT, Ky., Aug. 2 (UPI)  A special Campbell County grand jury said today that it had not found any evidebce of criminal negligence in the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire on May 28, 1977, in which 165 persons were killed.

title: Deaths
description: CAHNJuliette on August 1, 1978 in New Rochelle, NY. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Cahn, devoted mother of the late Harold D. Cahn. Many years active member Madison Club of Brooklyn. A true Sister of the Eastern Star, resident of the United Home of New Rochelle and President of the Residence Council for S consecutive years. Survived by granddaughter, Barbara Nathan and great granddaughter Susan Meredith Nathan both of South Orange, NJ. Funeral services were held at Mount Hope Cemetery, Brooklyn.

description: Millions of barrels

title: SIX FIREMEN KILLED AS ROOF COLLAPSES AT BROOKLYN BLAZE
description: Six firemen fell to their deaths as the blazing roof of a Brooklyn supermarket collapsed yesterday morning. It was the worst accident involving the city's firefiehters in a dozen years.

title: Newark Historic Project Opposed
description: NEWARK, Aug. 2  Two black Newark City Councilmen objected today to the attention being given by the city and state to the rehabilitation of a historic downtown area of Newark known as the James StreetCommons while, they contended, other neighborhoods are sufferine from neglect and datarinra nnn

title: McCowen to Read Bible on TV for 2 Hours
description: LOS ANGELES WARNER BROS. TELEVISION will produce a twohour television program in which Alec McCowen, the British actor who starred in Hadrian VII on Broadway, stands on an empty stage and narrates the Gospel according to St. Mark.

title: Chilean Leader Discusses Extradition in Letelier Case
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 2  President Augusto Pinochet confirmed today that three former officers of Chile's secret police were being held under military arrest here for possible extradition to the United States for trial in the murder of Orlando Letelier.

title: Enough of Mr. Young
description: Once again the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, Andrew Young, has played to the audiance with an offhand, eyecatching statement embarrassing to his nominal boss, the President of the United States, and injurious to the conduct of a rational American foreign policy.

title: Pictorial Parade
description: PEKINGHANOI TENSIONS RISE: Chinese leaving Vietnam because of alleged harassment wait at the border with China for official admittance into that country. Yesterday, China accused Vietnamese guards at the frontier checkpoint of forcing about 2,000 panicstricken refugees across the border by shooting into the air. The incident is likely to be discussed at talks between Chinese and Vietnamese officials next Tuesday in Hanoi.

EARNINGS CocaCola Net Up 13.1%; Greyhound Profits Rise
description: The CocaCola Company, the world's largest soft drink maker, yesterday reported a 13.1 percent gain in secondquarter profits from the period a year earlier and a 20.8 percent increase in quarterly sales.

title: Resignation of 2 Aides Confirmed by Citibank
description: Citibank disclosed yesterday that two officers who had directed the bank's moneymarket and foreign-exchange operations in Paris and Brussels had resigned.

title: GARDENING
description: HERBS may not be the most beautiful plants  some are even ugly  but their scents and flavors earn them a special place in a garden. Their other redeeming quality is that the less you fuss over them the better they grow, even in rather ordinary soil.

title: Model Agency Helps Animals Ousted by a Fire
description: One of the city's leading modeling agencies provided temporary shelter yesterday to 60 animals that were removed from the Humane Society Building on 59th Street because of a fire in a nextdoor naint store.

title: Rep. Crane of Illinois Is the First In Republican Race for President
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Representative Philip M. Crane, pledging to lead free people liberated from excessive government, announced his candidacy for President today as the first entrant in what may become the most crowded Republican field in decades.

title: Times and Reporter Are Given a Stay Until Tomorrow
description: M. A. Farber, the reporter for The New York Times who last week was ordered jailed until he turned over his notes for possible use in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, won a lastminute, twoday stay yesterday from Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court.

title: A Threat to Spanish Democracy
description: EVANSTON, 111,Crucial questions about the future of Spanish democracy were raised recently after national policemen charged into the bullring at Pamplona to break up a fight between

title: It's Easier in the Television Commercial
description: It looks so easy on television. Nice ride, Robyn, a man says as America's bestknown female jockey celebrates another winner by pouring herself a glass of diet soda. But those are only makebelieve winners, the easy kind arranged for television commercials. In racing's real world, nothing has been going easily lately for Robyn Smith.

title: The New York Times/ Penny Coleman
description: FOOD, FOOD AND MORE FOOD: Some of the fare available at the San Gennaro festival at the Garden State Plaza in Paramus yesterday were Italian sausage, pizza and candied apples. The festival will run through next Tuesday.

title: Amid the Burning Flames
description: Last Sunday, the worship was conducted outdoors, in the west yard of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark'sIn-The-Bowery, behind the fieldstone walls, the blackened steeple, the fallen roof and all the debris of the fire which so badly damaged that lovely church 179 years old  just days before. The Rev. David Garcia offered the mass and delivered the sermon. He said, It is from tragedy that life comes, from ashes that resurrection begins. The congregation sang, If you walk amid the burning flames, you shall not be harmed.

title: Erie Joins Islanders
description: ERIE, Pa., Aug. 2 (UPI) The Erie Blades of the defunct North American Hockey League became part of the New York Islanders farm system yesterday. Jim Devellano. chief of scout. ing for the Islanders, said many of New York's draft choices will be sent directly to the Erie team. The N.A.H.L. is in the process of reorganizing and is hopeful of playing in the 197879 season.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Home Improvement
description: FLUORESCENT lighting fixtures have long been used in kitchens, laundry rooms, bathrooms and the like, but in recent years they have become increasingly popular for use in other rooms throughout the house because they are much more economical than incandescent lamps and because the tubes last much loneer than bulbs. A 40-watt fluo- rescent tube, tor example, will put out between four and five times as much light as a 40watt incandescent bulb and will last anywhere from six to eight times as long.

title: G.O.P. Bill On Tax Cut Is Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  A Library of Congress analysis of the KempRoth taxcut bill disputes the assertions of its Republican sponsors that the measure would be selffinancing through its stimulative effect on the economy.

title: McEnroe Is 3Set Victor Amid Boos: Vilas Wins
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 2John McEnroe marked the second day of play In the $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament with a victory tempered by numerous vocal outbursts. The fiery 19yearold from Douglaston, Queens, questioned line calls throughout his long match at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Sound
description: Hans Fantel

title: Alleged Curare Victims Were Pale, Not Blue, ExHospital Aides Recall
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 2  Former staff members at Riverdell Hospital testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the alleged victims had been pale just before they died and had not had the blue color associated with curare poisoing.

title: Report Sees Small Gain In Northeast Shift to Coal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Oil constunption in New England mild be cut only 7 percent at most even if all the electric utilities and industries capable of burning coal converted from oil to coal as their main fuel, a Congressional report said today.

description: BUSINESS Digest

title: Lawyer Protests Blackout Of SpinksAli Fight
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP)  The Miami lawyer who successfully ended television blackouts for Super Bowl games said today he would protest the planned regional blackout for the Muhammad All Leon Spinks heavyweight fight.

title: Various Corporations Report Their Quarterly Sales and Earnings Results
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthe, counter.

title: Safest L.I. Beach? Lifeguards Settle That
description: By Tournament

title: TV: Arson: Fire for Hire
description: IT will come as no surprise to most New Yorkers that arson, which has destroyed large areas of the city, is a serious menace to life and property. However, Arson: Fire for Hire, an American Broadcasting Company News Closeup that will be shown tonight from 10 to 11, points out that the incidence of arson throughout the United States is increasing faster than any other serious crime.

title: Hispanic Arts Festival At Lincoln Center Aug. 20
description: The Association of Hispanic Arts will begin its third annual Hispanic Arts Festival on Aug. 20 at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center. A 2 P.M. performance by the Pete Elcondo Rodriguez and Primitivo Santos orchestras, Ballet Hispnic, Central Cultural Ballet Quisqueya and Loizenon de New Haven will start the twoweek series of activities, performances and exhibitions to be presented throughout the five boroughs.

title: Betting on Lebanon's Phantom Army
description: It is no great exaggeration to say that all that remains of Lebanon is a wouldbe President, a wouldbe Cabinet and a wouldbe army of 650 men. The wouldbe Government has now sent the wouldbe army south to the region bordering on Israel to assert, if that is the word, a sovereign presence. It can do so not by the strength of its arms but only with the diplomatic consent of Syria and Israel. The question for them and other interested governments, like our own, is whether this banner is worth raising.

title: Light Truck Sales Vroom Past Autos
description: DETROIT, Aug. 2  In many sections of the nation today lightweight trucks are outselling passenger cars by a country mile.

title: Greece Criticizes U.S. for Lifting the Arms Embargo Against Turkey
description: ATHENS, Aug. 2  The Greek Government expressed sorrow today at decision by the United States Congress to end the embargo on arms shipments to Turkey, and warned that its lifting would make it more difficult to solve the problems that have brought Greece and Turkey to the brink of war.

title: Nude Bathers Ask Legal Sanction
description: Gibson Lane Beach, a secluded halfmile strip of sand about one mile east of Bridgehampton, L.I., has become a sort of battleground involving the Southampton police and scores of people who like to sun themselves and bathe in the nude.

title: Pacific Bell Debt Issue
description: The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company's $150 million debenture issue marketed yesterday was priced to give investors a yield of 8% percent, a quarterpoint below a Bell System bond issue that was sold a month ago and 10 or 12 basis points lower than what investment bankers estimated as recently as Tuesday afternoon.

title: A.&P. to Offer Trading Stamps
description: In a move that left some supermarket observers shaking their heads in disbelief, the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company yesterday introduced Gold Bond and S. & H. trading stamps into onequarter of its 1,800 stores in seven of its divisions nationwide.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Dorothy Henry Wins Lawn Bowling Singles
description: BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Aug. 2Dorothy Henry of the Central Park Lawn Bowling Club won the singles competition of the 13th American Lawn Bowlers Association Eastern Division tournament on Sunday by defeating Toni Mercer of the New York Lawn Bowline Club.

title: About New York
description: Making Illusion and Reality Inseparable

title: TOTIE FIELDS DEAD; COMEDIENNE WAS 48
description: Totie Fields, the raucousvoiced nightclub comedienne whose jokes about her obesity and whose struggle to resume her career after the amputation of her left leg two years ago won her the affection of millions, died yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev. She was 48 years old and lived in Las Vegas and in Los Angeles.

title: Stock Redemption
description: The Federal Paper Board Company announced that it would redeem all its outstanding 4.6 percent cumulative preferred stock on Sept. 15. The redemption price will be $25 a share plus accrued and unpaid dividends. The company said a dividend of 283/4 cents share on the stock had been declared and was payable on Sept. 15 to holders of record Aug. 31.

title: Notes on People
description: ASPOKESMAN for TuftsNew England Medical Center in Boston said yesterday that John Cardinal Wright was in satisfactory condition after undergoing neurosurgery to correct a muscle disorder in the legs. The 69-year-old Cardi- nal, the highestranking American prelate attached to the Vatican, is Prefect of the Congregation for the Clergy. He entered the Boston hospital June 20 after being confined to a wheelchair several months ago because of polymyositis, an inflammation and degeneration of the leg muscles. ... Walter W. Heller, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, was reported recuperating at home after surgery for the removal of a cancerous prostate gland. Mr. Heller, now a University of Minnesota economics professor, underwent surgery three weeks ago.

title: Vermont Sues Wire Concerns
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 2 (AP) The State Attorney General, M. Jerome Diamond, said that his office had filed suit against six electricalwiring supply companies for alleged price fixing,

title: Connery and Caine Settle Suits Against Allied Artists
description: Sean Cannery and Michael Caine have reached an amicable out-ofcourt settlement of lawsuits the actors had filed against the Allied Artists Pictures Corporation.

title: SIX FIREMEN KILLED AS ROOF COLLAPSES AT BROOKLYN BLAZE
description: Burst of Flame Swallows Victims at Market  Union Charges Delay on Second Alarm

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of America has elected Richard Puz as executive vice president in the World Banking division and Merrill Ring as senior vice president to head the research department of the Bank Investment Securities division.

title: Issue for Finns Becomes Urgent: After Kekkonen, Who?
description: HELSINKI  In Finland, there is one question that never goes away. People have been posing it for almost a decade, but never with more urgency than now. Who, the politicians and diplomats ask one another, will succeed Urho Kekkonen as President?

title: U.S. Is Reported to Fine Food Inspection Official
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  The Agriculture Department has reprimanded the head of its food inspection service, Robert Angelotti, and fined him 10 days pay for falsifying expense accounts, according to Congressional hivestigators.

title: F.B.I. Was Told a Missourian Paid Ray in King Murder, Report Shows
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Federal Bureau of Investigation received a report in 1974 that a Missouri businessman was the individual who made the payoff of James Earl Ray after the killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., according to documents made public today.

title: Goodyear to Revamp Akron Tire Factory
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP)  The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plans to invest $75 million in the renovation of its old Plant 2 tire factory for new office and laboratory space.

title: Design Notebook
description: A GARDEN is a lovesome thing, the poet said. He was entitled to his opinion, no doubt, but I prefer a post office any day. A Post Office, to be precise, with a big P and a big O.

title: Deaths
description: MORRELLJoseph J. On Aug tst. 1978. Beloved husband of Lillie. Brother of Samuel. Founder and oast President of The Spirits Square Club of New York. Services Fri. Aug 4th 1978 10:30AM. Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76th St, NY.

title: CARTER AIDE BARRED FROM O'NEILL OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Furious over a White House decision to dismiss a close friend, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, has refused to deal President Carter's chief Congressional liaison officer, according to a top O'Neill aide.

title: Suffolk Ban on Funds To Finance Abortions Voided by State Court
description: A justice in State Supreme Court in Riverhead, L.I., ruled yesterday that the Suffolk County Legislature acted illegally when it adopted a resolution directing that no county funds be used for abortions.

title: Dow Advances by 22.78; Gain Bizzest in 31/2 Years
description: Stock prices posted their biggest advance in three and a half years yesterday, apparently responding to hopes that interest rates would soon level off. The Dow Jones industrial average curved ahead nearly 23 nnints.

title: Joseph Harari, a Trade Specialiit And Shipping Concern President
description: Joseph Harari, president of American Trade Sales Inc., a shipping agency, drowned Monday in a flash flood in Punggaluku, Indonesia, according to reports received in New York yesterday. He was 56 years old.

title: 22 Summonses Are Issued on Dog Law's First Day
description: On the second day of the canine litter law, dog owners continued to scoop, bag and dispose of what their dogs left behind  or at least the owners did so when the police were watchine.

title: Hudson's Bay to Bid For Zeller's Interest
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, in move to increase its interests in retailing, said that it intended to make an offer for all common stock of Zeller's Ltd., a Montrealbased store chain, except for an estimated 6.4 shares held by Zeller's subsidiaries.

title: Times Reporter Given Summons From Court In Moscow Libel Case
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2  Craig R. Whitney of The New York Times was served today with a summons to appear tomorrow at the Moscow City Court.

title: HEALTH CHIEF CALLS WASTE SITE A PERIL
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. Aug. 2  Citing a great and imminent peril, Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the New York State Health Commissioner, recommended today that pregnant women and infants up to 2 years of age leave their homes in the contaminated Love Canal area of this city immediately, and that the public school on the property not open in the fall.

title: Relatives Told The Sad News At a Firehouse
description: The blond, longhaired youth pulls his soupedup Pontiac to an abrupt halt in front of the red doors of the firehouse on Geritsen Avenue in Brooklyn and, despite his crutches, rushes toward a uniformed fireman.

title: INCITEMENT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2  The National Broadcasting Company scored an important procedural victory today in the socalled Born Innocent trial when the judge agreed to limit the trial to the question of whether the showing of the controversial television movie had incited four children to imitate one of the scenes by sexually abusing a 9-year-old girl.

title: House Asks End Of Ban on Trade With Rhodesia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The House of Representatives voted today to lift economic sanctions against Rhodesia if a freely elected government is established by the end of the year.

title: French Air Controllers To Call Off Slowdown Until Transport Talks

title: Film: 'Magic of Lassie,' at Music Hall:Jaded Pooch
description: "THE MAGIC OF LASSIE," the latest ill-advised lulu at the Radio City Music Hall, begins with a song. James Stewart, playing the newest of Lassie's kindly old grandpas, leads two children in a number about "that hometown feelin'" and how wonderful life's simple virtues are. But in a movie in which the local grocery is a supermarket, the old-timey furniture is straight out of a Sears catalogue and the "bricks" by the hearth look like wallpaper, this kind of sentimentality is genuinely distressing. If anything, "The Magic of Lassie" is a testament to the creeping modernization of just about everything worthwhile. Even Lassie, who used to be just a smart, good-hearted and very, very clean dog, has developed the jaded manner of a veteran movie star.The ostensible villain of the piece is an evil zillionaire (Pernell Roberts), who means to steal Lassie, rename her "Heatherbelle," and annex Grandpa's land to his own vineyards. These lackluster ambitions give rise to a lackluster plot, but never mind  the real heavies are offscreen, creating a monster of a score. The songs, written by Robert B. Sherman and Richard N. Sherman, and sung by either Debby or Pat Boone, are not to be wished upon even that most cloying of creatures, the show-biz dog.It's a well-known fact that Lassie, now a direct male descendant of the original male collie (female collies supposedly have less photogenic coats), has some very special talents. He/she has sixth, seventh and eighth senses when it comes to returning home or retrieving lost children and kittens. And he/she can understand remarks made in English, replying with a hearty "Bark, bark!" from time to time.But until now, Lassie's gift for breaking into song (via voiceovers) had been largely unexploited. No more: This time, as Lassie wanders forlornly along a railroad track. Miss Boone supplies Lassie-ish thoughts in the background. Sample lyric: "I'm gonna get free by and by / I'm gonna get my patch of the sky."Then there are the numbers attributed to the little boy who has loved and (temporarily) lost his magical pet: "Lassie, my Lassie, I don't know why/But Lassie, I can't say goodbye." And, most reprehensible of all, there is the episode in which Lassie, having of course run away from his/her wicked new master, stumbles across the entire Mike Curb congregation in a country field, just as they happen to be rehearsing a big banjo number.To whom is all this a worse insult  the dog lover, the music lover, the child forced to sit through the film by a well-meaning relative, or the optimist who thought the Music Hall's reprieve might amount to something? Whatever your sentiments, the point is best argued at home.

title: Favored Nicklaus Begins Bid for 5th P.G.A. Today

It is commonly agreed that unless rain pours for a couple of days, nobody is going to shoot any 63's in the 60th Professional Golfers Association championship, which begins tomorrow at Oakmont with a field of 150 of the best professionals in the business.

The obedience is not universal, and one group of malcontents went to court to try to overturn the law; but for the moment, there is a discernible desire to respect it or at least to test its force. So all of us  dogowners, doglovers, doghaters and the indifferent  should applaud. It is one of those deli. cate moments of social experiment when every citizen's attitude can make a difference.

title: Small Classes Are Still Beautiful
description: The common view of good schools is that children learn better in small classes than in large ones. Indeed, the private and suburban schools of the affluent point with pride to their success with smallgroup instruction and are the envy of most other communities. But now a study by the Educational Research Service questions this faith. It has examined a variety of existing studies on class size and, without any new information, concluded that decades of research fail to justify small, overall reductions in the class size or pupilteacher ratio.

Layard is talking about the winged lions, the bulls, the black obelisk, the double sphinx, the steles and bas reliefs and the 40,000 cuneiform tablets he would send by raft to Baghdad and by ship to the British Museum:

title: Screen: Saga of a Car In 'Corvette Summer':A Double Debut
description: THERE isn't a line in "Corvette Summer" that doesn't read better than it plays. It's not just that Hal Barwood and Matthew Robbins, who make their respective producing and directing debuts, are best known as the screen-writing team responsible for "The Sugarland Express," "MacArthur" and "Bingo Long"; it's that they overstate scenes in a way they'd never dream of overwriting them.The central portion of "Corvette Summmer," set in Las Vegas with an "Alice in Wonderland" air, has a visual zaniness that meshes effectively with the script. But for the most part, the movie takes a slender, boyish conceit  of the sort that is suddenly so popular among Hollywood's current batch of boy wonders  and invests it with silliness rather than whimsy.Ostensibly, this is the story of a boy (Mark Hamill) and his car (a lovingly customized Corvette). In fact, it is the picaresque saga of a crazy, hopeless search, once the car is stolen and the boy sets out to recover it.The premise is not unlike that of "The Sugarland Express," in which a mother embarked on a long journey to recover her child, traveling across a landscape that seemed increasingly mad as the trip wore on. But Mr. Barwood and Mr. Robbins brought a wisdom to that earlier script that they deliberately eschew here, in the interests of a brand of juvenilia that simply doesn't suit them."Hal and I really aren't into cars, but we felt the Corvette was the perfect symbol for our story and our hero," Mr. Robbins is quoted as saying in production notes for the film. That's the trouble, right there: The movie seems to have been conceived in a fairly sophisticated spirit and then clumsily translated into kiddie-ese.Mr. Hamill, who had just the right insistent innocence for "Star Wars," is this time obliged to affect a navet that would be unconvincing in a tiny child. Annie Potts, as a would-be call girl he meets along his way, has Goldie Hawn's loopiness without the charm.Miss Potts may well be a gifted comedienne, but Mr. Robbins never lets her relax enough for the talent to show. Too often, he strains his actors' enthusiasm to the breaking point.Still, the middle of the movie is appealing, for anyone who can tolerate a mirthlessly nutty beginning and an ungainly shoot-'em-up finale. In Las Vegas, the half-mad buoyancy of Mr. Hamill's search for a four-wheeled Holy Grail finds an appropriately sun-baked setting, and Mr. Robbins's direction tackles pop culture with a gusto that resembles his hero's. It's a pity that the segment of the film that finally achieves a cockeyed conviction is so short-lived."Corvette Summer" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because Miss Potts's character makes no bones about what her new line of work is to be, and because of some very fleeting, dimly-lit nudity.

title: Art People
description: THE time is around 8:30 on a recent Friday night. The place, the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden, which is filled with people deployed on the chairs, the steps and around the fountains. Informal but decorous, they recline in small groups on blankets spread on the ground with the occasional bottle and paper cups, or they sit, proclaiming their loneliness by sternly reading books. Rodin's Balzac supervises them from one side of the patio, Eli Nadelman's Figure of a Hunter surveys them from another. And from across the yard, a Despiau nude seems to regard the scene with an air ofinquiry. The trees tremble a little in the breeze.

title: Film: Burt Reynolds In Action in 'Hooper':Moviemaking Fun
description: "SMOKEY AND THE BANDIT," the Burt Reynolds movie that "Hooper" both follows up and improves upon, was a nationwide blockbuster and a washout in New York. The audience for "Hooper" won't be so neatly divided, and it may even be just as big. Mr. Reynolds is one of the most effortlessly appealing movie stars around, but consolidating his following has always been a problem: There are fans who like to watch him. tearing up the highway, and there are fans who enjoy his delightfully flippant self-mockery, with all the covert thoughtfulness it implies. This time, Mr. Reynolds has made a movie to please fans of all persuasions, and to please them a great deal.The title character, whom Mr. Reynolds plays, is the greatest Hollywood stuntman of his generation. Accordingly, he is sandwiched between the battered, ex-greatest stuntman of the previous generation (Brian Keith) and a fancy young newcomer (Jan-Michael Vincent) eager to give the old boys a run for their money. Watching Mr. Vincent dive off a skyscraper, Hooper and a friend remark, with a characteristic blend of malice and merriment, "Well, we probably could've done that when we were his age  'cept they didn't have buildings that high."Hooper, who is working as stunt coordinator on a movie called "The Spy Who Laughed at Danger," sees retirement in the cards. So does his doctor: "If you were a horse, I'd shoot you," the doctor remarks, looking over the latest demolition job Hooper has done on his vertebrae. The presence of young, handsome and vigorous Mr. Vincent suggests the limitations time will impose on both Hooper's career as a glutton for punishment and Mr. Reynolds's as a matinee idol.But the film, while pensive enough to hint at these things, isn't so morose that it cares to dwell on them. It's far more interested in demonstrating  very convincingly  that making a movie can be more fun than almost anything else in the world.Mr. Reynolds and Hal Needham, who directed "Smokey and the Bandit," use the film-set milieu to generate some lovely in-jokes. At one point, Hooper is shown entertaining guests at a party with a reel of his favorite stunts, including some of Mr. Reynolds's own white-water work in "Deliverance." The guests are fast asleep.And then there is the highly unpopular director of the spy film, played with wonderfully humorless self-importance by Robert Klein. Concocting a finale that involves cars crashing into people in wheelchairs, buildings collapsing, explosions everywhere and a spectacular automobile jump across a river, the director is peeved to hear that his crew may not be able to execute all this. "I don't care. I want it!" he whines. "It's the ending I want. It's the statement I want to make." Later, when the elaborate scene is set up, Mr. Klein pronounces it to have "a nice grayness, like 'La Strada.'"In another scene. Mr. Klein shrieks something about movies being "pieces of time." For anyone unfamiliar with the title of Peter Bogdanovich's book of critical essays, let's just say that Mr. Reynolds has got even for "Nickelodeon" and "At Long Last Love."There is genuine humor and tenderness in Mr. Reynolds's romantic episodes with Sally Field, who plays Mr. Keith's very patient daughter, and there is real vitality in the large-scale action sequences. Also, Mr. Reynolds's generosity is particularly impressive. It's heartening to watch as scene-stealing an actor as Mr. Reynolds work this hard to make himself an ensemble player, just one of the boys."Hooper" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), largely because of the innocuous cussing that constitutes part of the stuntmen's camaraderie.

description: FRIDAY, AUGUST 4, 1978

title: 7 Men Are Arraigned On Charge of Robbing Two New York Banks
description: Seven men believed to have been involved in at least 25 bank robberies that netted them more than $250,000 since the first of the year have been arraigned over the last three days following arrests by the Federal Bureau of Investieation.

title: A Few Good Words for the British Empire
description: ABERGAVENNY, WalesChiseled on one of the structures of the Rockefeller Center in New York is the inscription British Empire Building. It is an historical curiosity, for the Empire which it commemorates, and which loomed so large in the world of the 1930's, when the Center was being built, is now no more than an equivocal memory. In its Victorian heyday the British Empire comprised nearly a quarter of the earth's land mass, and a quarter of its people. Today a few scattered islands are all that is left, and the glory is gone.

title: Lawyers for New Jersey Newspaper Seek a Court Order to Block Petition
description: CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 3Attorneys for a weekly newspaper here sought a court order today to halt a petition drive by residents and merchants in the area to curtail commercial and legal advertising in the publication, whose editorial content they find objectionable.

title: Beaths
description: MORRELLJoseph J. The California Wine Association and A. PereIIIMinetti and Sons records with deep sorrow the passing of their beloved officer. on August 1, 1978. Mr Morrell was associated with California Wine Association for over 60 years. His Passing will be deeply felt. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to the family.

title: CARLOS CHAVEZ, 79, COMPOSER, IS DEAD
description: Carlos Chavez, the composer and conductor who for more than half a century stood in the eyes of the world for the best in Mexican music, died Wednesday in Mexico City of a heart ailment. He was 79 years old.

title: ABC Ch.arged With Staging Gang Fight
description: A group of black television producers has asked the Federal Communications Commission to investigate their charges that parts of the ABC Closeup documentary "Youth Terror: The View from Behind the Gun were staged.

title: BUSIN Digest
description: Ford Motor has decldto bulld a $500 mllllon plant in Canada, subject to final nega tiations on Canadian aid. The news came on the eve of a visit by American officials proteting the aid. [Page A1.j

title: Almahurst Wins Pace, $210,000
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Aug. 3  In a teeming rain and minutes from midnight, Falcon Almahurst splashed through the stretch tonight to win the Meadowlands Pace. Instead of turning into a pumpkin, Falcon Almahurst turned into the season's biggest winner, collecting $210,000 of the $560,000 purse.

title: Watson Leads at 67; Nicklaus Is 12 Back
description: OAKMONT, Pa., Aug. 3  They'll never believe it. Jack Nicklaus, the heavy favorite to win the Professional Golfers Association championship, starts the opening round with a bogey and a double bogey and is five over par after six holes, six over par after eight holes.

title: For Firemen, Sadness Is a Part of the job
description: When an emergency call came in at 12:90 yesterday afternoon at Ladder Company 153 in Brooklyn, Lieut. Ray Jones of the Fire Department summoned his men, threw on his helmet and coat, climbed aboard a fire engine and directed the driver to the scene.

title: Children Seek Fish to Fry in Urban Pond
description: Right after they had attended a fishing clinic, 50 youngsters went to a pond in Prospect Park, in Brooklyn, to test their skill.

title: Chase Brass Finds New Way to Cast
description: in one continuous operation. The new process replaces a methodat now requires as many as 46 separate operations.

title: News Summary
description: Israeli jets streaked over Lebanon and bombed an area described as a Palestinian terrorist training camp five hours after a terrorist bomb killed an Israeli and injured 50 persons in a crowded market in Tel Aviv. An Israeli Cabinet statement announced that the air strike was in response to the attack in the market. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: Vesma Grinfelds Triumphs
description: DALLAS, Aug. 3 (AP)  Vesma Grinfelds of San Francisco romped to her seventh professional women's bowling title last night in the $25,000 Metroplex open. She won $3,000 for her effort, and finished 290 pins ahead of her tour roommate, Virginia Norton of South Gate, Calif.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: It's one entertaining thing after another this summer at Heckscher Park in Huntington, L.I., where events are scheduled daily through Aug. 20. This weekend is typical: the Orlando Ballet Company tonight at 8:30 (admission is $2); the Long Island Symphony Orchestra's free pops concert tomorrow at 8:30, with Anita Sheer, Spanish guitarist, and Luis Liciaga, Spanish folk dancer, and Sunday, Opera on the Sound's fully staged production of La Boheme at 8:30 P.M. (admission, $4). Seating is the same for all performances  blankets or chairs from home. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to Route 110; go north to Route 25A and continue on Main Street to Prime Avenue. Program information: (516) 2718923.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Casco Bank Hails Ruling by F.D.I.C.

title: Father Ford Funeral Tomorrow
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke will officiate at a funeral service at 10 A.M. tomorrow for the Rev. George Barry Ford, who was prominent as a champion of civil rights. The service will be held at the Church of Corpus Christi, 531 West 121st Street. Father Ford died on Tuesday at the age of 92 at the Mary Manning Walsh residence at 71st Street and York Avenue.

title: July Sales Of Chains Rise 10%
description: Penney, Up 25.3%, Leads the Way

title: The G.O.P.'s Pre1980 Lawsuit
description: WASHINGTONThe Republican national chairman, Bill Brock. obviously understands that money is a staple of politics and that changes in the laws regulating how much money can be raised and spent in campaigns can also produce shifts in the outcome of elections. He also believes that the current spending limits for Presidential elections  $21.8 million apiece for Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford in 1976 amount to an unfair tilt against the G.O.P.'s Presidential candidate in 1980. So the Republicans have undertaken a lawsuit, hoping to persuade the United States Supreme Court to take another look at a part of the Federal Elections Campaign Act, which it already found to be constitutional two years ago.

title: Boy, 12, Is Charged With Murder
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 3  A 12-yearold boy was arraigned in Westchester County Family Court today on charges of seconddegree murder in the stabbing death of an 18-year-old youth last Tuesday night at a group home in South Salem. N.Y.

title: Miss Navratilova Helps Lobsters Defeat Apples
description: If the Apples are going to win their third straight World Team Tennis championship, they'll have to show a lot more than they did last night at Madison Square Garden. They were roundly defeated by the Boston Lob. sters, 2719.

title: Stage: Sammy Davis in Stop the World
description: SAMMY Davis Jr. drove an updated, Americanized, occasionally downhome version of Anthony Newley and Leslie Bricusse's English musical, Stop the World I Want to Get Off, into the New York State Theater last night. The revival is scheduled for a limited engagement. The star was operating at the very top of his form. He Is a large talent as a singer, dancer, actor and mimic  who can light up any stage. Mr. Davis has been away too long from Broadway musical theater.

title: RaiIFreight Traffic Up 4.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The Association of American Railroads reported today that ht traffic on United States rai for the latest week totaled an estimated 17.3 billion tonmiles, 4.4 pe cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Jury Sworn in Lawsuit Over Television Movie
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3A jury of six men and six women was sworn tonight in San Francisco Superior Court to try a lawsuit over a television movie alleged to have inspired a sexual assault.

title: Mysterious Soviet Ship Movements Worry and Puzzle Norwegians
description: OSLO  A number of Soviet maritime violations, little noted outside Norway, have seriously strained relations between the Norwegians and the Russians, who share a short border in the Arctic.

title: For Andy North, It Was. Fun
description: As long as he lived, Fred Corcoran insisted that no golfer bad ever sunk a putt to win the United States Open. The championship has often been won by a single stroke, of course, and probably the last shot was always a putt, but on those occasions there were contenders still on the course who had to lose before the winner's victory would be established. Fred contended that no player had ever addressed his ball on the final green knowing that the putt would give him the Open, and had run it down. In the Desert Classic, yes; in the Sports of The Times Doral Invitational, sure. But never in the National Open. Never in Fred's lifetime,. that is. The great golf promoter, historian and raconteur died last year, and it wasn't until this year that a golfer sank a putt to win the Onen

title: Court Rejects Appeal By ExPupil Accusing School of Malpractice
description: Declaring that the failure to learn does not bespeak the failure to teach, the Appellate Division of the Second Judicial Department yesterday rejected a $5 million educational malpractice suit against the Copiague Union Free School District.

title: World New Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters) senior State Department official said .today that Afghanistan's three-month-old leftist GovernMent had asked the United States to step up its foreignaid program.

title: Major Changes Urged at Cairo Museum
description: A team of United States experts has recommended many changes in the use and operations of the Cairo Museum, The sprawling structure on the Nile houses the world's largest collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts and is the permanent home of the treasures from Tutankhamen's tomb.

title: From Bad to Worse on Rhodesia
description: It is hard to know what the House of Representatives thought it was doing this week when it voted to break a United Nations embargo on trade with Rhodesia as soon as the present triumvirate of black and white factions have themselves anointed by elections of their own design. We can find only two messages in the measure: (1) to Prime Minister Ian Smith and his black associates: Hang on; do not negotiate with the leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrillas; the relief Western recognition and trade resumption is on the way; (2) to the guerrillas: There's no point maneuvering for a military impasse that might lead to negotiations; as soon as elections with no guarantee of fairness to your people are held, we shall freeze you out; so you might as well do your best to disrupt the elections.

title: Ford Motor to Recall 1,475,000 78 Cars and Trucks
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP)  The Ford Motor Company will recall the first 1,475,000 automobiles and light trucks that It built in North America in the 1978 model year to correct an emission defect, the company said today.

title: Rhodesia Perspectives: U.S. Sees Tragedy While Salisbury Looks for Relief Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The Carter Administration's efforts to bring about solutions in Rhodesia and the Middle East have run into such serious political and diplomatic difficulty that doubts are Increasingly being raised here over

title: Red Sox Win, Drop Yanks 81/2 Back
description: Boston's pitching staff, serving a potion stronger than sleeping pills, put the Yankee hitters to sleep late Wednesday night and early Thursday morning, then kept them snoozing last night.

title: 'Win' at the Resorts Casino in July Shows 25 Percent Jump Over June
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 3  The win at Resorts International's gambling casino here in July was $20,652,497 for a daily average of $666,209, Resorts an. nounced today.

title: Ethics Unit to Accept Testimony Of Korean ExEnvoy in Writing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct announced today that it had agreed to accept a 1/4 longstanding Offer by the South Korean Government to make Kim Dong Jo, the former Ambassador to Washington, available for written questions about his alleged role in the Korean influencebuying scandal.

title: Blues Still Abundant Off Jersey and the Hamptons
description: AREA A  Despite recent bad weather, fishermen in this area are still reporting good catches of bluefish. Action has been lively 10 to 15 miles off Margate, N. J., in 70 or 80 feet of water where Hopkins lures and bucktails have proved most productive. Closer to shore, schools of blues in the 2to 4pound range have been caught with tubetype lures. Blues have also been abundant south of Sandy Hook, with party boats reporting catches up to 12 pounds. In Great Egg Harbor Inlet, fluke catches have been averaging 3 pounds on minnows and cut bait. Weakfishing in the inlet also has been picking up in recent days for fishermen using cut bait.

title: Carey and City Hall Gain Accord On Sale of Rikers Island to State
description: Governor Carey and New York City officials have reached agreement on a fiveyear plan for the state to buy the entire Bikers Island jail complex from the city, which would then use the money to reopen the Manhattan House of Detention for Men  known as the Tombs  ana to upgrade and build other jails.

title: Top Officials and Union Debate Handling of131.aze FatattoOFirefighters
description: As the families and comrades of six dead firemen grieved and muncipal flags in New York City were lowered to halfstaff yesterday, fire officials and the firefighteretmion debated the handling of the Brooklyn supermarket fire on Wednesday that turned into the worst fire tragedy here since 1966.

title: Bread-and-Butter Issues to Mark Lawyers
description: With lawyers coming under increasingly ferocious attack, the American Bar Association has begun its annual meeting in New York City, with the primary focus on issues of bread-and-butter interest to lawyers.

title: State Receives U.S. Funds To Fight Medicaid Fraud

title: Books: Life And Gossip In Ballet
description: "A MERICAN BALLET THEA.TER, the latest in a series of lavishly illustrated ballet books from Alfred A.Knopf, is certainly a schizoid affair. With its blinding gold cover and impressive bulk, it is the quintessential coffeetable book. It is a handsomely produced volume, with a wealth of pictures of Ballet Theater stars and nearstars through the years, and balletomanes will find its detailed record of Ballet Theater productions both absorbing and useful.

title: Ecumenism Is Quietly Pursued At Meeting of Anglican Bishops
description: CANTERBURY, England, Aug. 3 Ecumenism is emerging as the most significant issue among Anglican bishops at the Lambeth Conference, revealing the persistent, though often hidden, power of the drive for church unity.

title: Publishing: Ripples In the Merger Pond
description: THE publishing world this week pondered two developments in the controversial area of mergers and conglomerates: first, the plan to merge Charles Scribner's Sons and Atheneum Publishers; sec- ond, the decision by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, through its publishing arm, to have its trade house, the BobbsMerrill Company, stop bringing out any new fiction by 1980.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, sent letters today to each member of the Senate asking for support of his request for a special appropriation of $8.2 million to begin an influenza immunization program this fall.

title: Heinz Politzer, 66
description: BERKELEY, CALIF., Aug. 3  Heinz Politzer, an authority on Austrian and German literature and professor of German at the University of California here, died Sunday. He was 66 years old.

description: CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 3Attorneys for a weekly newspaper here sought a court order today to halt a petition drive by residents and merchants in the area to curtail commercial and legal advertising in the publication, whose editorial content they find objectionable.
