description: Afternoon

title: A Revival in Rain for Red Sox
description: The Boston Red Sox, who reached town in the throes of their worst slump of the season, left early today with revived spirits and batting averages after two rainy nights in Yankee Stadium  just when their three pursuers in the American League East were closing for the kill. their revival apparently came in the nick of time, because the division is now entering a kind of August free-forall involving the four top teams. In fact, during the next 11 days the Red Sox and Yankees will play 18 games against their chief rivals, the Milwaukee Brewers and Baltimore Orioles.

title: Screen: 'Eyes of Laura Mars':In The Netherworld
description: DEAD men in evening clothes; supine women guarded by sleek, ferocious dogs; upside-down corpses wearing garter-belts, with their hair and makeup in exquisite disarray  these are the tricks of Laura Mars's trade, the hallmarks that have established her as the New York fashion photographer who outkinks them all. However, not everyone is a fan. Someone has gotten the notion that there's evil in Laura's work, he/ she/it has decided to wipe out the photographer plus all her super-hyper-ultra chi-chi friends.So far, very good indeed  especially because the "Eyes of Laura Mars" audience is given ample opportunity to share the killer's pique. Laura (Faye Dunaway), being much too self-involved an artiste to worry about the implications of her work, merely thinks of herself as someone who gives "an account of the times in which I'm living," times rife with "moral, spiritual and emotional murder."Questions about the exploitative aspects of her art merely prompt Laura to snap, "Look, does anyone have anything positive to ask?" The models she works with are even more trendily blase.These models are almost certainly being set up, deliciously, during the early parts of the film. They giggle, chew bubble gum, have pet teddy bears, don't seem to know when they're wearing clothes and when they aren't, and date rich idiots when they aren't making eyes at one another.When Laura's whole crew is hauled into a police station for questioning, one of the girls is irate at being treated like a hooker, even though she's more than dressed for the part. Another merely complains of being bored.A couple of Laura's shooting sessions, staged with a delightful blend of nonchalance and depravity, epitomize the wickedly satirical edge of this lively, high-toned thriller.While two cars are aflame in Columbus Circle, and models in lingerie and fur coats prettily smack each other around, Laura, bless her creative little heart, is all business, solemnly snapping away in a Theoni Aldredge creation. Occasional cuts to spectators in the street make it clear that Laura may well have just arrived from the planet for which she is named, as far as workaday Joe or Joan America is concerned.However, right in the middle of the session Laura has a psychic flash, something that neither she nor the movie needs.Laura can witness killings taking place across town, but only from the unseen killer's point of view  the better to forestall a surprise ending that is altogether dumbfounding (with the emphasis on dumb). These flashes leave her understandably frantic, but Laura has already been established as too much of an amoral flake to arouse much sympathy in her lady-in-distress capacity.But forget the faltering finale, and never mind about a score that, although it includes Barbra Streisand's smashing rendition of the theme song, also makes the killer's forays even more ominously heralded than Bruce the Shark's.It's the cleverness of "Eyes of Laura Mars" that counts, cleverness that manifests itself in superlative casting, drily controlled direction from Irvin Kershner, and spectacular settings that turn New York into the kind of eerie, lavish dreamland that could exist only in the idle noodlings of the very, very hip.Ren Auberjonois brings his full supply of comic prissiness to the role of Miss Mars's principal artistic whatch-amatcallit, and Raul Julia makes her ex-husband a brooding loon, hence a good suspect.The best supporting performance comes from Brad Dourif (who played the young suicide in "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest"), as an ex-con who epitomizes both the movie's taste for voyeurism and its essential seediness. Mr. Dourif, whose bedraggled appearance and half-unhinged manner make it hard to believe he would ever have been hired to carry Miss Mars's lens caps, has been given the job of chauffeur by Mr. Auberjonois, for shady reasons we will never know.Mr. Dourif's awe and fear at what he witnesses during the course of a typical Mars day is the keenest commentary the movie has to offer. His tiniest gestures are noteworthy. Miss Dunaway is perfect for her role, but it's beginning to look like the only role she cares to play.Hysterical jitters, countered by fits of extreme hauteur or assertiveness, have constituted so many of her recent performances that it's hard to remember what else she can do. In any case, high-minded artistic fluttering  the kind Diane Keaton attempts in "Interiors"  comes so naturally to Miss Dunaway that Tommy Lee Jones, as a down-to-earth, soothing cop, is not just a good foil but an indispensable one. Without his stabilizing presence, the movie might well have turned into a "Network" set in the netherworld.A footnote: Miss Dunaway has lately had to play some of the worst-written love scenes on the block, and "Laura Mars" gives her another clinker of this ilk. When she and Mr. Jones embrace at long last, she says "It's terrifying." He says "It's beautiful." She was right the first time.

title: Older Yachts Dominate On Cruise to Nantucket
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 3  The older yachts showed the way on the New York Yacht Club cruise today. Seventysix vessels in six classes raced from Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, to Nantucket over a 20mile course in a sparkling southwest breeze that blew away rain clouds and haze.

title: Koch Gets 8 Letters but No Money In His Appeal to the Tax Exempted
description: Two weeks ago, Mayor Koch appealed to the 1,800 owners of taxexempt property to make voluntary contributions to the city in lieu of taxes. So far, the city has not received a nickel, although it has got eight letters of response.

title: SYRIA BACKS BEIRUT ON TROOPS IN SOUTH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 3  Syria announced today that it would support Lebanon against Israel's obstruction of Lebanese Army deployment in the south of the country.

title: Art Critic Chooses Museum Favorites
description: IN every great permanent collection of art there is something that speaks to each of us imperiously and will not yield to the competition. Here is one critic's choice of just, a few such works from six public collections in New York. City. To make a choice of this kind we have to follow our own private instinct, even if that runs contrary to the fundamental rhythm that every great institution sets up for itself. Every such institution has such a rhythm. Most often that rhythm is beaten into us by the Grand Staircase.

title: South Africa Bans a U.S. Novel
description: CAPE TOWN, Aug. 3 (Reuters)  The Harold Robbins novel Dreams Die First has been banned in South Africa, the Government's Directorate of Publications announced here today. It joins the bestselling author's The Carpetbaggers and The Betsy on the list of banned books here.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Pitt to Leave S.E.C. Post

title: Ban on Indirect Aid to 4 Countries Is Defeated in a Close House Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The House narrowly rejected today an effort to ban the indirect use of foreign aid funds for Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam and Uganda after opponents had charged that such a restriction would require the United States to withdraw from international aid banks and other institutions.

title: Del Monte Takeover Bid Is Made by R.J. Reynolds
Bill to End NaturalGas Price Curbs, Key Part of Energy Plan, in New Peril
Mother Killed With 6 Children In Utah Plunge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 3 (AP) With her husband dead of suicide, a woman and her seven children plunged 11 floors from the balcony of a downtown hotel today in an apparent act of religious zealotry, the police said. The mother and six of the children died.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: McShann Quartet, a Hybrid of the Blues
description: Jay McShann has rolled into town from Kansas City, Mo., and settled into Michael's Pub, where, for the next two and a half weeks, he will be singing and playing the blues that have been associated with him for more than 35 years, and with Kansas City for even longer.

title: Notes on People
description: In his first appearance before a Congressional subcommittee since he retired from the Senate in 1975, Sam J. Ervin Jr. said yesterday that Congress has no powir to amend the past by extending the sevenyear limit established .for state legislatures to ratify the equal rights amendment. Mr. Ervin, who opposed the amendment in 1971 when he was in the Senate, testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on the Constitution in the Old Senate Caucus Room, where he presided over the televised Watergate hearings five years ago. The power to fix a reasonable time for state action on a proposed constitutional amendment must reside in the Congress :that submits it, said Mr. Ervin. It cannot be determined retroactively by a subsequent Congress. The 95th Congress has power to legislate for the future. It has no power to amend the past.

title: Trouble to the North
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 3  The Protestant School Board of Greater Montreal announced this week that its English-language schools had been forced to stop admitting youngsters who do not have at least one parent educated in English. Under Quebec provincial law, such pupils are required to attend Frenchlanguage schools, whether or not they want an English education.

title: Pesticides Found in Wells
description: MONTAGUE, Mich., Aug. 3 (UPI)The pesticide component C56 and seven byproducts  all produced by the Hooker Chemical Corporation  have been detected in White Lake and groundwater supplies near the plant, state officials said today.

title: Shoemaker Banned on Coast
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP)  Bill Shoemakei, Who has ridden more winners than any other jockey in the history of thoroughbred racing, was suspended yesterday by the Del Mar stewards for careless riding. Shoemaker will be sidelined for five racing days starting Saturday as the result of his disqualification aboard firstfinishing Run Proud in Monday's seventh race.

title: ASSEMBLYMAN CITES ABUSES IN WELFARE
description: A Brooklyn Assemblyman exhibited a City Human Resources Administration computer printout sampling yesterday that indicated, he said, that 61,000 individuals received welfare payments for several years even though their Social Security numbers were not listed.

title: Juvenile Center in Bronx Inspires Conflicting Views
description: I think that the physical characteristics of the Spofford Juvenile Center exhibit our schizophrenia about what Spofford is, Beverly Sanders, Assistant Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration for Special Services for Urban Affairs Children, said in a recent interview. When you go through the place, you'll see big, heavy, locked doors that you open with huge keys, and then you'll see nice win- dows with small screens that you could just push right out before they were reinforced.

title: Old Bethpage Schedules A Social, Drills and Song
description: Visitors to the Old Bethpage Village restoration, a recreated farm community of the mid1800's on, Round Swamp Road (south of Exit 48 on the Long Island Expre'ssway),", this weekend can sample a bit of Long Island living from the days of yore. A ladies so- ciabie will be held tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M., complete with homemade ice cream, crafts and parlor music.

title: SOVIET COURT FINES TWO U.S. REPORTERS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3  The Moscow City Court today fined two American reporters the equivalent of $72.50 each for failing to publish retractions of articles they had written about a convicted dissident.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE LEBANON TO AVENGE BOMBING IN TEL AVIV
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3  A terrorist bomb here killed one Israeli and wounded 50 in the crowded Cannel Market today. Five hours later, Israeli jets streaked over the Lebanese border to strike at a target described as a Palestinian terrorist training camp.

title: No Yesterdays, No Tomorrows, It's Only Today at Spofford
description: The muchcriticized Spofford Juvenile Detention Center in the Bronx is the sort of place where signs and decorations tacked to cracked and dirty walls tell far more about its frustrated staff and young inhabitants than either group is likely to speak about directly.

title: Gunmen Shooting from Car Kill A Policeman in Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland (AP) Gunmen in a passing car shot and killed a 30-year-old police reservist last night at Ballymena, 25 miles northwest of Belfast, the police reported.

title: Ousted Friend of O'Neill Is Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  In an effort to repair its frayed relations with House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the White House announced the appointment today of his close friend and protg, Robert T. Griffin, to a newly created, $50,000-a-year Federal job.

title: Troop Transfers Let Cambodians Flee to Thailand
description: TA PHRAYA, Thailand, Aug. 2  A sudden spurt in arrivals of refugees from northwestern Cambodia, the largest outflow of Cambodians since the end of the civil war in 1975, appears to be largely the result of a thinning out of military forces in that region.

description: Corporate demand for shortterm credit be subsiding figures released he Fede erve yesterdav strongly indicated.

title: U.S. Senate Candidate in Virginia Dies in Plane Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Richard D. Obenshain, the Republican candidate for United States Senator in the current Virginia campaign, died late last night when his small plane crashed and burned while approaching an airport southwest of Richmond. The pilot and another occupant of the plane alsolvere killed.

title: Visitors at Theater Lab
description: Jan Van Dyke and Dancers, a moderndance troupe from Washington, will perform this weekend at the American Theater Laboratory, , 219 West 19th Street, as part of a monthlong series of performances by out-oftown companies. Shows are at 8 P.M to- night and tomorrow. Tickets are $3.50 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). Future performers will include the Albuquerque Dance Theater. Information and reservations: 9240077.

title: Ali, at 36, Still Talks the Good F.iht
description: DEER LAKE, Pa., Aug. 2 Muhammad Ali pointed his $60,000 Stutz Tomahawk up the hill this morning to what he says is his last training camp.

title: Beethoven at Lyndhurst

title: Judge Finds Job Bias at U.S. Steel
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) Federal District judge ruled today that the United States Steel Corporation had discriminated against black workers seeking management or craft positions at its suburban Fairless Works. He rejected, however, claims that blacks were routinely assigned hot dirty lobs.

title: Opera: Grand Duke Revised
description: GILBERT and Sullivan collabo rated on The Grand Duke in 1896. It was the last operetta they were to write, and it was a failure. It disappeared for good, from the repertory of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company and from the reportories of various offshoots in England and America. Thus it is of more than unusual interest that tne Light Opera of Manhattan has revived this virtually unknown work. Those who love the G.&S. operettas  and who doesn't?will want to make up their own minds about the merits of the work, and Light Opera of Manhattan is now giving them a chance.

title: UPSTATE WASTE SITE:

description: BANDERA, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP)  The rivers of central Texas raged over their banks today and, with at least nine persons already dead, the flooding in the hill country threatened several lowlying cities and inundated the grave site of Lyndon B. Johnson.

He thinks they talk to each other, and he thinks he understands a lot of what they are saving.

title: Topics
description: Street crime has fallen to a new low, to judge by the report from Newark. Two men there are charged with stealing a street, by pulling up its 12pound Belgian paving blocks, one at a time. The thievery went on for a period of weeks; the men are accused of removing some 50,000 blocks, and selling them for $21,000. Wiseacres may be tempted to wonder about what the road to hell is now paved with, or how to curb criminal instincts, or whether the defendants cornered the pavingblock market. Such impulses might be directed toward devising a punishment that fits the crime. What strikes us about the case is the culprits audacity in thinking that motorists hereabouts are so inured to bad roads that they wouldn't even notice the absence of paving. The just sentence seems obvious to us: put em to work filling potholes.

title: Screen: Disney For the Older Set:Dickensian Disney
description: IF this were a world of perfect logic, the arrival today in neighborhood theaters of "Candleshoe," the latest Walt Disney production, would be an occasion of calculable joy not among children but among the elderly.For "Candleshoe," with its beguiling English countryside settings, languid pace, defanged Dickensian villains, compassionate butler, down-at-the-heels nobility, hidden treasure and orphaned children engaged in a plot to outwit swindlers, keep up appearances and save the old manor from foreclosure, is the fiction of a bygone era.The chords it sounds, with its evocation of a world of stately homes, formal gardens, family heirlooms, titled women, eccentric ancestors, perfect servants, tea parties, steam engines and classic motorcars can resonate within an older generation in a way they never can among children whose cultural touchstones are more likely to run the gamut from Big Bird to The Hulk to John Travolta and the Bee Gees.The values "Candleshoe"  espouses  kindness, consideration, good manners, sacrifice for the sake of others, pluck in the face of odds  were, too, the overt moral currency of a society that long antedates Watergate, Koreagate and the Me Generation.So entering the world of "Candleshoe," which is based on the Michael Innes novel, "Christmas at Candleshoe," is like taking a trip in a time machine. Within the terms of its plot, Jodie Foster, a delinquent foster child up to no good in the streets of Los Angeles, is whisked off to a Tudor mansion in Warwickshire, a journey that seems more a vault across generations than across distance.There, ostensibly in league with a blustering villain inspired by Dickens and played by Leo McKern, she is to try to pass herself off as the long-missing marchioness, heir to the estate; and she is to endeavor to find a hidden treasure, whose existence is known only to McKern and Vivian Pickles, who portrays his sister, a servant discharged from Candleshoe.And who should be the kindly current mistress of Candleshoe? Why none other than Helen Hayes, who has taken in a few orphans from the overcrowded local children's home. And who should be the perfect butler, the feisty Scottish gardener, the tippling chauffeur and the old colonel who takes tea with old Lady Gwendolyn? Not four people, but one  David Niven, doffing and donning wigs and mustaches and eyebrows and various articles of clothing in league with the orphans to keep Lady Gwendolyn from knowing that time and the taxman have reduced her circumstances to a point of peril.The cast is beyond reproach. In this summer when Hollywood seems to have concluded that box-office magic lies in setting its best young actresses down in England, Miss Foster as Casey Brown easily keeps pace with Tatum O'Neal as Sarah Brown (could they be related?) in "International Velvet." Miss Hayes, Mr. Niven, Mr. McKern and Miss Pickles comport themselves with their customary professionalism.There's a new Walt Disney movie in town. Kids, take grandma.

title: Spain to Stop Topless Bathing

title: The Bar's Finest Hours
description: In a century of existence, the American Bar Association  sometimes called the organized bar has had proud moments, as when it worked to rescue legal services for the poor from a Nixon Administration bent on destroying them. It has had moments when it ought to have been spanked, as when it took stands against nofault insurance. And there have been times of utter confusion, as in its sluggish, negative response to price competition and advertising. Whether or not the A.B.A. represents the profession  half the nation's 460,000 lawyers are now members  it certainly reflects the best and the worst that lawyers represent.

description: OTTAWA, Aug. 4  The Ford Motor, Company's decision to build a $533 million automotive engineering plant in Ontario instead of in Lima, Ohio, was welcomed by Canadians today, although some, including union leaders, expressed strong reservations about using taxpayers money  $68 million in Canadian funds  to subsidize a company like Ford.

title: Woman's Slayer Gets 25 Years
description: Bartolomeo Peppe, 45 years old, who shot the woman he was living with to death on March 3d in front of her daughters, 8 and 9 years old, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison by Justice Hyman Barshay in State Supreme Court in Queens. The victim was Eva Avicolli, who was slain in her apartment at 4219 18th Avenue, Borough Park, while Mr. Peppe's two sons, aged 11 and 13, held back the victim's two girls.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, AUG, 4, 1978

title: Met Golfers Are Beaten By the Rain
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 4Bob Housen, the New Jersey State amateur champion from Woodlake, Jerry Courvilie of Shorehaven and Bill Britton of Silver Lake were among the firstround victors today as the Metropolitan Golf Association's 76th championship continued.

title: Former Forensic Chemist Testifies That Curare Syringe Bore Dog Hair
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 4  A former chemist in the office of the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he had found dog hairs on some of the syringes and other items taken from the surgeon's locker at Riverdell Hospital.

title: Harvard and C.I.A. Deadlocked Over Secret Work by the Faculty
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 3  Harvard University and the Central Intelligence Agency, despite a year of negotiations, are at an impasse over the university's attempt to ban secret operations and recruiting by faculty members.

title: FRANCIS MILLER DIES; VIRGINIA POLITICIAN
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 4  Francis Pickens Miller, who campaigned against the Byrd political organization in Virginia more than two decades ago, died here yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: KEY BRITON ACCUSED OF A MURDER PLOT
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  Jeremy Thorpe, the former leader of the Liberal Party, was arrested today and charged with having conspired to murder Norman Scott, a former male model who said he had had a homosexual relationship with him.

title: Concern Increases in Bronx Over Rowdyism at Stadium
description: As the visiting Red Sox were poised to win their second game of the night at Yankee Stadium Thursday night, it began to rain heavily, and the game was suspended temporarily. Moments later, frustrated Yankee fans, already angry over their team's loss of the first game, spilled onto the field, and soon scuffles broke out between the fans and stadium security personnel.

title: Indian Town Lives. Well on Cash Sent Home by Its Men in Mideast
description: CHOWGHAT, India  This town near the southern tip of India is enjoying a sudden economic boom  not because of anything happening here, but because of the new prosperity in the Persian Gulf, 2,000 miles to the northwest.

title: Times Reporter Jailed as Marshall Refuses to Extend Stay of Penalties
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 4  A New York Times reporter went to jail here today and The New York Times Company began paying a $5,000-a-day fine after Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court refused to stay those penalties any longer.

title: Men Write to Challenge Single Women's Criticism
description: On July 14, this page published an article by Nan Robertson entitled Single Women Over 30: Where Are the Men Worthy of Us?  In it, a variety of women stated that their growing sense of selfrespect had left them painfully aware of how few desirable men were available to them. Most of the men they met, the women said, were bores, emotionally retarded little boys, cads or men who fancied younger women. This viewpoint elicited numerous letters, prepon; derantly from men. Excerpts from some of the letters follow:

description: Following is the text of Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall's opinion in which he refused to stay civilcontempt penalties against M. A. Farber and The New York Times Company:

title: Doctor Says She Alerted Chief on Test Tube Baby
description: A doctor testified yesterday that she had complained about a 1973 attempt to fertilize a human ovum outside a woman's body because a laboratory culture produced in the experiment was a horrible mess.

title: California Expects Bumper Rice Crop
description: FIREBAUGH, Calif.  Here in the San Joaquin Valley and northward to the Sacramento Valley, it is 100 degrees and dusty  not at all the lush tropical climate generally associated with ricegrowing. Yet this is the nation's most productive rice region, its irrigated paddies producing a significant portion of the rice available for the world market.

title: World Gold

title: A Motion Might Cut Off NBC Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4  Procedural arguments today before the judge in the socalled Born Innocent case raised the possibility that the trial might be abruptly terminated on Monday after the newly sworn jurors hear the plaintiff's opening statement.

title: Stocks Post Slight Gain; Volume Off
description: The stock market finished slightly higher in much slower trading yesterday, following a day that saw the heaviest turnover in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: MAY S. MILLER
description: May S. Miller, widow of Meurice Miller, who was president of I. Miller & Sons, shoe manufacturers and retailers, from 1951 until the late 1950's, died yesterday at her home at 785 Fifth Avenue. She was 76 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  The Environmental Protection Agency removed major obstacle to completion of the nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N.H., today by rejecting arguments from environmentalists and approving the plant's openocean cooling system.

description: The old rahrah is out. But a strong voice and a nimble body are still basic requirements for a high school cheerleader.

title: Flood Engulfs Texas Town
description: ALBANY, Tex., Aug. 4 (UPI) A flash flood today sent a 20foot wall of water over this ranching community of 2,000 people, killing six persons and forcing survivors to seek safety on roofs, trees and floating pickup trucks.

title: Carter Declares Disaster
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)  The White House formally announced today that President Carter had declared major disaster in Texas because of the flooding. He signed the declaration last night, but the formal announcement was delayed until today.

description: EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 4 (AP)  Four soldiers aboard an Army Huey helicopter were killed early today when it crashed and burned on McGregor Range on a training mission. The victims were Capt.

description: Pondering the prospect of facing Ron Guidry in just a few minutes, Earl Weaver sat in the BaltiMore dugout before last night's game with the Yankees and remarked: Our best bet is hope for four innings and then rain. They wouldn't be able to bring him back.

title: Namibia Accord. It May Prove to Be Model
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 Peace seems elusive in SouthWest Africa more than a week after the Security Council endorsed an independence plan that is supposed to stop guerrilla warfare, end control by a white South African

title: Associated Press
description: TRENTON, Aug. 4  Governor Byrne asked Congress today to join with New Jersey in buying $40 million worth of the New Jersey Pine Barrens to protect it from unsupervised development.

title: Renewed Research on Human Fertilization in Labs Ured
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  Congress heard pleas today for a renewal of American research on laboratory fertilization of human embryos, suspended for the last three years, but was warned that legal and ethical implications of such procedures must be dealt with legislatively.

title: Bulova Plans to Shift Queens Watch Work To Switzerland Plant
description: The Bulova Watch Company, the nation's oldest watch producer, is discontinuing the manufacture of watch movements in the United States after 55 years and is shifting those operations from Queens to its plant in Switzerland.

description: Weeden & Company, once the nation's leading thirdmarket securities firm but recently buffeted by a series of multimilliondollar losses, announced yesterday that it intended to combine with Jefferies & Company, a small institutionlly oriented brokerage concern based in Los Angeles. No details of the deal were given.

title: Meadowlands Development Study
description: SECAUCUS, Aug. 4  The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission said today that improved highways would not be adequate to meet the expected population and industrial growth of North Jersey's 19,730acre Meadowlands area and that radically new transit systems mieht be needed.

title: Deaths
description: PLUMMERNorman, age 77. On August 4, 1978. In Newtown, Conn. Formerly of 2 Bronxville Road, Bronxvine, N.Y. Services Henan Funeral Home, 58 Main St, Newtown, Conn, Monday 11AM. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings, N.Y. Calling hours Sunday 3 to 5PM.

title: Candidate Hurt in Plane Crash
description: ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 4 (UPI)  Sam Hardage, a businessman and unsuccessful candidate for the United States Senate seat in Kansas three days ago, was seriously injured when his private plane crashed on landing at the Aspen airport late yesterday. The authorities said that Mr. Hardage, 39 years old, who finished third in Tuesday's nineway Republican Senate primary, was airlifted to a hospital in Denver, 150 miles east of Aspen, with a possible skull fracture, facial lacerations and internal injuries.

title: Mets, Behind Swan, Defeat Cardinals, 83
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4.  The St. Louis Cardinals have fallen on hard times, and none has fallen harder than Bob Forsch. Tonight Forsch failed for the eighth time to record his 10th victory as the New York Mets routed the Cards, 83.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Hoffmann Will Stress. Fructose Marketing
description: With Governmentmandated health warnings prominently displayed on saccharin products and health-conscious and calorieconscious consumers curtailing their use of sugar, HoffmannLa Roche Inc. sees a strong marketing potential for crystalline fructose, a natural product twice as sweet as conventional sugar.

title: Blue, Giants Top Dodgers, 21
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (AP) Lefthander Vida Blue posted his 10th straight victory, and Bill Madlock's fifthinning homer snapped a 11 tie that lifted the San Francisco Giants to a 21 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

title: Is Former Nun Tough Enough for a Tough Job?
description: WASHINGTON  Helen Kelley is better prepared than most to do battle with a big bureaucracy.

title: A Winner for the Horseplayers
description: Racetrack regulars have their version of the old joke about the brain transplant. The tout who sells victims on the idea of getting one displays a wide variety of choices: a $50,000 brain left by a successful businessman; a $100,000 specimen formerly owned by a distinguished lawyer; an even larger brain, costing $250,000, from an internationally famous scholar. Finally, the tout points to a freezer containing a tiny brain with a price tag of $500,000.

title: First Families Leaving Upstate Contamination Site
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 4  Toting their cribs and suitcases past scrawled signs reading Wanted: safe home for two toddlers and Today is the day they give babies away with half-apound of tea, families began today to move away from the contaminated Love Canal.

title: Kennedy Defeats Boggs In A.A.U. 3Meter Diving
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 4 (AP)  Jim Kennedy of Knoxville, Term., won his second national diving title of the year, coming from third place in the final three dives last night to edge Phil Boggs and Greg Louganis in the 3meter springboard competition of the Amateur Athletic Union outdoor diving championships.

title: Dutchman Of Today Is Offered
description: BAYREUTH, WEST GERMANY, Aug. 4 Wagner's The Flying Dutchman, a new Bayreuth Festival production that was seen for the second time Thursday night, is an opera swept by irresistibly stormy outbursts and anchored in such stark psychological complexities that it helped start a revolution in music theater.

title: Soviet Space Capsule Burns Up
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 4 (UPI)  An unmanned space capsule that resupplied two orbiting Soviet astronauts and picked up their space garbage has completed its mission and burned up over the Pacific, the Soviet press agency, Tass, said today.

description: N. W. Ayer ABH International, the world's oldest advertising agency, continued to act like a spring chicken yesterday as it landed the hotly contested worldwide advertising account of Pan American World Airways. description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)  The Department of Energy charged two major oil companies today with probable pricing violations totaling $132 million.

title: JOBLESS RATE JUMPS TO 6.2% FOR MONTH AFTER DROP IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  The national unemployment rate, which tumbled in June to 5.7 percent, rebounded in July to 6.2 percent, the level that prevailed in the late winter and spring, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Officers Doubt 2d Alarm in Fatal Fire Was Delayed
description: The head of the fire officers association said yesterday that he did not believe there had been any delay in sounding a second alarm to save overtime payments in the Brooklyn supermarket fire that killed six firemen on Wednesday.

description: The reason government in Washington is near a standstill is that President Carter and the Congress are living in two different countries.

description: Neil John Welch, the agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Philadelphia operations, was named yesterday as head of the New York office, the bureau's busiest office in the country.

title: NEW YORK BEACHES CLOSED IN OIL SPILL
description: Five New York City city beaches will remain closed to bathers because of oil globules in their waters, though their sands have been somewhat cleansed, and there is a scant possibility they may be opened tomorrow.

title: ABC Producers React to Youth Terror Complaint
description: Pamela Hill, executive producer of a documentary that is the object of a complaint to the Federal Communications Commission, yesterday countercharged that a former production associate on the program had initiated the complaint because his ABCTV contract had not been renewed.

title: British Study Commission Urges Bermuda Vote on Independence
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  A British commission has blamed Bermuda's irregular economic structure for the riots there last December and recommended independence for Britain's oldest colony.

title: Meat Official, Under Fire, Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  Robert Angelotti, the head of the Agriculture Department's Food Safety and Quality Service, resigned today in the midst of a dispute over his expense statements on meals provided by a meatpacking concern.

description: OAKMONT, Pa., Aug. 4  The round was a scrambling one, but with what he called a golden putter, Tom Watson saved it to shoot a two-under-par 69 and reinforce his lead today in the second round of the 60th Professional Golfers Association championship.

description: The State Department of Energy has adopted energy conservation regulations aimed at reducing the consumption of oil and electricity in the state by 5 to 6 percent by 1980.

title: Crime in the City Is a Seasonal Matter: Summer Is Its Peak
description: Summer in the city is not always a carefree time of lazy days for New Yorkers who remain here, least of all for the police to whom the season always seems bring more trouble. The notion that crime increases the summer is not a myth, they say, but a reality that results from increased human contact that provides greater opportunity for violent encounters.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 4 (UPI) The Aetna Life Insurance Company, subsidiary of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, has entered into a $60 million mortgage agreement with Caesars Palace Hotel, the first major longterm financing commitment by an insurance company to the Nevada gambling industry. The hotel is a subsidiary of Caesars World Inc.

title: Church in Nicaragua Urges Somoza to Quit To Quell Civil Unrest
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 4 (UPI)  The Roman Catholic Church called today for the resignation of President Anastasio Somoza and the establishment of a new socioeconomic order to end the long wave of violence in the country.

title: Vilas Advances in Jersey Tennis
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4  It has been a productive summer for Guillermo Vilas. He has finished a second book of poetry, has started a novel, written the lyrics for two songs, starred in a movie and is negotiating for a publisher for his autobiography.

title: Jan Van Dyke and Her Dancers Present 3 Works at Theater Lab
description: Jan Van Dyke and Dancersoffered three works by Miss Van Dyke at the American Theater Laboratory on Thursday evening that were so introspective that they suggested that this company from Washington enjoys being lost in thought.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Grumman Corporation, the nation's largest producer of carrierbased aircraft, yesterday reported that its second quarterprofits declined 23.6 percent from the same period in 1977. Grumman's sales increased 7.5 percent for the quarter over the same period.

title: Dempsey In Top Post Of Fidelity
description: The Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, still reeling from a $4.9 million secondquarter operating deficit, announced yesterday that it had named an outsider, Raymond J. Dempsey, as president and chief executive officer.

title: 2 Suspects in Killing of Paris P.L.O. Officials Said to Admit Belonging to Group Tied to Iraq
description: PARIS, Aug. 4  Two Arab terrorists who murdered two Palestine Liberation Organization representatives here yesterday have admitted being members of a radical Palestinian group linked to Iraq's intelligence service, French police sources said today.

title: Cuban Agent Says U.S. Police Aides Urged Torture
description: HAVANA, Aug. 4  A Cuban, who said that he had infiltrated the Central Intelligence Agency as a double agent and was sent to work in Uruguay, charged today that United States police advisers routinely recommended the use of torture for interrogation purposes there in the early 1970's.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  The Carter Administration, aided by a small group of liberal Democrats in the House of, Representatives, mounted a drive today to reshape the key parts of the taxcut bill approved last week by the Ways and Means committee.

description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 (AP)  Sal Bando and Gorman Thomas belted tworun homers and Larry Hisle and Cecil Cooper added solo shots, powering the Milwaukee Brewers to a 62 victory tonight over the Boston Red Sox.

title: 4 Present Bids to Build New York Bus Shelters
description: Morris Tarshis, the city's Franchise Director, had under consideration yesterday proposals from four companies to construct bus shelters throughout the city.

title: Notes on People
description: The admiring stare of Britain's 18yearold Prince Andrew proved to be so disconcerting for Gianetta Baril, a 17yearold harpist, that She broke a sixth octave string on one of the last notes of Handel's Passacaglia at a banquet for Queen Elizabeth II in Edmonton, Alberta. The flustered Miss Baril's embarrassment led the Queen to give her son a public reproving frown and, apparently, a private motherly scolding. Andrew, who had been sitting at a table near Miss Baril during the perfortnance, consoled her afterward about breaking the string. Mum's blaming it on me, he said.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOREVER CHRISTIE It's al. ways good to have a suspense play from the late Agatha Christie on the summer scene; and now Towards Zero has checked in for weekend performances Off Off Broadway through Aug. 20. The place is the groundfloor showcase (70 seats) of the five-year-old Academy Arts Theater Company in the Sutton East Hotel, 330 East 56thStreet, between First and Second Avenues.

description: THE WOODLANDS, Tex., Aug .4 (AP)  Cynthia Woodhead lowered her American record in the women's 200meter freestyle and Tracy Caulkins, the slowest qualifier, set an American record in the 100meter breaststroke last night at the Amateur Athletic Union's long course swimming championships.

title: Walton Asks for Trade And Blazers Agree to It
description: Bill Walton, who has weathered controversy and injury to become the most dominant center in the National Basketball Association, has had enough of the Portland Trail Blazers. The league's most valuable player last season has asked to be traded, and in a surprise response yesterday the Trail Blazers agreed to let him go.

International Ltd., its Cayman Islands subsidiary, of having failed to disclose illegal payments to union officials in New Jersey, electioncampaign payments in Hawaii and a questionable $6 million payment to a Middle Eastern sales consultant.

title: Miss O'Connor Takes Jersey Golf Championship
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4 Cindy O'Connor of Spring Brook, a 19yearold college student, birdied five of this afternoon's 14 holes to defeat Elizabeth Wood of Bamm Hollow, 5 and 4, in the 36hole championship of the 53d New Jersey State women's golf tournament at Essex County Country Club.

title: The High Stakes in Alaska's Land Dispute
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska  Frontiers attract gogetters. Alaska is the nation's last frontier. And so it's not really surprising that the predominant mood among the state's 900,000 citizens is what might be politely called entrepreneurial.

title: Edmund F. Jewell, 82, Publisher of Newspaper
description: MEREDITH, N.H., Aug. 4 (UPI) Edmund F. Jewell, a former publisher of The Manchester Union Leader and an executive with the Hearst newspapers, died yesterday at the Lakes Region General Hospital in Laconia. He was 82 years old.

title: Bail of $250,000 Is Set For Spy a Second Time
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)  Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court today ordered bail set at $250,000 for David Truong, a convicted spy, saying that there were not enough grounds to conclude That Mr. Truong planned to flee the country.

title: News Summary
description: A leading British politician was arrested and charged, with three other men, of conspiring to murder a former male model who claimed to have had homosexual relationship with him. The man arrested, Jeremy Thorpe, was formerly leader of Britian's Liberal Party. The claim by Norman Scott, the former model, led to Mr. Thorpe's resignation as the party leader in 1976. Mr. Thorpe, 49 years old, remains Member of Parliament and of the Privy Council. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: Norwegians, Ardent Neutralists, Also
description: BODO, Norway  Thirtyeight years ago Norwegian military men warned the country's leaders that there was an unusual amount of German naval activity off their coasts. The politicians did nothing. On April 9, 1940, the Germans pounced on Norway and quickly subdued it.

title: Two Die in Iowa Gas Explosion
description: FORT MADISON, Iowa, Aug. 4 (AP) A propane gas line running through a parched cornfield in southeastern Iowa exploded today, killing two elderly persons, injuring six and destroying a twostory farmhouse, the authorities said. Lee County Sheriff Don Arnold identified the dead as R. C. Knight, 79 years old, and his wife, Claricy, 82.

description: MORRISTOWN, Aug. 4  If there are rats in the belfry, their life styles may be threatened by some new neighbors who moved in last night. In fact, the rats in this Morris County community may be in serious trouble wherever they are.

title: Spanish Enclave in Africa Fears for Future
description: CEUTA Hunched over, their backs piled with plastic shoes, detergents, radios and other dutyfree goods bought here, Moroccan women position themselves to bribe the Moroccan customs officials, who kick at them angrily if the sums proffered are insuf-

title: Carter Signs Farm Bill For $4 Billion in Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) President Carter today signed a $4 billion farm loan bill that he said would allow some debtridden farmers to stay in business.

title: President to Visit Tobacco Country To Attempt to Bolster Candidates
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 4  Tobacco more than a crop in North Carolina; it is almost a sniritual belief.

title: U.S. Golfers Leading Britain in Curtis Cup
description: RYE, N.Y., Aug. 4  The women's amateur golf team from Britain and Ireland, believing it can win the Curtis Cup for the first time in 22 years, backed up this selfconfidence this morning with the best start by a British team since 1938 in the biennial series against the United States.

title: BRITISH POLITICIAN TIED TO DEATH PLOT
description: LONDON, Aug. 4  Jeremy Thorpe, the former leader of the Liberal Party, was arrested today and charged with having conspired to murder Norman Scott, a former male model who said he had had a homosexual relationship with him.

title: Mrs. Hawes Again Wins WestchesterFairfield Title
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 4 Regine Hawes of Westchester Country Club repeated as champion of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today by defeating Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot, 1 up, at Pelham Country Club in the 53d title tournament.

title: Rehabilitation Is Good Business
description: ST. PAUL, Minn.  Two years ago, Robert Schroeder, a shipping clerk at the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company here, strained his liack on a warehouse loading dock. Doctors said the injury would prevent him from returning to the job he'd held for 19 years, but the company's rehabilitation counselor enrolled him at a business college. Today Mr. Schroeder is a raw materials analyst at 3M, earning more thari he did as a warehouseman.

title: Desire Under the Elms To Be Done as an Opera
description: WATERFORD, Conn.  The latest program to originate with the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center here  its first composers and librettists conference  will begin with an American folk opera, a musical version of O'Neill's Desire Under the Elms by Edward Thomas.

title: CHESS
description: BAGUIO, THE PHILIPPINE How would Anatoly Karpov, the world champion, or Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger, stack up against Bobby Fischer? It has been almost six years since Fischer won the world championship from Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union in Rejkjavik, Iceland, and all this time he has secluded himself in his Pasadena apartment. In 1975, Fischer lost his title by default to Karpov when he refused to play under the match rules set by the World Chess Federation.

title: A Festival Takes Arms Against a Sea of Success
description: ASHLAND, Ore.  Jerry Turner, the producing director of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, is worried. But what could worry a man who oversees one of the most successful theater festivals in the country, this year producing 10 plays for almost a quartermillion people, 300 miles from the nearest urban center, with standingroomonly audiences?

title: ON THE ISLE
description: The good sloop Clearwater, which has been spreading its environmentalaction message for a decade now, pulls into the Huntington town dock (New York Avenue, Halesite) today at 2 P.M. to start a 10day journey through North Shore waters. A duplicate of a 19thcentury Hudson River sloop, the 106footlong ship will spend two days at each of four ports of call, inviting Long Islanders aboard for traditional folk music concerts, threehourlong sails and inspection tours.

title: ART
description: PURCHASE MOST of us shy away from student art shows, and with good reason. They're usually comprised of dribbles and drabbles and knicknacks that should be left in the privacy of the school studio and not brought out into the public arena. Even the best student artists often think that expression and inspiration are achieved through copyings of their teachers works.

title: Miss Kattermann Sets Sept. 30 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Kattermann of New York and Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Blanche Nancy Kattermann, to Robert Douglas George, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. George of Kenwood, N.Y. A Sept. 30 wedding is planned.

title: New Haven Youth Take Helm As Yachting Comes to the City
description: Yachting. It bears the connotation of wealth and conjures up the picture of men dressed in blue blazers and white ducks elegantly maneuvering gleaming yachts, with the help of a professional crew. Yachting today bears little resemblance to this. And as a sport, it has evolved to the point where the costs of small boats and access to the water are within the reach of many.

title: Tokyo Says China Spies Got Military DoCuments
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5 (UPI) A ChMese spy ring in Tokyo obtained thousands of secret documents from Japan's Defense Facilities Agency during the last 10 years. the nonce said today.

title: Research on Rocks From the Moon Is Threatened
description: A last remnant of the Apollo project, research on the samples of lunar soil and rocks returned by the astronauts, is being threatened as Congress considers cuts in next year's budget for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Tuesday, weather permitting, the 16 acres of Central Park's Sheep Meadow will be covered with blankets, chairs and close to 150,000 people. The occasion will be the New York Philharmonic Orchestra's first concert in the parks this summer. Andre Kostelanetz is slated to conduct the allTchaikovsky program, which concludes with the 1812 Overture and accompanying fireworks display. Friday night the same program can be heard at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, and again on Saturday in Queens at Cunningham Park. There are three other programs including Wagner, Berlioz and Mahler that New Yorkers can enjoy out of doors, with the final concert to be conducted by Zubin Mehta on August 29. (See Music)

title: L.I. Band Swings Without Gimmickry
description: When this guy at one of the big clubs out here showed us where our makeup man would work, we just broke out laughing, said Dave Patrick, guitarist for Solar, one of the most talkedabout young bands now working the East End of Long Island. As Mr. Patrick tells it. barely containing Its glee ana amazement, the club spokesman didn't think it was funny. You know what he said?

title: Smog: War Between the States
description: BY one measure, Connecticut has the worst air pollution in the country outside of Los Angeles and it's not really Connecticut's fault, according to a lawsuit that will he filed next week New Vnrk and New Jersey, so the argument goes, have created Connecticut's terrible pollution problem because they spew out hundreds of thousands of tons of pollutants that float over the border and land here.

title: Fine Disks From LesserKnown Pianists
description: It's a healthy sign in the classical record business today that few musicians of quality are prevented from making disks simply because their names lack the magical sound of a Horowitz.

title: GARDENING
description: WEDNESDAY will be Plant Science Day at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in Hamden. The annual open house is popular with local gardeners and farmers.

title: MUSIC
description: AFINANCIAL sword of Damocles is hanging over the Silvermine Guild of Artists chamber music series, and nobody is prepared to promise that there will be a 20th anniversary season next summer Already the traditional fourconcert series has had to be cut to three, but the performance quality has stayed very high, and the folks up in New Canaan are hopeful that new patrons will come to the rescue.

title: Hua Kuofeng of China Visits Europe this Month
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  The stewpot of Balkan politics is boiling again. In the pot is a volatile mixture of nationalism, ethnic animosity and ideological rivalry, heated up by the strategic ambitions of outside Dowers.

title: Miss Chandler, Louganis Capture Divine Events
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Aug. 5 (AP)  Jennifer Chandler and Greg Louganis, both competing for the host team, the Mission Viejo Nadadores, had wide victory margins in last night's springboard events at the Amateur Athletic Union national outdoor diving chamnionshins.

title: Kit Is Released for Sale to Test Marijuana Samples for Paraqual
description: OXFORD, Miss., Aug. 5 (UPI)  A kit developed by scientists at the University of Mississippi to test marijuana for the presence of the herbicide paraquat has been released for sale.

title: Nicolas Ascieu
description: Paul T. is not speaking to Mike G., David Z. or George D. Mrs. G. and several others walked out of the tenants association and formed their own group. Allegations were made. Letters written. Flyers appeared regularly. It was difficult to walk a dog at night without getting the latest word.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN gutters split, rot out in sections, or develop bad cracks along open joints, they allow water to come pouring down the side of the house whenever it rains and can also be the cause of excess dampness entering the  walls or working its way in behind exterior trim and siding.

title: FISHING
description: THE outlook for tuna, which only a few years ago seemed to belong on the list of endangered species, now is fairly bright. Anglers from Sandy Hook to Atlantic City are reporting good amounts of school tuna moving northward along the coast.

title: 76ers At a New Camp; Will Open on Sept. 11
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP)  The Philadelphia 76ers have changed their training camp from Ursinus College in suburban Collegeville to Franklin and Marshall College in Lancaster.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: THE TAMING OF THE SHREWShakeWare's play, starring Raul Julia and Meryl Streep. Directed by Wilford Leach. The second production of free Shakespeare in Central Park. Delocarte. (6771750) Opens Wed.

title: Dialogue To Speak
description: WITH the publication of these two volumes, the Oxford series Greek Tragedy in New Translation is roughly onethird of the way along its course: 11 down, 21 to go. It is a distinguished enterprise; on the whole, the translators have amply satisfied the demand of the General Editor, William Arrowsmith, for language, rich and vivid as poetry which is equally effective as dialogue actors can speak, naturally and with dignity. The project has even higher ambitions: Its aim is to recreate the entire extant corpus of Greek tragedy as though it had been originally written by ancient masters at home in the English language of our time. This is a job for poets, and though there are a surprising number of Greek scholars who are also published poets (six of the 11 translations have only one name on the title page) the work often has to be done, as in the case of the two Sophoclean tragedies under review, by a poet in collaboration with a scholar.

title: Associated Press
description: WILSON, N.C., Aug. 5  Addressing an audience of several thousand tobacco farmers and their families, President Carter called today for continued Federal price supports for tobacco and for an enlightened education and research program to make the smoking of tobacco even more safe than it is today.

title: A OneWay Stream of Traffic
description: VENICE, Aug. 5 (UPI)  The Grand Canal became a oneway thoroughfare today when an law intended to ease boat traffic snarls took effect. It is one of 19 canals converted to oneway. Fines for going the wrong way on a oneway canal will run as high as $240.

title: Undercounting of Minority Groups Proves Difficult to Overcome
description: WASHINGTON Sometime in October of next year, 410 trucks will rumble out of a warehouse in Jeffersonville,Ind., and fan out toward the farthest reaches of the country. They will carry the millions of forms and everything else needed to take the 1980 Census of Population and Housing, which promises to be the biggest, most costly, most crucial, and some say most troubled headcount in American history.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: We would like to correct a statement made by Harvey Minkoff, author of Volunteer Firefighters: A Suburban Tradition [July 9] that there are no Women firefighters in Westchester County. That statement is no longer Correct. On April 12, the Fire Patrol Company of the Chappaqua Fire Department elected Muriel Lipschitz as a member of the company. She was forMany accepted by the Board of Fire Commissioners the next day.

title: Paperbacks:
description: A PRINCE OF OUR DISORDER, by John E. Mack. (Little, Brown, $6.95.) The life of a man who gave rise to legends, only to be destroyed by them  T. E. Lawrence (18881935), English soldier, archeologist, author and leader of an Arab rebellion against the Turks during World War I. This Pulitzer Prizewinning biography by a Harvard psychiatrist is judicious and not overburdened with scientific jargon.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Although most collectors today concentrate more on the esthetics than the pedigree of an object, there are areas in the decorative arts  Judaica, for one  that are notable exceptions.

title: Doctor Offers Advice On Finding a Doctor
description: HARRISON HOW does one choose a doctor? Some persons sake the advice of their nextdoor neighbors. Others ask referrals from top surgeons. But for many persons who find themselves suddenly sick, choosing a doctor is often a matter of finding help quickly and settling for someone who seems nice.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: IT was a clear, cool and dry summer afternoon, just as Max Spann, a realestate broker, predicted it would be. The volunteer fire department had set up a hamburger and hotdog stand and was doing a booming business. Children and dogs romped on the grass. Farmland stretched as far as the eye could see.

title: United Press International
description: LOSES IN SEMIFINAL: Manuel Orantes of Spain in action against Eddie Dibbs at the Volvo International tennis tournament in North Conway, N.H., yesterday. Dibbs won, 26,76,64, and will play John Alexander in today's final.

title: The Painful Collar of Pete Rose
description: When my hitting streak was ended, he was saying the other day, I felt terrible. I felt as though I'd lost my best friend.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The cashladen institutions didn't want to get caught sitting on the sidelines so they went wild.

title: Environmental Agency Will Test Common Pesticide for Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)  A Commonly used pesticide in the textile, adhesive and automobile industries is being reviewed to determine whether it is safe to use, the Environmental Protection Agency has announced.

description: WHEN gutters split, rot out in sections, or develop bad cracks along open joints, they allow water to come pouring down the side of the house whenever it rains and can also be the cause of excess dampness entering the walls or working its way in behind exterior trim and siding.

title: A Sponsor of Jersey Press Shield Bill Decries Jailing of Times Reporter
description: A New Jersey State Senator who sponsored a bill in 1972 for a comprehensive shield law to protect reporters and their sources yesterday called the imprisonment on Friday of M. A. Farber, a New York Times reporter, a disgraceful act that put into grave danger the public's right to know through a free press.

title: Watson Takes 5Shot Lead in P.G.A.
description: OAKMONT, Pa., Aug. 5  Tom Watson's fivestroke lead may look like runaway, but even Watson is not yet ready to say the 60th Professional Golfers Association championship has his name on it. Everyone agrees the formidable Oakmont Country Club is the kind of course that made it hard to protect a lead, and everyone is expecting hardfought finish tomorrow among at least five men.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators rose moderate fourtenths of a percent in June, but most of that increase was artificial, caused by a rush for building permits in California before new, stringent energy conservation requirements were imposed on new buildings. The index, which tends to foretell future economic trends, was essentially unchanged in May. Other signs that economic growth may be more sluggish in the remainder of 1978: New factory orders dipped threetenths of percent in June, and sales of new domestic cars injuly eased off the heady pace of May and June. Detroit reported sales gains of only fourtenths of a percent in last month's final 10day selling period from the yearearlier period although for the full month deliveries were 4.2 percent better that in 1977 Prices received by farmers for their goods fell for the first time in nine months, according to the Agriculture Department. The 1 percent decline won't immediately affect retail prices for food, said department experts, who noted in a separate report that consumers can expect a 10 percent increase in food prices in 1978. The department had originally estimated that increase at percent.

title: Grumman Corp. Planning to Diversify Into DowntoEarth, Nonmilitary Field
description: BETHPAGE, L.I.  The Grumman Corporation, the aerospace company that built the Lunar Module to help the United States explore the moon in the 1960's and that produced the swingwing supersonic F14 fighterbomber in the 1970's, plans to return to earth in the 19S0's.

title: Extradition of a Syrian Is Sought For Taking Children From Jersey
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP) Somerset County authorities were seek. ing the extradition today of Nabil Hassan, 33 years old, who fled back to Syria with his two children.

title: VAUDEVILLE STRIKES BACK!
description: From Pompano Beach, Fla., to Tampa and St. Augustine, to Norfolk, Va., and to Akron, Ohio and Lorraine, to Johnstown, Pa., Wheaton, Md., Portsmouth, R.I., to New Bedford, Mass., and Manchester, N.H., the InterCounty bus rented in Babylon, L.I., had zigzagged, onenighting just about all the way. For 31 days  and 27 cities the land cruiser had been the vaudevillians main base, a mobile family room of sorts where packs of plastic cups, thermoses of coffee, coolers filled with soft drinks and beer, packages of potato chips and cookies, enough books for a village library, needlepoint, suit and dress carriers and blankets and pillows lay in overhead racks and on and over the seats.

title: FRANK FONTAINE, 58, DIES AFTER BENEFIT
description: The comedian had a history of heart problems and was hospitalized in 1970.

title: What's Behind the Gold Rush?; A Look at History; A Look Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  Gold again appears to be widely loved. At one time during the week the price soared beyond $207 per fine ounce  fully $20 per ounce above the average price received by the United States Treasury at its auction on July 18 and almost $50 per ounce above the level seen in late April when the Treasury announced that it

title: Writer of Character
description: TN his introduction to this commemorative 75th birthday selection from the works of James Gould Cozzens, Matthew Bruccoli tells us that he about to present a relatively forgotten man. It is not that Cozzens has suffered from lack of exposure (after all, he had six BookoftheMonth Club selections, Pulitzer Prize, a William Dean Howells Medal and couple of Hollywood adaptations in what he calls his postapprenticeship novelistic career). But his major books  The Last Adam(1933), Men and Brethren(1936), The Just and the Unjust(1942), Guard of Honor(1948), By Love Possessed(1957)  do not appear on college reading lists that are chockablock with Cozzens contemporaries, and the English faculties tend to ignore him.

title: Walton, Knicks To Meet
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 5 (AP)The New York Knicks and the new San Diego team in the National Basketball Association are sending officials to Portland in an effort to capture the Trail Blazers' prize center, Bill Walton, a representative of Walton said today.

title: Diane C. Goss Wed To Karr Farrell Jr.
description: Diane Catherine Goss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carpenter Goss of Westport, Conn., and Block Island, R.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Karr Winslow Farrell Jr., son of Sally G. Farrell of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. Glyn Jones, chaplain of the Northfield Mount Hermon School, of which the couple are alumni, performed the ceremony in the Westside Baptist Church on Block Island.

title: India Is Trying to Supply Water To All Its Villages in Five Years
description: MOTRAN, India  Well before the hot morning sun creeps over the graybrown hills nearby, bringing dawn to this tiny village, Sushila Das is up and out, on her way to get her family's drinkine water.

title: ART
description: RIDGEFIELD THE group show occupying the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art's upper floors through Sept. 3 is entitled Contemporary Reflectinnc 197778 And through it. feels enormous, it actually comprises only 47 works by as many artists who were winnowed from more than 500 applicants.

title: U.S. Weighs Charge City Allows Racial Imbalance at S.I. Schools
description: The Federal Office for Civil Rights is investigating charges by several teachers that New York City's Board of Education has permitted Staten Island's five academic high schools to become racially imbalanced.

title: GARDENING Lilies Have Their Day
description: H AVEyou driven through the countryside in midsummer and noticed the tall patches of orangeflowered plants blooming here and there alongside the road or in an old fence row? They represent one or me naraiest ana most prolific elements in some longabandoned farmstead garden. Not only have they survived unattended, but they have spread and naturalized as well.

title: A Delicate G.O.P. Balance
description: THE last cups of coffee had just been cleared away at a preconvention Republican luncheon when state party chairman Frederick K. Biebel announced an impending event  the unveiling of the G.O.P. candidates for attorney general, secretary of the state, comptroller and treasurer.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  German Shepherd Dog Club of Greater New Haven breed, obedience and junior showmanship match, North Haven Park and Recreational Center, Lindsley and Elm Streets., North Haven, Conn.; entries from 9 A.M.; obedience judging, 11 A.M.; breed judging, 1 P.M.

title: Uncommon New Plays By Tom Stoppard And David Rudkin
description: LONDON Tom Stoppard has a gymnastic wit, a semanticist's command of language and one of the most fantastically inventive pens in the Englishwriting world. He is philosophercomic. David Rudkin, on the other hand, is a poetmoralist with a Strindbergian intensity and an inter. personal vision. Each of these disparate English playwrights has had an uncommon new play produced here this summer.

title: Beaths
description: SIDELRobert. The New Nautilus Coop mourns the passing of one of our beloved members.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: A little more than a month after an Army recruit died at Fort Dix, N.J., of a new type of influenza similar to that found in swine, President Gerald R. Ford proposed in March 1976 that everyone in the United States be vaccinated against swine flu.

title: CRIME
description: Like its two predecessors, SPEAK FOR THE DEAD by Rex Burns (Harper & Row, $8.95) is a competent procedural. But the hero of the series Gabriel Wager, a halfbreed cop in the Denver Police Department  is no longer in narcotics, as he was in The Alvarez Journal and The Farnsworth Score. Wager has been transferred to homicide, and suddenly he has to deal with a particularly gruesome murder.
