description: Here are some of the latest disaster films now in production:

title: Jams Gayle Lipman Wed To Gregory W. Altschuh
description: Janis Gayle Lipman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lipman of Augusta, Me., was married yesterday to Gregory William Altschuh, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Altschuh of Ballwin, Mo.

title: Court Stops Mrs. Brennan's Postal Service
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 5  Instead of picking up letters from customers of her twoandahalfyearold downtown private postal delivery service, Patricia H. Brennan was telephoning them yesterday to tell them she had finally been put out of business.

title: The World
description: It is a measure of the authority of the three black members of the Salis. bury Government that they were not consulted  or even informed  in advance of Rhodesia's raid last week on black guerrilla bases in Mozambique. It is even more a measure of Rhodesia's tragegy ttiat two of the black leaders applauded the raid while the third was equivocal.

title: Military Funds Measure Approved by the House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)  The House today passed compromise legislation authorizing $36.9 billion for weapons purchases, research and development by the military.

title: Wheels in Motion for New Racer
description: Everyone was talking about it for years, but no one was doing anything about it. Finally, H.A. (Humpy) Wheeler and John Greenwood decided to try to do something about it, and they may have stirred up a hornet's nest.

title: Energy Master Plan Bill Gets Approval by Carey
description: Governor Carey yesterday signed a bill authorizing the creation of a statewide master plan to be used as a guide to future energy decisions.

title: Grumman Sights Nonmilitary Target
description: BETHPAGE THE Grumman Corporation, the aerospace company that built the Lunar Module to help the United States explore the moon in the 1960's and that produced the swingwing supersonic F14 fighterbomber in the 1970's, plans to return to earth in the PARO'.

title: In Clarksville, 1 Cow + 1 Buffalo=1 Beefalo
description: CLARKSVILLE ASIGN on Route 1 in this Mercer County community reads, Beefalo  World's Best Grass Converter. A beefalo is not a farm implement, as you might think, but a hybrid animal that is a cross between a cow and a buffalo. The 150 animals on the Vaccaro Brothers Sod Farm convert grass, instead of grain, to beefalo steaks.

title: Miss Cronin Wed To John Schreiber
description: Rebecca Lynn Cronin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cronin of Baton Rouge, La., was married yesterday in Temple Sinai in New Orleans, to John Robert Schreiber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Screiber of Scarsdale, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Julian Feibelman and the Rev. William Farrell, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: This page: Some of Norma Karnali s concoctions for the Emerald Cit3 sequence of 77tt Wiz. Opposite page: Sequin jumpsuit by Ronald Kolodzie, dress by Norma Kamali and fox coat by Halston for Ben Kahn.
description: It started because director Sidney Lumet wanted the segment to be all about status and style. It ended up with Oscar de la Renta, Bill Blass, Mary McFadden, Ralph Lauren, Halston, Norma Kamali, Stephen Burrows, Scott Barrie, Zoran, Ronald Kolodzie, Fernando Sanchez and furriers Alixandre and Ben Kahn producing the costumes that help turn the Emerald City scene in the UniversalMotown film The Wiz, due in October, into a razzle dazzle spectacular. While the star, Diana Ross, gets to wear only one simple white blouse and skirt through two hours or more of film, 400 beautiful black dancers get to preen and prance for 10 minutes  changing costumes three times  in original creations by these top fashion talents. The result is an unforgettable extravaganza (for instance, the moment when 20 handsome male dancers hoof it up in impeccably tailored Ralph Lauren tuxedos  of gold lame). It is also a salute to American design talent. The idea came from Joel Schumacher, screenwriter of The Wiz, and, according to most of the designers, it was because of his enthusiasm that they agreed to do it. They were given color swatches and $200 for each costume a pittance compared to the average $1,000 it takes to produce a single sample. Each design was made three times  once in emerald green, once in red and once in gold. Everyone had a field day. Some, like Halston, refused to use inexpensive theatrical fabrics and sent costumes made of stuff costing $100 a yard and more. Bill Blass's arrived with his usual custommade touches. Fernando Sanchez cut short a Paris holiday to personally drape each dress. Said Norma Kamali, When we finished, we all had tears in our eyes. We had enjoyed it so much. All of them made a great contribution of time, talent and money. says Joel Schumacher. As for the costumes themselves, alas, they will go the way of all chorusline clothes  to the storerooms of Universal Studios to be reworked for some other film or just fade away, their magic preserved only for 10.

title: ANTIQUES
description: BELMAR OH, these? said Walter Newman, pointing to a group of old ceiling fans hanging in his store. They are not for sale. I'm collecting them. Going to have them hooked up some time.

title: Dog Racing: Long Shot or Safe Bet?
description: IN 1934, the last year there was dog racing in New Jersey, promoters of the fledgling sport came up with the awful idea of using monkeys to ride the greyhounds. The public was understandably repelled by the simian jockeys, who were finally banned from the track, but the sport never recovered; the bill legalizing it was found to have been unconstitutionally drafted, and dogracing was banned only four months after it had begun.

title: Thousands Turn Out At Rites for 2 Firemen Killed by.Falling Roof
description: Thousands of firefighters, public officials and others turned out in the rain yesterday for the first of the funerals for six firefighters who perished last Wednesday when a blazing roof collapsed at a Brooklyn supermarket.

title: Territory and Temperament Thwart a Middle East Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Hopes for peace. in the Middle East soared dramatically high last November when Egyptian President Anwar elSadat suddenly flew to Jerusalem. But since that dazzling ascent, there has been a stagebystage decline, from the early facetoface conferences of Mr. Sadat and Prime Minister Menachem Begin, through bilateral negotiating committees to triangular meetings under United States sponsorship. Now it's back to where it started, with a harassed American Secretary of State shuttling between capitals.

title: Tip Blows His Top
description: Ah, what a battle of titans: Tip O'Neill, the Speaker of the House, versus the White House. And what was it all about? Well, the Speaker last year got the Administration to keel) his friend Robert Griffin in an important job. But the Administration later concluded that he had to be replaced. Apparently, not enough care was taken to assuage the Speaker's sensibilities. He became angry indeed, saying he had been Misled by Frank Moore, the President's emissary, and that he and Mr. Griffin had been shabbily treated.?

title: Kate Proctor Is Married In Greenwich
description: Cathleen Patricia Proctor, daughter of Mrs. James Wilson Riley Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and William Ross Proctor Jr. of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Wesley Robertson Brooks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard W. Brooks of Greenwich.

title: 2 Men and 40 Horses Killed in Jersey Blaze
description: A blacksmith and a groom died and at least 40 harnessracing horses were killed yesterday, when a fire swept through stable in Englishtown, N.J., owned by Eery& Filion, a leading harnessracing driver. One person was reported missing.

title: Van Ramsey to Wed Liza Skouras Fowler
description: Dr. and Mrs. George Anderson Fowler of Santa Fe, N.M., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Liza Skouras Fowler, to Van Broughton Ramsey, an architect and son of Mrs. James Hite of Bay City, Tex., and Cecil Robinson Ramsey of Houston.

title: In memnriant
description: BUCHBINDERHarry, Four long years. The glow of remembrance shines as brightly as the beauty of our memory. We miss a truly grand guy. Loving Family.

title: Steelers' Bradshaw Injured
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 (AP)  Two Pittsburgh quarterbacks, Cliff Stoudt and Mike Kruczek, tossed touchdown passes tonight after the starter, Terry Bradshaw, suffered a broken nose, and the Steelers, ignited by Ron Scott's 87yard touchdown jaunt, beat the Baltimore Colts, 2210, in a National Football League exhibition.

title: News Summary
description: Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived in Jerusalem in search of a formula to keep the IsraeliEgyptian negotiations alive. His latest trip in the role of mediator was taken in a mood of uncertainty and doubt. Foreign Minister. Moshe Dayan greeted Mr. Wnce with a remark that Egypt and Israel werestuckand needed the United States to help. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: what's Doing in PANAMA
description: THE TROPICS  Panama is a country one usually visits on the way to somewhere else, going north or south by plane or east or west by ship. But it is well worth coming to Panama for its own sake either for a few days rest and fun or for an entire vacation. There's the canal; there are casinos, and there are beautiful, beaches on offshore islands. And more than anything else, there is the tropical ambience  the heat and humidity, the noise and rhythms, the rain forests that seem to grow before one's eyes, the relaxed laughter of many races living in harmony. Those who dislike noise should keep to the islands or that strip of Middle America, the Canal Zone. But that is to miss the real flavor of Panama.

title: The Nation
description: When unveiled last March, the Carter urban plan had a little something for everybody. Now it's got a lot less of one very important element  money  in part because of the way the package attempted to please. There have been other setbacks, but the big blow came last week when the House Intergovernmental Relations subcommittee, whose members are predominantly rural and conservative, voted to 6 to postpone indefinitely a bill that would have provided $1 billion a year for distressed cities.

title: BRIDGE
description: Since the earliest days of the game of bridge New York City has had the largest number of worldclass players available. In an intercity match of 20 or more players a side only Los Angeles would have had a realistic chance to defeat New York at any period in time.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN gutters split, rot out in sections, or develop bad cracks along open joints, they allow water to come pouring down the side of the house whenever it rains and can also be the cause of excess dampness entering the walls or working its way in behind exterior trim and siding.

title: Wine
description: Who is going to save us from the great whitewine shortage?

title: A Voyage Aboard a Vanishing Species
description: The captain of a passing pleasure craft fixed us with an appraising eye, then broke into an appreciative grin as his 35knot twindiesel fiberglass sports cruiser flashed by while we cleared Sandy Point and entered Chesapeake Bay. He swung around in his cushioned chair on the flying bridge, raised a bullhorn and electronically bellowed across the waters: You're looking mighty pretty, Lady Katie.  me praise was for our 65foot skipjack, the Lady Katie, classic sloop that has been restored to almost mint condition. She is one of the last of her class to prowl the bay and the only one available for charter.

title: Life in the Test Tube
description: WASHINGTONThe birth of Louise Brown should be a cause of joy and gratitude. Nature (blocked oviducts) has been outwitted and Louise is apparently healthy and normal. Three cheers for Doctors Patrick Steptoe and Robert Edwards! So what else is new? That is probably the reaction of very many to the testtube baby.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: EXETER, N.H.  Five years ago, Joseph S. Gaziano, a stocky exMarine who hasn't changed his haircut since boot camp, assumed the leadership of Tyco Laboratories Inc. after a parade of chief executives had failed to bring the company out of its tailspin. Tyco, an 11yearold concern with losses of $18.8 million in 1970, seemed to be another of the hightechnology stars located along New England's Route 128 that was headed for oblivion.

title: Musical on God Casts Special Spell on Cast
description: NORTHPORT MICHAEL OREFICE, wearing blue shorts and a yellow Tshirt that features an obscene green animal, is standing on a table with his hands outstretched and his eves rolled back.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Red Sox and Slumps
description: Carl Yastrzemski, a few weeks short of his 39th birthday, the captain and hero of the Boston Red Sox, was a perfect symbol of the team last week: achinn in midseason.

title: One Vote for Direct Primaries
description: THE experience of the Democratic State Convention in Hartford on July 2122 was a prime argument for the total revision of the state election laws in Connecticut. There should be direct open primaries for all levels of state of. fice, from governor through state rep. iesentative. Though, to be sure, much of the backrciom political work had been done long beforehand, the convention itself represented every ignominious image of people engaged in political activity.

title: The Region; Continued; ColorBlind Tests Can Be Biased, Too (True/False)
description: STAMFORD  In the 1960's, when the heat was on to integrate police departments throughout the country, not much attention was paid to the racial composition of fire departments. But this has been changing in recent years, a trend brought sharply into focus by a Federal judge's decision last week on firedepartment testing and hiring procedures in Bridgeport. Connecticut's largest city.

title: Auto Insurance And Reform
description: THE Byrne administration's proposals for automobileinsurance reform (a reinsurance facility in place of the assignedrisk plan and a merit rating system) will produce none of the dire effects that the industry has been solemnly predicting, and, in particular, they will not increase the cost of insurance for good drivers.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than massmarket paperbacks. This listing based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and wholesalers with more than 2,500 outlets across the United States.

title: Viiginia and Marc Chagall, 1998.
description: SIDNEY ALEXANDER'S Chagall is not the Sundaysupplement artist: not simply, that is, the 91yearold patriarch of modem art, survivor ancient cultural battles; nor the Jewish artist, storyteller par excellence, whose fables of old Russia, full of floating pedlars and bridal couples, fiddlers on the roof, sacrificial cows and symbolic goats, ghetto villages and moonstruck streets, have charmed generations; nor the international celebrity of recent years whose important commissions  including ceiling paintings for the Paris Opera, murals for the New York Metropolitan Opera, stainedglass windows for the Synagogue of the Hadassah Hebrew University Medical Center outside Jerusalem  have brought him a glossy fame and considerable wealth.

title: Miss Remington Becomes the Bride Of T.A.McKay Jr.
description: Elizabeth Ryder Remington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ryder Remington of St. Louis, was married there yesterday to Thomas Agnew McKay Jr., son of Mrs. McKay of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. and the late Mr. McKay. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of St. Michael and St. George by Canon Joseph Swift.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH few taxpayers bother to attend the routine meetings of municipal councils and boards, the spirit of Connecticut's Sunshine Law is that they should feel welcome to watch their business being transacted in town hall. But what about watching in the first selectman's living room? ne montniy meetings of New Lanaan's 12member Board of Finance are usually held in Town Hall, but the June meeting took place after dinner in the home of Henry S. Noble, the First Selectman.

title: Christine Hastings Is Married
description: Christine Margaret Hastings, daughter of Mrs. Frank Patterson of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Harold Hastings, was married yesterday to Robert Alan Elkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archie Elkins of Jersey City. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather by State Supreme Court Justice George D. Burchell. The bride is completing work for a master's degree in occupational therapy at New York University. Her husband is a lawyer in private practice with his father in Jersey City.

title: Salzburg Festival Presents Its New Magic Flute
description: SALZBURG, Austria  In a captivating version of Mozart's The Magic Flute that is nave yet sophisticated, witty yet moral, the Salzburg Festival unveiled its second new production recently. It was a unanimous critical and popular triumph for the director and designer, JeariPierre Ponnelle, and the conductor, James Levine, who beamed through nearly 20 minutes of bravos from the normally reserved audience.

title: Miami Beach Casino Backers Seek to Put Issue on Ballot
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 5  Those who see casino gambling as a road to economic rebirth for Miami Beach are close to getting the 256,000 petition signatures they need to have a constitutional amendment on the matter placed on the Nov. ballot.

title: TV VIEW
description: The most serious threat to television and its claim to First Amendment freedoms is not the Federal Communications Commission or the Supreme Court or an Imperial Presidency, but the runaway television rating process. The current obsession with surveying the habits and pulse of television sets, rather than the response of and impact on human beings, has resulted in an industry preoccupied with shortterm indicators and profits at the expense of its own longterm promise and economic stability.

title: 4 SLAIN IN PAKISTAN IN A RAID ON PLO.; IRAQIS SUSPECTED
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 5  Four armed men broke into the Palestine Liberation Organization's office here today and killed four persons, bringing ArabagainstArab terrorism to this country for the second time in four days.

title: Women Film Directors: Will They, Too, Be Allowed to Bomb?
description: HOLLYWOOD yes, women are beginning to direct feature films; Claudia Weill's Girlfriends, which premieres Friday, will be the third such movie to open in New York this year. Yes, women are beginning to be entrusted with major projects  for instance, Jane Wagner is currently editing Moment by MoKirk Honeycutt is a West Coastbased freelance writer who regularly covers the film scene.

title: 2'San Francisco Areas Make a Comeback
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5  Two highcrime, lowincome neighborhoods in central San Francisco, the HaightFillmore District and Hayes Valley, are experiencing rapid rehabilitation because young professionals are moving in and restoring the area's many Victorian houses.

title: Lloyd Taft Jr. Plans to Wed Mimi Shanlev
description: Marcella Marie Shanley and Lloyd Bowers Taft Jr., graduates of Hampshire College, plan to be married next December. The prospective bridegroom is a greatgrandson of President William H. Taft, who also served later as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Garden
description: Prune overgrown hedges. It is late to feed rhododendrons, azaleas and other ericaceous landscape plants Lacebugs on andromeda cause dusty, faded look; use malathion or Sevin.. Last call to plant second crop vegetables such as beans, cabbage, broccoli and leaf lettuce for late summer harvest. Finish dividine iris.

title: Pepsi Bethel  Master of Jazz Dance
description: The accompanist was up to double time, and two by two, the class charged across the studio in a series of leaps and long steps. A small, slight black man with a cap of gray hair and a body that could be described as nearCubist  all edges, angles and indentations  stood to one side, shouting out the beat and pounding a tambourine. As the last pair finished, Pepsi Bethel dropped the tambourine and launched a run of his own, tacking on a couple spins, a fancy shuffle and a high kick at the end. Laughing, the students did their best to follow; moments later, at the class's conclusion, they broke into a spontaneous ovation that lasted half a minute.

title: Yale Researchers
description: MARILYN J., a woman in her mid40's with a teenage daughter, had a history of depression throughouther marriage. Eventually she found that she could not manage even taking a simple family vacation. She was unable to talk about her feelings. When her marriage began to break up, she sought psychiatric help.

title: Eccentrics Flowered
description: APART from the monarchy, few institutions in England emerged earlier than Oxford and Cambridge. They are, for example, older than Parliament  very early in the 12th century, indeed by 1117, there were scholars at Oxford. Since then Oxford has grown like a coral reef  buffeted at times by the rage of religion, the clash of civil war and the anger of social envy but, like the monarchy, adapting to social change, to the demands of new economic and political worlds, even if slowly. No matter how tumultuous the times, no matter how powerful, passionate, resentful those bent on reform might be, Oxford preserved an exceptional independence and cherished an elite.

title: Marital Therapist and Persistent Writer
description: L ISTEN, Joel D. Block remembers being told by his high school guidance counselor. You're not too bright. You had better be doing things that don't take intellect. Was he wrong!

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: I wish to commend The Times for printing the article Contracts Without Contacts [July 23].

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Anybody in musical journalism learns, soon on, approach firstperformance claims, especially of works by old composers, with a large amount of caution. Nobody keeps accurate records along these lines, and those who go off halfcocked are sure to be brought to the bar. Say, for instance, that you run a small opera company and have round Dido Abbandonata, a forgotten work by Giovanni Battista Pierluigi. You look up the Handbook of American Operatic Premieres by Julius Mattfeld (No. 5 in the Detroit Series of Musical Bibliography, in case you are interested) and you find no entry. You check with Maria Rich of the Central Opera Service. She has never heard of any performance in America. You ask around, and nobody has ever heard of any performance. Hell, they have not even heard of the composer. So you announce Dido Abbandonata as an American premiere. Sure enough, you are going to get a letter from the Lower Chaminade Society of East Cattleboro, Iowa, complete with photostat of program, saying ha, ha, we staged this on Feb. 12, 1902.

title: Vilas and McEnroe Lead Semifinalists
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5 Guillermo Vilas survived a threeset scare against Jeff Borowiak tonight and joined John McEnroe, JoseLuis Clerc and Balazs Taroczy in the semifinals of a $75,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Cobbs
description: Elizabeth Lipton Cobbs, a student at the George Washington University Medical School, was married yesterday to Philip Davis Greene, a partner in the Washington law firm of Schwalb and TInnnanfald.

title: Pictures of Things as They Are
description: DOROTHEA LANGE was endowed with most of the acceptable stigmata of the certified genius, photography division. Ambitious, of course, with a flair for fame, hard on herself and others, alter.; nately (but always theatrically) kindhearted and inconsiderate, implacably egotistical, domineering, contentious, apparently humorless, selfanalytical ad nauseam, hardworking to the point of total exhaustion  even deathshe appears to have been like most great photographers, a pain in the neck.

title: Allen, Legend Still: How About That?
description: The script lay unopened on the table. Soon, The Legend would enter a soundproof booth and begin reading into a microphone the words typed for him, making them come to life with a cadence like the rise and fall of a roller coaster. But now there was the matter of the can of coffee and the halfeaten doughnut. Pondering them, The Legend reached lazily for the doughnut, then drew back his hand. It was still early in the morning, too early to grab the day. The Legend looked tired. His eyelids were marshmallows.

title: Western Nations Agree On HijackingPact Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)  The United States and six other industrial nations that attended a meeting of heads of state in Bonn at the beginning of this month have followed up that session with details of an agreement on prompt, effective and coordinated action against countries that harbor air hijackers, the State Department said today.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Billy Martin Affair; Give Jackson a Chance, He Is Doing His Best; Martin Owes Apologies To Veracious Renorters; Is Martin on Parole From the Liars' Club?; Steinbrenner and Finley: 1 Too Many for Baseball; Yankees Held Negligent For Ignoring Counseling; As a Publicity Stunt, The Midget Was Superior; Not Everyone Cheers The Return of Martin; Third Base Is His Bag And His Only Bag; Murdoch's Suspension: Punishment Doesn't Fit; The Manager; The Resignation; The Return
description: To the Sports Editor: In the 1960's, Yankee fans went on an orgy of mass hate against Roger Maris. Today, Reggie Jackson is the object of their animosity while the puerile pugilist, Billy Martin, has all but reached point of canonization. Yankee Stadium has become a bedlam of the bizarre.

title: Miner Advances In Golf
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 5  The 76th Metropolitan Golf Assocition amateur championship reached the final round early this afternoon with these surprising results:

title: Holly Nichols observes a nest of imperial Amazon parrots in a mountain rain forest on Dominica. You must keep watching, she says.Sometimes they fly in without a sound.
description: Two large black shadows appear suddenly in our peripheral vision. Looking up quickly through binoculars, we see brief, brilliant flashes of red, yellow, green. A pair of parrots returns, screeching, to the outer branches their nesting tree. They quickly vanish from sight amid the confusing play sunlight and shadow in the dense tronical foliaee ne parrots are silent now. My companion explains in a whisper that they are making their way  slowly, secretively, so no predator can follow ward toward the trunk of the tall hardwood tree. Their nest is there, concealed from our view by a tangle of huge ferns, vines and air plants.

title: Report Faults County on Bias
description: ALACK of official agencies to combat housing and job discrimination in Westchester has made it difficult to achieve an effective racial balance, according to a study just completed by the Regional Plan Association.

title: J. Negley Cooke Jr., A Chemical Executive And SkiFund Leader
description: J. Negley Cooke Jr., former president of Glenbrook Laboratories and past chairman of the New York chapter of the United States Ski Team Fund, died Thursday of cardiac arrest at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical. Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan and Stowe. Vt.

title: Traveling by Herself, Miss Onassis Arrives In Athens From Soviet
description: ATHENS, Aug. 5  Christina Onassis Kauzov, traveling alone, arrived here from Moscow today.

title: Couple on Foot Hit by Auto
description: SAYLORSBURG, Pa., Aug. 5 (UPI) Olga Wozniak, 61 years old, was killed and her husband, Harry, seriously injured early today when they were struck by a hitandrun automobile as they crossed a highway, Route 930, the state police said.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY You Have to Show Your Lawn Who's Boss
description: NOW that we have truth in labeling, congressmen's finances, the F.B.I. and Richard M. Nixon, I think we're ready to handle another great illumination  the truth about lawns.

title: Alydar Wins Easily; J. O. Tobin Runs 6th
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 5 Alydar had his moment of glory today.

title: DINING OUT
description: SOCIOLOGISTS have dwelt at length on the accelerating rate of. change in our society, but none of them, we suspect, have ever been to Le Gai Pinguin in White Plains: It seemed on recent visits exactly as it was 20odd years ago when we were first sent there as a parental treat. Oeufs la Russe, coq au vin, crme caramel signified the world of French restaurants at that time  and they are unchanged.

title: 12 Wives Lose Suit on Court Handling of Beatings
description: A suit brought by 12 women who said they had suffered repeated beatings by their husbands and who charged that per. sonnel of Family Court had denied them access to judges to seek orders of protection has been dismissed by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: Social Agency Names Director
description: A new executive director, Bernard C. Fisher, is taking office for the 35yearold Citizens Committee for Children of New York Inc., Aug. 14. Mr. Fisher has most recently served as assistant executive director andNew York area director for the State Board of Social Welfare. Elizabeth If. Wolff, the advocacy group's president, said he would immediately try to promote increases in social services to welfare childrep, in line with a committee study that charged that 600,000 such children were being given short shrift in New York City. Other priority projects, she said, involve juvenile justice, health and child care.

title: 100 Acre Search Fails. To Turn Up Any Clue In Slaying of Student
description: Volunteers searching the,kvoods yesterday in New Hartford, Conn., near where the body of Michael H. Aranow, a medical student at Columbia University, was found on July 30, uncovered everything from spent cartridges to bottle caps, the state police said, but no clues to the murder.

title: Cover: Photograph by Gianfranco Gorgoni / Picture credits, Page 58
description: Cover: Photograph by Gianfranco Gorgoni / Picture credits, Page 58

title: More Nations Seek a PR Polish on Their U.S. Image
description: WASHINGTON  When a strike paralyzed Nicaragua early this year, President Anastasio Somoza Debayle took time from his homewise problems to cast an eye northward. How would journalists report the events in the United States, and how would their stories affect his Government's image here?

title: Editors Choice
description: ILLNESS AS METAPHOR, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $5.95.) A powerful attack on the attitudes we adopt toward sickness in our writing and thinking.

title: Yanks Beat Orioles; Cards Top Mets, 53
description: Scoring a total of three runs, which Manager Bob Lemon called a momentous occasion, the Yankees broke a threegame losing streak last night at Yankee Stadium with a 32 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Tempest on the Charles. The voices that drift through Harvard's halls in midsummer are usually temperate and reasonable, as befits an ancient seat higher learning. They were that way last month as 80 carefully selected men and women, all recent college graduates, all anxious to find places in publishing, forgathered in the Gutman Library for the daily sessions of Radcliffe's 31st annual Publishing Procedures course. They listened with the earnestness of neophytes about to take religious orders as a score of editors, authors, printers and marketing specialists explained what the life they aspired to would be like. Some particularly relished the protest of John Irving, author of The World According to Garp, that book publishing is fast being Hollywoodized.

title: With a Branch at Auschwitz
description: THE century of the multinational corporation will not likely see a more creative and perversely influential member of that brotherhood than I. G. Farben, the German chemical firm. We owe its scientists for such blessings as sulfa drugs. and aspirin. But I. G. is much more unforgettable as the industrial demon of two world wars, introducing poison gas to trench warfare in the first and, in the second, commercializing the horror of Auschwitz.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: The horses are running at Saratoga, which means that Charlie Patrick is back on the job as tennis pro at the Little Club (Saratoga Golf and Polo Club). In real life Charlie Patrick is the entire athletic department at Bard College in AnnandaleonHudson, where he taught tennis and soccer to Chevy Chase but not nitirh when that illustrious athlete was an undergraduate.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: AVON  Suzanne Benton: Mask and ritual journey tales, Thursday 7:30 P.M., in the park. Information 6781867.

title: Karpov Holds Off Mating Attack in Game 9: Draw Likely
description: BAGUIO the Philippines Aug. 5 Viktor Korchnoi, the challenger labored long and hard to press aSlight advantage against the world chess charnpion Anatoly Karpov, in the ninth game of theirjitle match here in the.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: AN unusual demand for condominiums is sweeping the state. The market, depressed since 1974, has lately been termed fantastic, unbelievable and even wild.

title: The Best Goods
description: In the foreword to Inventive Paris Clothes 19091939: A Photographic Essay by Irving Penn (Viking / Studio, $18.95), the great fashion photographer says he was inspired by A luxurious clothesworld (that] had once existed (and not so long ago at that), apparently without concern for cost, where it seemed no material was too expensive to use, no amount of labor too dear to employ, no designer's fantasy too extravagant to realize. The clothes from the Costume Institute collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are by Poi ret, Vionnet, Molyneux, Chanel, Schiaparelli and others. The text and captions by Diana Vreeland, special consultant to the Costume Institute, are as sumptuous as the garments themselves. The Callot dress on the left, with its floating panel train, is of coup de velour, edgedwith silver lace.

title: When Is It Rock and When Rock n Roll? A Critic Ventures an Answer
description: Baby, that is rock and roll sang the Coasters in 1959, and nobody had to ask what they meant. Rock and roll had defined itself since it burst upon the national consciousness in the mid1950's. According to Chuck Berry. it had a backbeat you couldn't lose. According to Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, whc wrote the Coasters hit, you couldn't always understand the words; if you did, You'd really blow your lid. Accord. ing to a leaflet distributed by White Citizens Councils in the South, the screaming, idiotic words and savage music of these records are undermining the morals of our white youth in America, but on the whole this warning was not greeted with the serious consideration it merited.

title: SMOKING PERIL CITED IN INDUSTRY STUDY
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5  Cigarette smoking can cause irreversible heart damage and might be responsible for medical maladies ranging from indigestion to cancer, researchers for the American Medical Association said today.

title: Trouble to the North: II
description: OTTAWA  Canadian politicians and journalists confidently expected that Prime Minister Trudeau would call elections for last spring. Then they confidently expected he would call elections for this summer. This week, he stunned them again by saying there was no need for resort to the polls at this time.

title: ANTIQUES
description: HARTFORD IN 1838, when she was 27 years old, Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote to friend: I have about three hours a day in writing, and if you see my name coming out everywhere, you may be sure of one thing, I do it for the pay. have determined not to be a mere domestic slave without even the leisure to excel in my duties. I mean to have money enough to have my house kept in the best manner.

title: Deaths
description: MOSKOWITZ  Alexander. Beloved husband of Bonnie, devoted father of  Roberta Mandel, and Arthur Moskowitz, adored son of Sarah, loving fatherInlaw of Howard Mandel, dear brother of Florence Rubin, Sylvia Goldstein, Harold Moskowitz, cherished grandfather of Joshua, Julie, and Lori. Services Sunday 1 P.M. Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Summer School for Musicians
description: MADISON ABAREFOOT girl with a music stand before her goes over a flute passage under the shade of an oak tree. A boy plays a French horn in a deserted gazebo. Two trumpet players perform an impromptu duet on a vast, open space of lawn, while other young men and women, all carrying instrument cases, walk by, hardly casting a glance in the direction of the players.

title: DINING OUT
description: EAST HADDAM AS the saying goes, there is good news and bad news at Geiston House in East Haddam. First the good news. The 19th century Victorian house in which the restaurant is ensconced is a beauty, inside and out, and handsomely maintained. Each dining mom is nristinelv done in period style. The entire effect makes an attractive complement to the neighboring Goodspeed Opera House, another Victorian delight located just a skip away on a hillside overlooking the Connecticut River. Lunch or dinner at Gelston House before a performance at Goodspeed could make an appealing outing to this nicely preserved summer town on the river.

title: At Home: She Defies Category, She Is a Woman in the Country
description: EVERYONE has a theory about her. She's rigid; she's frigid; she's compulsive. In place of personality, she has a defense mechanism. She is the world's champion coper. She's a bore, a Renaissance woman, a saint, a peach.

title: DUAL ADDICTION
description: Helen of Troy was said to have dissolved opium in the wine she served her warrior guests as a balm for their grief. Today, increasing numbers of Americans have concocted similar balms for themselves: alcohol and tranquilizers, alcohol and sedatives, alcohol and stimulants.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (AP)  The Soviet Union accused China today of whipping up military hysteria by calling for World War III and trying to scuttle detente between Moscow and Washing. ton.

title: POLITICS
description: WHITE PLAINS ALFRED B. DELBELLO attributes some of the trouble he has had lately in getting his programs to the Board of Legislators to the great influence he thinks the Conlervifive Party has on the hoard.

description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Deaths
description: KIRBYWilliam E. Of Scarsdale, N.Y., on August 4th, 1978, husband of Helen McGoldrick, father of William E., Jr., brother of Charles Kirby, Mends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y.. Sunday 7.1 P.M. Mess of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, Monday 11 A.M.

title: Volunteer Services Suffer As SelfImage of Women Changes
description: WASHINGTON.  The National Council of Jewish Women in Atlanta must now pay people to stuff envelopes and drive car pools, routine jobs that were once performed by volunteers. But a program in family counseling where women can deal directly with people and learn new skills has a long waiting list of volunteers.

title: Deaths
description: F RANGI PAN IHermina, In Fra. mingham, Mass, Aug 4, 1978, mother of Mrs. Rose Miller. Services pd. vate. Interment Mt. Auburn Cemete rv, Cambridge, Mass. In lieu of flow ers, contributions may be made her memory to the charities el choice.

title: ART More Real Than Real
description: EAST HAMPTON WHEN realism started yet another comeback more than a decade ago, it was generally greeted in the art world with a shrug of indifference. Most of the comebacks of the last 30 years were unsuccessful. Was there any reason to believe that this one wouldn't be like the others, a shortlived phenomenon? The feeling in certain art circles was that realism had burned itself out, offering few new important possibilities, and that abstraction still held most of the artists in its powerful grip.

title: LETERS
description: To the Editor: I find it ironic that Caroline Seebohm, in her review of William Arnold's Shadowland (July 2), fails to mention Mr. Arnold's principal source Frances Farmer's autobiography, Will There Really Be a Morning? (Putnam, 1972). The reviewer would have had less praise for Mr. Arnold's tragic detective work had she read Miss Farmer's own graphic account of her fiveyear imprisonment in the violent ward of Western State Mental Hospital. Miss Farmer describes, in poignant detail, the tortures of insulin shock, hydrotherapy and brutal incarceration: She was kept naked and caged in a pen for incurables; she witnessed a lesbian rape that left its victim mutilated and catatonic. At one point, she was forced by a guard to eat her own excrement. Few prisoners have undergone such hellish torment. Yet she not only enduted: she survived the inferno to write a stirring autobiographical account of her experiences.

title: BEHIND TEE BEST SELLERS
description: James Carroll's Mortal Friends hasn't been banned in Boston. To the contrary, the city seems to have taken to its heart the 35yearold author of the bestselling novel about the Boston Irish and the Irish Irish. Here, Mortal Friends is taken as a really Bostonian book, Mr. Carroll said recently in a telephone conversation from his home on the down side of Beacon Hill. Mayor Kevin White himself introduced the author at a lecture. It embarrassed me to admit my world was not Boston.

title: 171 Shot Victor in Jersey
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5  Delta Flag, a colt whose name wasn't even on the original guest list, turned out to be the life of the party today in the $100,000 Monmouth Invitational Handicap.

title: Boarding Homes: Caught in the Web
description: DURING the last several weeks, the plight of residents in New Jersey's boarding homes has been the center of Ian inquiry conducted by the State Cornmission of Investigation. The newsoapers have frequently given these hearings frontpage coverage, with concen tration on the exploitation of these residents by the caretakers, who turned out.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WITH gasoline hovering at about 70 cents a gallon unleaded  it has become for some of us not only a litiuid to treasure, but also one to conserve, if possible. If you live in the city, it is easy to conserve gasoline  and thus energy, we are told  by simply not driving, by using public transportation, by walking.

title: Reduce Rents? No, No, SomeTenants Say, Not That!
description: To a tenant, there's nothing quite like opening the mail and learning that the rent is being reduced.

title: Suffolk Tax Shift Propdsed
description: WITH pressure building for a reduced realty tax in Suffolk County, the County Legislature last week received a proposal to set aside part of the salestax revenue to stabilize the property levy.

title: Victoria Grant, Inspector, Is Fiance of A. L. Rykus
description: Victoria Leslie Grant, a structural inspector with the Pittsburgh Testing Laboratory in Seattle, plans to be married next September to Alvin Lewis Rykus, who works in Seattle for Familian Northwest, plumbing distributors.

title: Janice Lynn D'Arrigo, a Vassar Alumna, Becomes Bride of Anthony Tagliagambe
description: Janice Lynn D'Arrigo, daughter of Civil Court Judge Charles J. D'Arrigo and Mrs. D'Arrigo of Emerson Hill, S.I., was married yesterday to Anthony F. Tagliagambe, who next month will become an assistant district attorney for Brooklyn. Re is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Mario F. Tagliagambe of Brooklyn.
