description: TuesdayThursday  MG Car Club Long Island Center 1,000mile international T.S.D. rally into Canada; start and finish at junction of Interstate 81 and New York Thruway in Syracuse. Information: Ken Feigner (516) 3640798 between 6 and 9 P.M.

title: SUFFOLK HEARS PLAN TO EASE REALTY TAX
description: With pressure building for a reduced realty tax in Suffolk County, the County Legislature last week received a proposal to set aside part of the salestax revenue to stabil ize the Property lexy.

title: Deaths
description: ALDHOUSAnna (nee Softly). of Hampton Bays on August 5, 1978, beloved aunt of Alice Wilkinson and Geech Kravalle. Services from the Brockett Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, NY on Tuesday, August 10AM. Interment to follow in Kensicc Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Visitinc hours 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM.

title: DelBello Now Seeks Referendum On Concept of a Power Takeover
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 4  County Executive Alfred B. DelBello today dropped his demand for immediate authority to borrow funds to take over the Consolidated Edison Company's electrical distribution network in Westchester, calling instead for a November referendum on the concept.

title: Crane Begins Presidential Drive With a Visit to New Hampshire
description: BEDFORD, N.H., Aug. 5 (AP)  Just 36 hours hours after announcing his candidacy for the Presidency, Representative Philip M. Crane, Republican of Illinois, was campaigning yesterday in New Hampshire, the state with the nation's earliest Presidential primary.

title: Around the Nation
description: HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Aug. 5 (UPI)  A murder indictment will be sought against a former Federal Bureau of Investigation informer who has been accused by two Ku Klux Klansmen of firing the shots in 1965 that killed Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a civil rights worker, District Attorney Jobie Bryan said today.

title: TestTube Baby Plants Are in Fashion
description: Test tube babies are born in the plant world every day. In fact, your next jade plant, Boston fern, aralia bromeliad or dracaena may be one of them.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BASKING RIDGE (High School, South Finley Avenue)  South Pacific, in a Ridge Summer Theater production. Friday and Saturday, 8:15 P.M. Opens Friday (through Aug. 12). $3. (201) 7663070.

title: John Stalvey Weds Virginia M. Holmes
description: Virginia Marcia Holmes and John Robert Dixon Stalvey, alumni of Williams College, were married at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J., yesterday by the Rev. S. 1inahpc narvin.

title: Vassallo Betters Mark In A.A.U. Swim Event
description: THE WOODLANDS, Tex., Aug. (AP)  Jessee Va.ssallo says he was entirely too calm last night before the final of the men's 400meter individual medley race at the Amateur Athletic Union longcourse swimming championships.

title: Bruce Moir Weds Elizabeth C. Wells
description: Elizabeth Cheney Wells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Shippen Wells of West Boylston, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Duncan Moir of Decatur, Ga., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Russell Moir of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Christopher Gist Raible performed the ceremony in the First Unitarian Church in Worcester, Mass.

title: Realty News.
description: Pitney Bowes is consolidating its operatiohs in New York City and is moving its offices from 630 Third Avenue to One Penn Plaza.

title: FreshAir Families Recall City Brothers
description: tiew York City was sweltering in the summer of 1922 as 10yearold Charles M. Coyne of Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section boarded a train at Grand Central Terminal bound for Potsdam, N.Y. It was the first summer that Fresh Air Fund children were leaving for vacations in St. Lawrence County, near the Canadian hnrelnr.

title: Earl (Dutch) Clark
description: CANON CITY, Colo., Aug. 5 (AP) Earl H. (Dutch) Clark, a former triplethreat quarterback, a coach of the Detroit Lions and a charter member of the National Football League's Hall of Fame, died here today. He was 71 years old.

title: Looking Straight At Death
description: FOR some, the most terrifying aspect of death that it will not yield to being managed; these are often the best of people, who strongly believe the attractive possibility that human existence can be arranged into an orderly, harmonious and peaceful communality. From Gerda Lerner's beautifully controlled account of her husband's death, it would appear that she and Carl Lerner were lust such vigorously optimistic realists. The kind of courage with which they faced the ravaging disaster of an inoperable brain tumor, given the tragic combination of indomitable character and violent circumstance, makes for a book that heartens and breaks the heart at the same time.

title: Tornado Set Back Cosmos
description: DALLAS, Aug. 5  Jeff Bourne stored four goals and the Dallas Tornado defeated the Cosmos, 53, in the last regularseason game for both teams.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Outwardly, the National Ballet of Canada and the London Festival Ballet would seem to have little in common. The implicit model for the Toronto company has always been Britain's Royal Ballet and devotees of that company have never considered Festival Ballet to be in the same class. At times, Festival Ballet hat even been regarded as the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo of the British Isles. Today, its repertory and plethora of dancers from throughout the world bring it closer to such American troupes as the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater than to the National Ballet.

title: DINING OUT New Chef in a Stylish Setting; Winston's
description: WINSTON'S, a dazzlingly stylish place with a waterfront vista in Port Washington, has been open for less than a year. Last winter's evaluation was a onestar rating for adequate seafood and steak. Now, there a new French chef and, having heard that he has considerable talent, I decided to take another look.

title: Eagagemests 5022
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Greenfield Nippily announce the engagement of their daughter Jane Sue to Mr. Lee Jeffrey Raisfeld, son of Mrs. Martine Raisfeld end the late Mr. Arthur Raisfeld.

title: Four Clevelanders Who Adopted Beethoven
description: If the ideal string quartet is democratic musical partnership in which four compatible, firstrate players perform together as if on a single instrument, the Cleveland Quartet has come close to that ideal these past few years. In fact, ever since the quartet was formed nearly a decade ago, violinists Donald Weilerstein and Peter Salaff, violist Martha Strongin Katz and her husband, cellist Paul Katz, have built a reputation for giving the kind of performances that steadily win high critical praise and the approval of chambermusic devotees.

title: The Biennale's Romp With Nature
description: VENICE The first obstacle facing you on entering the Biennale grounds is a plain concrete slab, 25 feet square, conceivably the first leg of a transVenice flyover system. It's the work of Mauro Staccioli.

title: GARDENING
description: FALL planting starts while summer is still with us. In New Jersey, many perennials are best planted in August or early September, and some of them cannot be planted successfully at any other time.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: ARECENT fact sheet distributed by the Federal Railroad Administration on the subject of upgrading the WashingtonNew YorkBoston rail corridor has an intriguing heading:

title: Fidrych Throws 8 Pitches, Leaves
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP)  Cornplaning of stiffness in his right arm, Mark Fidrych was lifted after working only the first inning of a minor league game today, the Detroit Tigers said:

title: Lightning Starts Oil Tank Fire
description: CITRONELLE, Ala., Aug. 5 (AP) bolt of lightning struck a petroleum storage tank farm about 30 miles from Mobile yesterday, starting a fire that remained out of control for hours and destroyed five tanks, fire officials said. One firefighter was burned by scalding water but was treated ait1 released.

title: Citizens Assess the Assessors
description: WHEN Mount Kisco and Newcastle cooperatively embarked on the process of reassessing their taxable properties last year, they were the first two Westchester communities to walk that pitted path toward assessing property at 100 percent of its market value. mere 131 of the 991 New York State communities had preceded them in this effort dictated by state law and court decisions and invariably they had incurred the wrath of their residents. Last week the two communities looked at the results of the same revaluation effort by the respected, massappraisal firm of Coles, Layer and Trumble (C.L.T.) and had come to radically different conclusions about the quality of that reassessment.

title: Health Insurance Is Merely the Latest Example
description: WASHINGTON  Last weekend, it was national health insurance. Last month, it was standards to protect workers against exposure to cotton dust. Next month, it may be the handicapped or the minimum wage. On those issues and a dozen others, the Carter Administration has turned its back on the liberal Democratic credo and adopted instead more analytical approach, rooted in the economic fundamentals of costs and benefits.

title: Ann L. Morfogen Becomes the Bride Of G.S. Weaver 3d
description: Our Lady of Mount Cannel Roman Catholic Church in Boonton, N.J., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Ann Landis Morfogen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zachary P. Morfogen of Boonton Township and  Barnegat Light, N.J., to George Sperry Weaver 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weaver Jr. of Wheeling, W. Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hugh MurPh/.

title: Defense Is Strength, but Quarterbacks Are Uncertain
description: Coach John McVay just smiles when it is suggested that the Giants he will unveil tomorrow night are not rebuilding.

title: American Women Triumph
description: RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5  The United States won the Curtis Cup for the 16th time today by posting a 126 triumph over the team from Britain and Ireland in this pretigious international women's amateur 0olf comoetition.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees conclude their threegame series with the Baltimore Orioles at 2 P.M. today in Yankee Stadium. At 8 P.M. on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, the Yankees have single games here against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: The Risks of MailOrder Investigation
description: The House Ethics Committee has now settled for an odd way of dealing with the big, unturned stone the South Korean bribery scandal: investigation by mail order.

title: Top Chinese Journalists Coming To U.S. at Invitation of Editors
description: PEKING, Aug. 5(Reuters)  A toplevel delegation of Chinese journalists left here today for a visit to the United States at the invitation of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: DOUBLEDAY threw a large party the other day for people in the trade and for assorted literati to celebrate the completion of renovations of its flagship store on Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets. Joseph Heller, Louis Auchincloss, William F. Buckley Jr., Ethel Merman and Irwin Shaw were among those who sipped assorted beverages, nibbled flavorsome tidbits, oohed and aahed over the decor and fashioned bon mots for the press. A fascinating if silent presence at this gathering was the new elevator, whose stainless steel machinery is now visible. It moved up and down its shaft as ominously and soundlessly as those sharks that have been getting so much attention in the bookshops these days.

title: Senate Fight Planned to Oppose Noncollege Tuition Tax Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)  Two Senators, supported by a coalition of groups interested in public schools, today announced plans to wage a Senate floor fight against tuition tax credits for elementary and secondary education.

title: The No. 1 Evangelical
description: Like John F. Kennedy, President Carter had a religion ptoblem dtiring his campaign. Mit unlike Mr. Kennedy, whose religion was largely. ignored after his election, Mr. Carter's faith continued to draw steady attention, and many of his fellow bornagain Sduthern Baptists feared that the reputation of the evangelical movement would stand or fall on the spiritual image projected by the President.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Shakespeare had his own theater. So did Molire, Ibsen and Strindberg. Shaw did not produce plays, but as a theater critic for three years, he got to know the life and machineries of the working theater at next to first hand. The performed play is the third dimension the written one. Knowing what happens to your words in actors mouths, knowing what an imagined movement will when tramped out by real people, deciding what complexities will survive when they are played  all this is essential to the playiright.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 5 (AP)  Hugo Corro of Argentina, the world middleweight boxing champion, outpointed Ronnie Harris of Canton, Ohio, today in his first defense of the title he won in San Remo, Italy, last April from Rodrigo Valdes of Colombia.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Visual age. The pollsters tell us that the average American household's television set is turned on 45 hours a week. The educators tell us that, as a result, the nation is facing a formidable problem how to teach our young people, growing up amid constant whirl of visual images, how to read the printed word.

title: Our Man in Jail
description: Our colleague, M. A. Farber, sits in jail because the courts feel their prerogatives and procedures take precedence over a full airing of his urgent constitutional case. He must remain behind bars indefinitely while he and The Times are also fined heavily  because he wrote about some mysterious deaths in a New Jersey hospital a decade after they occurred and refuses to disclose to the murder trial that ensued who told him what and when. The New Jersey courts deny stay of sentence unless his confidential files are revealed to them in private  which would betray his case even if his argument later prevailed. Two Supreme Court justices refuse to secondguess their New Jersey brethren and are divided on the merits.

title: Feisty Preacher in Vanguard Of Rights Issues in Brooklyn
description: Sunday service at the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn is in its last halfhour, and the Rev. Herbert D. Daughtry is roaring to the finish of his 45minute sermon on Power, Politics and Religion.

title: Shows and Events
description: Aug. 6  Outdoor Antiques Fair, Town Hall Park and Field, Route 15, Lafayette. Lafayette is 10 miles north of Interstate 80. Admission is $1.25. The show goes on, rain or shine, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. (201)2623063.

title: 2 Years After Riots, Poles Quietly Raise Price of Meat
description: WARSAW  Poland has been quietly introducing the sharp price increases and other economic adjustments it was unable to impose two years ago.

title: QUEEN'S VISIT STIRS A DEBATE IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 5  A visit by British royalty to Canada always raises the issue of the place of the monarchy in this country, with a considerable range of opinions voiced.

title: The Hughes Legacy: Activism in Court
description: TRENTON ON Thursday, Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes will mark his 69th birthday and thereby start his final year as head of the state's highest court.

title: At Marriott, Volume Has Yielded to Profit
description: WASHINGTON  On the face of it, little has changed. The Marriott Corporation, the $1 billion food and lodging company begun as a nickel root beer stand 51 years ago, is still booming. Profits this fiscal year, which ended July 31, were up about 25 percent over last year's $36 million, on a sales increase of roughly 15 percent.

title: E.L. Strohbehn Jr. And Heather Ross Planning to Marry
description: Heather Louise Ross, deputy assistant secretary for policy, budget and administration in the Department of the Interior, and Edward Lynde Strohbehn Jr., executive director of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, both of Washington, plan to be married next month in Rouses Point, N.Y.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  Color photographs by Joe Maloney; SX70, images and collages by Lauretta Lambrecht; 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 2 to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays; through Sept. 2; Light at the Beach, Montauk Hwy.

title: Some Retirees Who Left Find You Can Come Home Again
description: The dream for many is to retire to Florida, or Arizona or California, or wherever the sun shines and icicles are found only inside the butcher's freezer.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Some Thoughts on Prayer.

title: Blood And Sand
description: There came a grim reminder last week that the Palestinians, and the sometimes violent organizations that claim to represent their interests, will not stand mute while other politicians and diplomats  including Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, now on yet another Middle East mission  decide their fate. Once again, the point was made bloodily inside Israel.

title: Notes: The Sweet Sound of Going Home
description: Going home. The words can have particularly sweet sound for people who have settled in the United States and are going back to visit the old country.

title: 5 Largest Rivers in U.S. In AboveNormal Flow
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)  The flow of water in the nation's five largest rivers marked its normal summer decline in July but remained slightly above normal, according to the Geological Survey.

title: U.S. Program to Save the Condor In California Is Called Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)  The California condor is so close to extinction that only a captive breeding program would assure its survival, according to the National Audubon Society.

title: HONE CLINIC SureFire Repair for Gutter Cracks
description: WHEN gutters split, rot out in sections, or develop bad cracks along open joints, they allow water to come posuring down the side of the house whenever it rains and can also be the cause of excess dampness entering the walls or working its way in behind exterior trim and siding.

title: POLITICS; What Do You Do When the Railroad Doesn't Work?
description: GOVERNOR CAREY sometimes engages in mental gymnastics or political obfuscation  depending upon viewpoint by speaking in riddles to those around him. Perhaps fittingly, the Governor's first hint that he was about to change the leadership of the Long Island Rail Road came in a riddle.

title: Ridgewood Sisters Star at Basketball
description: RIDGEWOOD THEY have their gold medals and their pride. But there was something more important for Mary and Anne Donovan of this Bergen County town as they pondered their participation in the recent National Sports Festival in Colorado Springs.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: JOHN L. MESSINA of Port Chester was on his feet at last Monday's hearing by the Board of Legislators, trying  with his colleagues  to sort out the cost of county takeover of Consolidated Edison's Westchester properties as the major step toward establishing county utility.

title: VANCE STARTS TOUR IN MIDEAST TO KEEP PEACE EFFORT ALIVE
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 5  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived here tonight in search of a formula to keep the Middle East neeotiations alive.

title: Dr. Tinsley R. Harrison; Heart Specialist Was 78
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 5 (AP) Dr. Tinsley Randolph Harrison, one of the founders of the Medical Center at the University of Alabama in Birmingham, died of a heart attack last night. He was 78 years old.

title: Red Sox Trounce Brewers, 81
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 (AP)  Jerry Remy and Dwight Evans lined tworun homers, and Carl Yastrzemski added a home run and a runscoring single, leading the Boston Red Sox to an 81 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today.

title: U.S. Study Finds 20% of Labeling Erroneous for Choice Beef Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  In a study of the Agriculture Department's beef grading program, the General Accounting Office has found That the prime and choice labels that consumers see on more than half the beef cuts they buy have been in error about 20 percent of the time.

title: Letter T O T H E E D I T O
description: I very much enjoyed Anne Taylor Fleming's Capote articles (The Private World of Truman Capote, July 9 and The Descent from the Heights, July 16), mostly because they helped explain this mysterious fellow who seems to have achieved fame and fortune for no obvious reason. However, he does seem interesting and, of course, rather tragic.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Pete Rose, whose hitting streak was stopped at 44 games by Larry McWilliams and Gene Garber of the Atlanta Braves: Garber was pitching like it was the seventh game of the World Series. He had a 164 lead. I had any guts, I'd have bunted that last changeup [on which he struck out]. I hope I see him again tomorrow in a onerun game.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Acoin made for the Land of the Beaver (or Castorland), in upper New York State, was a feature of the recent Breen III auction put on by the Pine Tree Auction Galleries at LaGuardia Airport in June. Castorland was a French colony near Carthage, not far from the present Watertown, N.Y. It was in existence in 1796 when France was still in a ferment.

title: Obscenity and the Law of the State
description: IN approving its 212page revision of New Jersey's Penal Code, the State Legislature came across a knotty problem and, in a typical response to such situations, passed it on to someone else.

title: City Residency Law Stirs Concern
description: The city's new residency law, which after it goes into effect on Nov. 1 will require all new municipal employees to live in the city and all current employees living in the city at that time to remain resident or forfeit their jobs, has caused nervous concern among a great number of the workers.

title: New York City's Welfare Rolls, at 907,126, the Lowest Since June 1969
description: New York City's welfare rolls have fallen to their lowest level since June 1969, with 907,126 recipients as of last June, Dr. Blanche Bernstein, the city's Human Resources Administrator, announced yesterday.

title: Gambino'sBeir As Crime Chief Yet to Emerge
description: Two years after the death of Carlo Gambino, reputedly the most powerful organizedcrime figure in the country, law enforcement officials say that no certain successor has emerged and that Carmine Galante, the head of the Bonanno crime family, had sought to assume the role but failed.

title: Justice Dept. and Private Group Press Prison Reform Standards
description: The Department of Justice and the American Correctional Association have drafted tough and specific new standards for the nation's prisons in an effort to bring about better living, working and administrative conditions for prisoners in Federal, state and local institutions.

title: Women's Sports Are Doing Just Fine
description: For a while, I have been wondering the reference to the game of The Boys of Summer would be changed to the Boys and Girls of Summer. Or, if that sounds too much like one of those 1960's Beach Party movies, maybe the phrase would become Summerpersons.

title: Events Today
description: Central Park South Art Exhibit: Watercolors, oils, sculptures, carvings, photographs and prints for sale; 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; south wall of Central Park, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas along 59th Street.

title: Sports Today
description: Texas 200 for Indytype cars. (Television Channel 2, 4 P.M.)

title: The Republican Road Is Now a TwoLane Street
description: WASHINGTON  From the Capitol to Kansas, two Republican Parties were on display last week, almost as different from each other as from the Democrats. In Washington, cleancut Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois, the hope of the New Right, announced for the Presidency, pledging a free people liberated from excessive government. In Toneka, bearded Gov. Robert F. Bennett, who said he deserved reelection because he kept taxes down and expanded state aid, won the primary after preaching nothing more ideological than Jefferson on that government is best that governs least.

title: Strategy tfor Those Dining Out Alone
description: The prospect of dining out alone nightly in foreign restaurants has probably deterred the departure of more incipient single travelers to Europe than any other contingency. While it is not true that 15 years of Freudian analysis are needed before one can dine out singly with a reasonable sense of well being, the background of a very good military school plus the fortification of a certain amount of alcohol are viable substitutes.

title: Herat and Labor
description: JERUSALEMThe differences between the Labor Party and the Herut Party involve both domestic and foreign affairs. World opinion is mainly concerned with our debate on international issues. Israel is an authentically democratic country and its foreign policy is decided by the majority. We, in the Labor Party, are for the time being out of power. Yet, on some basic issues there is something like a national consensus. Israelis are divided on strategy and method, not on the aim of peace itself. Both coalitions, that of the Government and that of the opposition, reject the creation of a separate Palestinian state between Jordan and Israel. We know that it would be militant, chronically hostile and dangerous to the security and peace of Jordan and Israel alike. Such a state would also bring a strong Russian influence into the heart of our land, at the gates of Jerusalem itself.

title: Teachers and How to Evaluate Them
description: TEACHERS have a responsibility to provide classroom experiences that help students learn. Teachers should be evaluated so that if there are areas fm improvement, constructive criticisrr can be given to make that teacher more effective.

title: DINING OUT
description: FREEHOLD has everything American going for it. There is the Freehold Raceway, historic Monmouth Battleground, a museum Revolutionary relics, a main street of Colonial and Victorian houses and churches and a magnificent GreekRevival fire station. FrPphnld hag everything except a good American restaurant.

title: An Irish Thing to Do
description: JEAN KERR is one of the first women to hitch herself up to a typewriter and spin the straw of her not completely suburban existence into publishing gold. She is now, as she was back when her children were eating the daisies, an intelligent, irreverent, articulate writer, and her latest book is exactly what the public has come to expect of her. Exactly.

title: Late Bloomer
description: COMING upon this novel reminds me of leafing through a collection of wellmade daguerreotypes or yellowing photographs: faded, posed, framed in isolation from one another; portraying faces of loss, amusement; showing formal family scenes and bighipped carriage horses, rutted roads with barefoot children and booted passersby, sweatshiny workers in plowed fields, gowned women wearing necklaces.

title: 8 Travelers on Horseback Retrace the Santa Fe Trail
description: SANTA FE, N.M. Aug. 5  Eight tired and drymouthed riders arrived at the Santa Fe plaza today, capping a 900mile trek on horseback along the historic Santa Fe Trail.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Thank you for the July 9 article Stony Brook's Thrust Into the Arts. When the doors to Phase II of the fine arts complex opened (although they haven't yet officially), we all breathed a sigh of Thank heaven we don't have to play in the administration building's lobby anymore. It is refreshing to feel the university's support for us.

title: West Point Seeks to Eliminate Moral Corruption in Army Enlistees
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  A struggle to eliminate what many senior officers believe to be a moral rot that has infected the Army since the Vietnam War is to begin here in the classrooms of the United States Military Academy.

title: INTERVIEW
description: LONG VALLEY WITH dancers under contract for the first time in its 20year history, the New Jersey Ballet has come of age, Carolyn Clark, the artistic director of the company, said.

title: Is the Frisbee a Dog's Best Friend?; The New York Times/Ernie Hearion
description: WHITE PLAINS FRISBEE, in a new, rugged canine version sweeping the nation, is a sport that lets the good old American mongrel meet the elite of dogdom on common ground. uwners of snow champions joined hundreds of other spectators at Gedney Field to cheer on Merlin, a big, black mixture of many breeds, and 32 other contestants in the K9 Frisbee CatchandFetch City, County and State Contest. Mixed breeds accounted for about 60 percent of the dogs participating.

title: Astor Cup Sail to Arete
description: MARION, Mass., Aug. 5 The act of sailing for the Astor Cup, the concluding prestigious event of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise, was like Dlavine a slot machine in Buzzards Bay today. There was so little wind and came from so many different and unaccountable directions that finding the right way to move was the equivalent of shoving coins in the machine and pulling the handle.

title: Debt Ceiling Now $798 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)  President Carter has signed a Congressional resolution increasing the public debt ceiling to $798 billion, the White House announced today. The resolution will permit the Federal Government to avoid a crisis of not meeting payrolls and halting the sale of savings bonds.

title: Seoul President Pledges All Possible Cooperation
description: SEOUL, Aug 5 (Reuters)  President Park ChungHee said today that South Korea had provided all possible cooperation concerning the testimony of a former Korean Ambassador to Washington in the Korean bribery scandal.

title: Laurie Hallenbeck Bride of John Rose
description: Laurie Lindsay Hallenbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leo Hallenbeck of North Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to John Weston Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hodgins Rose of Darien, Conn. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony in the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. The bride's uncle, the Rev. Rodney Scoville, a Methodist minister of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., assisted.

title: ART VIEW
description: Camille Pissarro was one of the finest human beings who ever touched a brush. He never said an evil word. He never harbored an evil thought. Nothing was too much trouble for him when it came to helping a fellow artist. He worked till he dropped. He had his full share private misfortune and bore it in exemplary style. He was very well read, and he put his reading to good use. His letters were a contribution to literature, though he would have been the last person to say so.

title: JazzFunk Band Finds a Place in the Sun
description: WHEN this guy at one of the big clubs out here showed us where our makeup man would work, we just broke out laughing, said Dave Patrick, guitarist for Solar, one of the most talkedabout young bands now working the East End. As Mr. Patrick tells it, barely containing his glee and amazement, the club spokesman didn't think it was funny. You know what he said? Mr. Patrick asked incredulously. All the bands have makeup men.

title: Santa Barbara Show Is a Family Favorite
description: Families arrived in close to 3,000 motor homes. About 15,000 people involved with the event were on hand. Some 25,000 spectators came through the gates. Entries totaled 4,650. The magnet was Santa Barbara, the biggest dog show in the United States, and the star was Mary Hartman, a Doberman pinscher.

title: Letters: Transit Chief Describes The New Express Runs to J.F.K.
description: To the Editor: Bernard L. Albert of Scarsdale is absolutely correct in his letter to the editor; (Travel Section, July 9) in calling for mass transit service to and from John F. Kennedy Airport.

title: Federal Aide Tours Contaminated Niagara Site to Assess Factors for Aid
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 5  William H. Wilcox, head of the Federal Disaster Assistance Administration, inspected the chemically contaminated old Love Canal site today at the request of President Carter and said he did not yet know whether he would recommend that the neighborhood be declared a disaster ???

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: Downstairs at the International Center for Photography (1130 Fifth Ave., at 94th St.), the main gallery is filled with grand and glorious photographs of Western scenery, most of them taken since 1950 by such photographers as Minor White and Paul Canoninro as well as by others less familiar. This is the first part of exhibition entitled The Great West: Real / Ideal (through Sept. 3), and the tone is set by two of Ansel Adams's heroic vistas of spectacular mountain scenery with dramatic lighting and atmospheric effects.

title: Sara Brooke Glenn, Law Student, Wed To D.K. Roberts
description: The marriage of Sara Brooke Glenn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Francis Glenn of Durham, N.C., to Douglas Kent Roberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Otto Roberts of Telford, Pa., took place yesterday in the Duke University Chapel in Durham. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James Cleland and the Rev. Albert Nelius.

title: U.S. Open Site Faces Race Against. Time
description: Three weeks before the first balls will be struck in the United States Open tennis championships, a race against time is under way to complete the new facility at Flushing MeadowCorona Park.

title: Gangway, the Threshers Are coming
description: They were true folk heroes of the turn of the century  the threshermen who came calling at America's farms at dawn. Moving across rich earth, transforming every wheatfield they traversed, the threshermen rode majestically in astride chuffing steam engines that literally made the harvest happen. And they brought an energy and an excuse for teamwork that made their visits seem like Christmas, Thanksgiving and July 4th rolled into one.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Today  Winners Circle, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle Island, L.I. Regular, green, special, amateurowner and maiden working hunter; intermediate and special jumpers, pleasure horses, adult horsemanship. 8:30 A.M.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BETHPAGE IT'S been over two months since Andy Galgano saw the red glow along the wall, since he shouted to his two buddies to get out, since he dove through the open window, since the buildine ienited behind him.

title: Accused Briton Does Not Plan to Quit Parliament
description: LONDON, Aug. 5 (ReuTers)  Jeremy Thorpe, the former Liberal Party leader, will not resign from Parliament despite charges that he plotted to kill a former male model who has said they once had homosexual relationship, the executive body of his local oartv announced tonight.

title: Karen Scholz Plans A September Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. John J. Scholz Jr. of Lincoln, Neb., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Joyce Scholz, to Robert Deland Bachrach, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Fabian Bachrach Jr. of West Newton, Mass. The wedding is planned for Sept. 16 in the Unitarian Church in Lincoln.

title: Making Of the Historian
description: THEODORE H. WHITE'S autobiography seems to me by far his finest, most affecting work. His Thunder Out of China, written with Annalee Jacoby and published in 1946.

title: Crime Leaders as Cited by F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says its investigation of organized crime has enabled it to identify mob leaders in various cities outside New York City.

title: Mobile Unit for Aged To Visit 5 Sections
description: THE Senior Mobile Unit of the County Office on Aging will provide services this month to elderly residents of Cross River, Mamaroneck, Somers, White Plains and Yonkers. services include taking applications for senior citizen discount cards

title: YESHIVA UNIVERSITY WINS UNION DISPUTE
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Yeshiva University does not have to bargain with a faculty union because the faculty members can be considered managerial personnel.

title: Miss Solomon Becomes Bride
description: Laurie I. Solomon and John Michael Pollock, were married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Andrew.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A fairly wide band of clouds extends all the way from Nova Scotia to the South Atlantic States, then westward to Arkansas. Showers and thunderstorms are spread out along this frontal zone with cooler air to then north and warm, muggy air to the south. Individual strong thunderstorm clouds can be seen over the Gulf of Mexico and across the Bahamas and Florida. Light showers are moving into the northern Rockies.

title: A.B.A. PresidentElect Warns on Unemployment of Young Lawyers
description: The incoming president of the AmeriCan Bar Association warned yesterday that unemployment and underemployment among young lawyers is a serious problem.

title: Shakespeare's Shrew With No Apologies
description: M eryl Streep and Raul Julia are rehearsing The Taming of the Shrew seated on two studio chairs in a rehearsal room at Joseph Papp's Public Theater. Act II, Scene 1, when Kate and Petruchio meet and clash for the first time. Miss Streen has Kate's skirts hiked un  revealing two red kneepads she's wearing for protection  and the PuertoRican born Mr. Julia is blowing away Petruchio's lines like so many dandelion seeds. She swings as sweetly as the nightingale, he says. Then stops.

title: INVESTING
description: Collectors come in two basic varieties, passive and active. A passive collector typically may simply keep family heirlooms or items accumulated over the years. Active collectors acquire tangibles they. enjoy and/or hope to turn into a profit some day.

title: Marathoners, Some Believe, Are Born Rather Than Made
description: This week, the world is watching with fascination and admiration as Diana Nyad prepares for an attempt to set record for the longest openwater free swim ever: from Cuba to Florida. Speed is of only secondary interest in this effort. Miss Nyad's main problem is how to keep her muscles moving, propelling her 103 miles across the Gulf Stream, for an estimated two and a half days. If she succeeds, hers will be the greatest sports endurance feat ever, by a man or a woman.

title: SHIPPING/MAILS
description: Arriving Today, Aug. 6

title: Michigan's Primary on Tuesday Rich in Candidates, if Not Issues
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5  Michigan voters are approaching the end of a primary campaign that has been flush with candidates and money but not, in the minds of most observers. with issues.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sherwood Munson Jr. of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Munson's daughter, Sharon Hale Harts, to Myron A. Wick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wick Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Japan Now Deb.ates Arms Issues That Have Been Taboo Since 45
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5  For the first time since 1995 a defense debate is in progress in Japan that deals with some of the fundamental taboos of the postWorld War II period selling arms abroad, working into a new role as a partner of the West in defense by rearmament and upgrading the standing of the military.

title: Jewish Identity Crisis Reexamined
description: IWELCOME with some reservations Randy Medoff's assessment [Westchester Weekly, July 2] of the Jewish identity crisis among American Jewish youth, especially in Westchester. It is abundantly clear Mat American Judaism is faced with urgent challenges. The plunging birthrate and galloping intermarriages, accompanied by malaise and apathy among many Jewish youths, are taking a mounting toll and sapping the vitality of the Jewish community.

Adorer grandfather of Jerold, Andrew, Ga ry, Pamela, Leigh and Jill. Service BoulevardPark West, Sunda, August 6, 12:30 P.M.. 115 West Street.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: The New Jersey Weekly of June 18 contained an article on bikeways in the state. The article emphasized the public's dwindling enthusiasm in acquiring available Federal funds for new bike paths.

title: Jacobs Wins Award
description: Franklin Jacobs, 20yearold sophomore from Fa irleigh Dickinson University who set a world indoor highjump record at 7 feet 7 inches, has been named winner of the Tanqueray Achievement Award for excellence in amateur sports.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Federal Government's response to the 1976 swine flu epidemic, which never materialized, has left some side effects. Seventyfive New Jerseyans or their survivors have filed suits asking for $50.9 million in damages from adverse reactions to the vaccine that was ordered by the Government and used in inoculating millions of Americans against the disease.

title: Oil Cleanup Efforts May Reopen Beaches in 3 Days
description: An oil spill from a barge that sank off the Rockaway Peninsula last Monday kept five Atlantic beaches in Brooklyn and Queens closed again yesterday, but sandandsea cleanup efforts, foul weather and favorable winds eased the danger and raised the possibility that at least some of the beaches might be re opened soon.

title: Pentagon Plans 6Month Review Of Study on Closing of 9 Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)  The Pentagon says it will take at least six months to review and analyze a study that proposes possible closing of nine military supply centers in seven states.

title: So You Thought Acting. In Commercials Was a Breeze
description: Television commercial acting may not be the most challenging of the performing arts, but neither is it quite as easy as it may look.

title: Debunking Myths About Getting Old
description: IN ARGUING for mandatory retirement in his article Is Retirement a Right of Passage? [July 16], Dr. Lewis Hyde engages in a very pernicious form of reasoning. His attitude about the elderly and their capabilities and needs can only be described as outright prejudice. In fact, Dr. Hyde seems to have a very advanced case of ageism.

title: Strategic Air Command Chief Endorses MX Missile
description: Gen. Richard H. Ellis, chief of the Strategic Air Command, has recommended to Secretary of Defense Harold Brown that fullscale development of the mobile MX missile begin this fall.

description: DETROIT  I think they have to bite the bullet or there's going to be a slow bloodletting.

title: Television This Week
description: 11:30 A.M. (2) FACE THE NATION. Attorney General Griffin B. Bell is the scheduled guest.

title: The U.S. and Rhodesia
description: LONDONAmerica's friends in Europe and Africa view with considerable apprehension the possibility of Congress's voting to end economic sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: Metropolitan
description: Brenda Feigen Fasteau, a Democratic candidate in Manhattan for the State Senate, has won a commitment from the city's Board of Elections to put her full name on the ballot in the coming election.

title: ART
description: MORRISTOWN WHY is printmaking attracting so many artists these days? Painters who usually express themselves in oils or acrylics are trying their talents in woodcuts, etchings, intaglios and other forms of prints, and sculptors who usually mold shapes out of bronze, marble, steel, plastics and other materials are doing the same thing. And then there are the pure printmakers, those who make nothing but prints.

title: East Side Drive Captures Jumper Title at Middletown
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 5 East Side Drive, the defending national highpoint champion in the division, won the amateurowner jumper championship today at the closing session of the weeklong Orange County horse show.

description: As if the plethora of air fares was not enough to shake the hardiest traveler, ponder the morass of airline rules that govern the carrying of baggage.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD WHILE the Republicans were basking in their newfound unity a week ago at the Bushnell Memorial Hall. the Democratic State Central Committee and a lot of spectators crowded into the party headquarters on Asylum Street for another selection process that seemed to underscore the Democratic differences.

description: LONGYEARBYEN, Spitsbergen Few inhabited places in the world are more remote and forlorn than this mountainous 24,000squaremile archipelago in the Arctic Ocean.

description: CROTONONHUDSON  Anything Goes, presented by Croton Shakespeare Festival. Today at 2 P.M. $3; students and the elderly $2. CrotonHarmon High School, Old Post Rd. South, off Rte. 129. 2713840 or 2718712..

title: STAMPS
description: The monumental structures of Europe that the Europeans esteem and cherish, are depicted on this year's omnibus Europa issue put out by most of the na tions in the Conference of European Postal and Telecommunications Administrations (CEPT). Of the 26 postal administrations, 29 have issued stamps for the common theme monuments predominantly translated into buildings and sites rather than statues and memorials.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: JACQUES FOURNIER, Bishop of Pamiers in the south of France in the early 14th century (and later Pope Benedict XII) was a grand and skillful inquisitor. He was determined to extirpate the last traces of the Albigensian heresy from the Pyreneean village of Montaillou, where it was gasping its last after centuries of Catholic persecution elsewhere France and Italy. A wily interviewer, Fournier wormed extremely full confessions out of Montaillou's shepherds and smallholders, wives and maids. Furthermore, the Bishop kept such good records that today, when the precise tenets of the Albigensian heresy are in doubt, a modern historian has been able to extract an astonishingly complete picture of daily life and culture in the Montaillou of 1320 from Fournier's transcript..

title: G.A.O. Cites Training of Officials in 77 Fire Fatal to 5 in.Dantiry
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 5 (AP)  The Federal General Accounting Office has found that inadequately trained staff at the Danbury Correctional Institution contributed to the July7, 1977, fire that killed five inmates and injured. 86 other persons.

title: FILM VIEW
description: With the possible exception of Mark Twain, there have been very few firstrate comic writers who have been as much appreciated in their own day as they have been later. Only recently have the early comic novels of Evelyn Waugh been recognized as the works of art they are, while Brideshead Revisited, originally hailed as being far more serious than Decline and Fall, Vile Bodies and A Handful of Dust, now seems comparatively fat, overwrought if not

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: WHAT happens to the white elephant houses, those with a couple of dozen toorns, servants quarters, large acreage, and huge fuel and tax bills? Familieg still buy them, according to real estate brokers, and some are sold as weekend houses for families who live in the city.

title: A MOTION TO DISMISS FORD SUIT IS DENIED
description: A motion to dismiss a stockholders suit charging Henry Ford 2d and 19 other officers of the Ford Motor Company with conspiracy to misuse company funds was denied Friday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WHEN the extraterrestrials decide to get touch with us, as the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind so vividly demonstrated, they will not have to tap into the President's red phone. Nor will they need to send out for a Billy Graham or a Muhammad All td'act as spiritual intermediary. No, they will simply transmit into the ether the notes of an ordinary diatonic chord, one only slightly more complex than the door chimes that signal the arrival of the Avon Lady, and we will all snap immediately to attention. You snicker at this simplehearted conceit, but the myth of a universally understood musical language is deeply rooted and has always struck a sympathetic chord in popular fancy. Politicians called upon to address international gatherings invoke this clich as if Dr. Pavlov had rung their bell. Their audiences accept it implicitly, too, even though a dozen radically different musical cultures may be represented among the listeners. A few jaded musicians and musicologists may smile, but ancient cliches do not wither away under the disdain such as they.

title: GARDENING
description: WEDNESDAY will be Plant Science Day at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in Hamden. The annual open house is popular with local gardeners and farmers.

title: To Maintain Our Values Is a Necessary Struggle
description: ARECENT inaccurate and misleading assessment of Jewish life in Westchester County that appeared in The Westchester Weekly opinion page cannot simply be allowed to stand.

title: William Amory Parker; Organized Mutual Fund
description: NORTH EASTON, Mass., Aug. 5 (AP)  William Amory Parker, who organized Incorporated Investors as the second mutual fund in the country, died yesterday at his home after a twomonth illness. He was 85 years old.

title: The Region
description: Blacks and other minorities make up 42 percent of the population of Bridgeport, Conn., yet in 1975 the 450member Fire Department had only one hlaCk member. This seemed odd to almost everyone, so that year the city gave a new written test that was supposed to eliminate any builtin white cultural advantage. Eightyfour black and Hispanic applicants took the test; 84 failed.

title: For the Candidates, the Curtain Is Rising on Act
description: WITH their nominating conventions now concluded, Connecticut's political parties are starting into bruising election campaign with the Democrats holding the advantages of incumbency but facing a divisive primary and the Republicans outwardly united and confident.

title: INTERVIEW
description: VALHALLA TWO committees of the County Board of Legislators were asked by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello last week to give more authority to Bernard M. Weinstein than any of his predecessors had enjoyed to administer Grasslands Hospital or its new and expensive replacement, the Westchester Medical Center.

title: Claudia Weill: From Shoestring to Studio
description: G irlfriends, by Claudia Weill, opens this Friday with a number of unprecedented achievements already to its credit.

title: ChinaVietnam Feud: Neighbors Are Puzzled but Don't Predict War
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 5  The great falling out between China and Vietnam has given more delight than concern to Southeast Asian nations fearful of the two major Communist powers in this region, but those nations respect the customs of diplomacy and do not let their pleasure show.

title: ANTIQUES Legacy of the Dutch
description: THE cupboard or kas was probably the most impressive and important piece of furniture in a 17thcentury Dutch home. Not surprisingly, the kas is also one of the most distinctive furniture forms associated with Dutchsettled western Long Island.

title: Food
description: There is an argument to the effect that the most interesting dishes to work with in any cuisine are those whose character can be changed at will, the changes limited only by imagination and taste. One of the great foods summer feasting fits that definition precisely  cold stuffed eggs. The ings are literally without end. Cold cubed chicken. ham, turkey, veal, and poached fish can be used, garnished with anchovies, olives, pimentos and other kindred edibles. The sweet herbs are virtuous: parsley. chives. tarragon, chervil, even rosemary. The egg yolks. sieved or blended, are generally bound with mayonnaise and/or butter. Add a bit of salt and pepper and your creativity can take it from there. Here are four of the various fillings.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The development of testtube babies can be compared to the perfecting of wing transplants so that pigs might fly: an impressive academic exercise which could lead to useful knowledge, but which in itself can only be called unnecessary. We could regard it with the detached admiration considered appropriate in every scientific advance (even one whose value is not immediately apparent) were not its implications so malevolent.

title: Pretty Boy
description: THE courthouse in Spiefidora, Tex., is an antique redbrick building with gables and turrets and gothic windows and a fourfaced clock, but all this is encased in a jerrybuilt modern coverup three concrete blocks that rise in tiers like a blank wedding cake. And Timothy John Coidridge, a onetime Splendora boy of legendary beauty who vanished without a byyourleave some 15 years earlier, is long last returning to Splendora, but he's returning as Miss Jessica Gatewood, a refined librarian of 33 who dresses in late Victorian style and wears her hair in Gibson Girl topknot.

title: Design
description: I love living in hotels, says Paloma Picasso. We are sitting in the drawing room of her apartment near the Seine. The building is sturdy 1900 bourgeois  high ceilings, delicate wall moldings, arched windows. arched mirrors over carved marble fireplaces, shiny wood floors, lots of windows and lots of light.

title: CAMERA
description: Commuters walking in and out of Grand Central Terminal were able to view spectacular color transparency of an African scene. This breathtaking photograph spanned most of the width of the station (a distance of more than 60 feet) and was made from a single color slide measuring a little less than an inch by an inch and a half! It was as much a tribute to the photographer Ernest Haas, as it was to the wizardry of Kodak's scientific team and the quality of the Leica camera and lens that recorded it.

title: Thoughts On Tenis, Success And Goals
description: While my recent heel injury has kept me on the New York Apples bench, I have had a lot of time to think. What I have been thinking about concerns World Team Tennis  how it is coming down to the end of its fifth season and how it is seems to be more accepted than ever.

title: GOVERNMENT SPENDS $1 BILLION ON IMAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)  The Federal Government is spending at least $1 billion a year to inform and sell the American people on its programs.

title: Julius Rudel Conducts Schubert And Haydn for Mostly Mozart
description: Although there were two soloists in the Mostly Mozart concert given at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, Julius Rudel was easily the star of the evening. Ordinarily, Mr. Rudel does his conducting across Lincoln Center Plaza at the New York State Theater: wnere ne is general airector of tne New York City Opera. There, year in and year out for decades now, he has consistently demonstrated efficiency, reliability and musicality in an extraordinarily broad range of operatic literature.

title: Kash Minbar Repeats American Trot Victory
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 5  Kash Minbar will get a second crack at winning the $200,000 Roosevelt International next Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway. The 6yearold stallion won the $50,000 American Trotting Championship for the second straight year tonight. He was clocked in 1:59 1/5 for the mile.

title: Business Panel Assails Koch on Use of Budget Surplus
description: The Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday that Mayor Koch's recent settlement with the municipal labor unions was based on financial gimmicks and would wind up costing the city much more than it could afford.

title: Raw Memories of Watery Deaths Haunt Survivors of Floods in Texas
description: COMFORT, Tex., Aug 5  The torrent was gone and the terror with it, going almost as rapidly as it had come, leaving behind a fresh, raw memory of watery death in the minds of Bill Smith and Arthur Burow as they sweated in bright sunshine to get the sewer system of their ravaged village working again.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS A First Play Examines Old Nazis and Neighbors
description: A middleagedman is sitting in a chair in a quaint suburban household, not unlike many on the Island. His fingers gently run over a string of rosary beads, but his mind is reflecting on the time when he was a Nazi SS trooper, responsible for the death of hundreds of men, women and children.

title: FOOD A Gatherable Feast on Fire; SASSAFRAS (OR CINNAMON) FLAVORED FLAN; SEA ROCKET (OR ARUGULA) VINAIGRETTE; Gathering greens
description: To most people, Fire Island is collection of summer playgrounds for bare feet reached by ferry boat, but to Felipe RojasLombardi it is also a limitless resource of edibles, waiting to be gathered and enjoyed.

title: Quanta Made Clear
description: JEREMY BERNSTEIN has one invaluable attribute for a science writer. It is not that he is professor of physics (at the Stevens Institute Technology), although that must be a considerable help; nor that he writes primarily for The New Yorker, although that must be a pleasure. It is that he able to write clearly, transparently, about subjects as opaque as quantum theory and molecular biology. Mr. Bernstein's prose disappears and the content shines through.

title: Miss McIntyre, Fellow Lawyer Have Nuptials
description: Virginia McIntyre, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randall P. McIntyre of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Mitchell Stevens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens of Warwick, R.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: I'm going to jail for what I believe to be the public interest, for what I believe to be the interest of my profession, M. A. Farber, a reporter for The New York Times, said last Friday just before entering a Hackensack, N.J., jail for a stay of uncertain length.

title: Topics
description: It was not an impossible dream, just improbable: That was Floyd McKissick's enterprise in black capitalism to build a new town called Soul City in Warren County, N.C. Only 50 families now live in Soul City, so there is much to be done before the dream takes shape. That it is a realizable dream, however, was evident last week at the dedication of a $12million regional water system, developed by the city's managers and neighboring communities, and financed by local, state and Federal funds. About 80,000 residents of Warren, Vance and Granville Counties will draw about ten million gallons of water a day from the system. Controlled electronically and backed up for emergencies by a dieselpowered generator, the system is what Mr. McKissick describes as the part of our infrastructure essential for growth and development.

title: Touring neighboring Cold Spring in Putnam County Page 9
description: CONSIDERING its distinguished neighbors, Cold Spring, in the southwest corner of Putnam County, should be household word. It not only looks across a splendid stretch of Hudson onto the West Point Military Academy and Storm King Mountain, but also borders on firstrate hiking trails, is two miles from the Boscobel restoration, and is the site of the highly regarded Plumbush restaurant. But though it seems to slumber, a bypassed river town on a bygone cold spring, it stirs with signs of a new awakening.

title: The Island's Gains in Albany
description: F OR the State Legislature, the endless summer continues. This Tuesday, legislators are scheduled to trek back to Albany in yet another effort to finish this year's business. It will be their second try. Last month, they were called into special session by Governor Carey and passed, among other things, a tough anticrime package. This week, they'll be taking up everything else.

title: MUSIC
description: CONCERT halls are all very nice for the regular season, but come summer many of us prefer to imbibe our music in the open air, with moonlight overhead, and maybe a duck or two paddling around the pond.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MARTIN GIUFFRE spent 25 years as a patient at the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital in Oakdale and five more years in an adult home. But today he has a job in a sheltered workshop and lives in a halfway house on the grounds of the hospital.

title: There's More Surveillance Than Meets the Eye at the Canada Border
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 5 (AP)  On back roads one can drive across the border from Canada to the United States without seeing more than a sign, a narrow slash through the woods and small concrete markers in pastures.

description: A newgeneration of gadflies has hatched since the hearings on Lilco's Shoreham nuclear plant ended in 1973. This new generation or gaailies seems to suffer from the same generation gap as all species. They either refuse to or do not know how to learn from the mistakes of their elders and are hellbent on repeating those errors themselves.

title: HOUSE UNIT ASSAILS SAFETY COMMISSION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  Congressional investigators charged today that the Consumer Product Safety Commis. sion had failed to protect the public against chronic hazards, such as cancercausing clothing, that continue to jeopardize the health of millions of American

title: An Excursion Beyond Paris:
description: For the visitor with two days to spend, the eastern route from Paris to Champagne has a bit of everything that France is noted for  vineyards, chateaus, ancient cathedrals and churches, wonderful restaurants and hotels, pastoral views and battlefields  all available within a circuit of about 200 miles.

title: 4 Teenagers Die as Car Crashes On West Point Army Reservation
description: Three teenage children of staff and faculty members at the United States Military Academy at West Point and a visiting German high school student were killed Friday night when their car struck a tree on the Academy grounds, an Army spokesman said.

title: PEOPLE
description: John Z. DeLorean abruptly canceled plans last week to build an automobile assembly plant in Puerto Rico, deciding instead to build the $125 million sports car plant in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Only week before Mr. Delorean had received $40 million in Federal Loan guarantees from the United States Government for the Puerto Rican plant.

title: SHOP TALK Sea Air on Main St.
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH WESTHAMPTONBEACH is the best place to shop in the Hamptons. The village has a bustling cosmopolitan atmosphere, but is still decidedly seashore; you can feel the ocean air along Main Street. There is ample parking.

title: Priscilla A. Watkins Is Betrothed

title: New Hand at Helm of Voters League
description: MAMARONECK LIKE many other suburban women, Ruth Hinerfeld is active in volunteer work. Unlike the others, Mrs. Hinerfeld cornmutes to w asnington eacn week where she heads a 131,000member national organization whose role is to influence public policy on issues such as the urban crisis and fiscal solutions, nuclear energy and  appropriately enough for an organization that began in 1920 as an outgrowth of the women's suffrage movement  ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution.

description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP)  London, once the world's largest city, has dropped to below seven million inhabitants. The Office of Population Censuses and Surveys said the 000ulation estimate for mid1977 was b,9IU,IUU. lne popuiation peakea in 1939 at 8.6 million and dwindled as slums were cleared and residents moved to new statesubsidized towns. The Guinness Book of World Records says Tokyo is the world's most populous city, with 8,586,900 residents in 1976.

title: Dibbs Tops Orantes

title: WHAT WENT WRONG?
description: JERUSALEM. It is eight months since President Anwar elSadat of Egypt visited Jerusalem, opening a new phase in what passes for history, but so far not for peace, in the Middle East. Recently, Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Davan.

title: DoItYourself Yacht Club At Full Sail on Sprite Island
description: HE ad in the paper was intriguing enough: Wanted: A few good people to join Sprite Island Yacht Club. Contact Lou Diamond, Vice Commodore. What was downright fascinating were tne last four words: Lou Diamond, Vice Commodore.

title: 41 Drown in Quebec When a Bus Calving Infirm Runs Into Lake
description: EASTMAN, Quebec, Aug. 5  A bus carrying mentally and physically handicapped people went out of control on hill, shot off a roadway and plunged into lake last night, drowning 41 persons, who screamed for help as the bus floated several minutes before sinkine.

title: Exclusionary Zoning In Suburban Connecticut: Old Fight, New Arena

title: SENATE TO CONSIDER PRAYER IN SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  Prayer in public schools, an issue Congress thought was past, will be back in the Senate Monday, and eight major religious groups went to work this week to defeat Senator Jesse Helms's efforts to reinstate the practice.

title: Jazz Dances by Pepsi Bethel Wind Up the Clark Festival
description: Pepsi Bethel called the company he brought to the City University Graduate Center Mall Friday night the Authentic Jazz Dance Theater. That name hinted at Mr. Bethel's interest in the origins of jazz dancing and of all the other styles and modes that have contributed to American popular dance.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Palestine Liberation Organization is in the throes of significant changes to deal with increasing pressure from Israel, disunity in its own ranks and its exclusion from negotiations on a Middle East settlement.

title: Headliners
description: Sex and crime are a volatile combination, especially in politics. For years, Jeremy Thorpe, former leader of Britain's Liberal Party, has been dogged by allegations that he had a homosexual relationship with Norman Scott, a onetime male model. The second ingredient for a firstrate political scandal was added last week: Mr. Thorpe and three political friends were charged with conspiring to murder Mr. Scott, a crime for which Mr. Thorpe could be sentenced to life imprisonment. The homosexual insinuations, which he has consistently denied, forced Mr. Thorpe to resign the Liberal leadership in May 1976, but he held on to a seat in Parliament and was widely respected for his statesmanship. A witty speaker with a gift for mimickry, he was sometimes called the last of the Edwardians because of his manner but also for his attire that often included a homburg, waistcoat and heavy watch chain. Now his parliamentary career, and the Liberal Party's dwindling fortunes along with it, are greater jeopardy.

title: Kathryn Sass Wed To James L.S. Pool
description: Kathryn Lucinda Sass, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Sass of Sharon, Pa., was married there yesterday to James Lawrence Stuart Pool, son of Mrs. Philip M. Brett Jr. of New York and the late H. Lawrence Pool. The Rev. Milo Gerberding, pastor of Christ Lutheran Church in Sharon, performed the ceremony at the Sass home.

title: The Water's Getting Better, The Hard Part Lies Ahead
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will hold sessions in New. York City this week to brief businessmen and government officials on soontobeissued regulations forbidding industries to dump harmful untreated waste into municipal sewer systems. The regulations are evidence of the increasingly sophisticated battle agaiiiSt water pollution, and they are particularly applicable to the industrialized region around New YorkTRENTON  For years, many of New Jersey's chemical companies. and other manufacturers have been complaining that they faced stiffer waterpollution controls than their competitors in other states. For years, there has been plenty of evidence that some New Jersey industries casually dumped pollutants into rivers and sewer lines.

title: HardDriving Carey Hails, And Defends, Record
description: All the Governor's men naa tnougnt My were done for the day. That was what the, day's official schedule had said, but as it turned out, the official schedule meant no more than the day's official speeches, which had not been delivered. And so they found themselves sitting at a corner gasoline station somewhere in Nassau County, in weather wiltingly warm, being informed that after Belmont Race Track, Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center and a reception in Garden City, Mr. Carey had decided to move on at 7 P.M. on a Friday night to an unscheduled stop at an Italian feast in Glen Cove.

title: Bridge:
description: For several years Past, two Chicago experts, Bob Price and Joyce Williams, have been the dominant force in the tournaments of. the American Bridge Association. Price is the top masterpoint winner and Miss Williams similarly beads the women's division, and is third overall.

description: Governor Carey and Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak brought their campaigns for Governor to a rainsoaked New York City yesterday in their drives to greet as many voters as possible before the Sept. 12 Democratic primary.

title: Part of Brooklet Oil Spill Drifts Toward Sandy Hook. but Is Disnersin
description: The 37,000gallon oil spill that forced the closing of five New York City beaches continued to drift southwest toward Sandy Hook yesterday, but spokesmen for the Coast Guard, which is observing the cleanup workers, said they were confident they would be able to disperse what remained of the slick with chemicals before it could reach the New Jersey shore.

title: MANY VOICE SADNESS
description: Across the nation and the world, the powerful and the average, parishioner yesterday mourned the man who for 15 years had been the spiritual leader of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Strike Authorization Is Voted by Pressmen At Major City Papers
description: The New York City Pressmen's Union voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize a strike against the city's three major newspapers. The union's leaders said there would be a walkout tomorrow night if the newspapers carried out plans to post revised work rules.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: The dividing line between cool, dry air and warm, muggy air is apparent as an elongated band of clouds stretching from New England southwestward to the Gulf Coast. Individual thunderstorm clusters stand out as brighter clouds over the Gulf of Mexico and across portions of the Southeast.

title: Arson
description: SEATTLEArson is, by all available data, the nation's fastest growing. crime problem.

description: The firstplace Boston Red Sox, on the rebound after a slump in July, continue to bat down the teams trying to catch them in the American League Eastern Division. They did it yesterday with a 40 victory over the secondplace Brewers in Milwaukee and increased their lead to seven games.

description: In contrast to Pope John XXIII, his predecessor, Paul VI was not naturally gregarious and innovative. But the modernizing was already well under way when he began his reign.

title: The Farber Case
description: The jailing of M.A. Farber, the New York Times reporter who refused to submit his notes to a NewJersey judge, is one of those hard cases that seem destined to make bad law. Freedom of the press, respect for the courts, the public interest: All are likely to suffer.

title: 3 Pennsylvania Firefighters Shot

title: Laz Barrera, Yankee Fan

Someone appeared around the corner of Barn 75 bearing a camera, and obligingly Juan and the animal stopped. Affirmed, the great young stakes champion, jerked his head to the left and stood motionless. Dabs of gold glowed through the chestnut coat. The colt was an actor offering the camera his best side.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Tired of paddling that canoe? Grumman Boats offers three kits that allow you to adapt a canoe for sailing, rowing or motoring. The sailing rig consists of a 55squarefoot sail, a leeboard, a kickup rudder and a Bendy threepiece, 16foot aluminum mast; it sells for $400, and a smaller version is available for $350. The rowing attachment, consisting of a seat for the rower and supports for the row locks, can be clamped to the gunwales with a screwdriver and pliers; that costs $75. A $23 bracket, adjustable to fit most canoes, can hold a small outboard to ease a long or upstream trip; Grumman recommends a quiet fivehorsepower electric motor. For catalogues and the addresses of dealers near you, write to Grumman Boats, Marathon, N.Y. 13803.

description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6  Gertrude Lewis Conaway Vanderbilt, widow of Harold S. Vanderbilt, the yachtsman and railroad financier, died today at her summer home, Rock Cliff, after a long illness. She was 77 years oirl.

description: ROME, Aug. 6  Pope Paul VI, the 262d occupant of the Throne of St. Peter, died peacefully tonight at the age of 80 after a heart attack in his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo.

title: Doing Something About the Weather
description: Mark Twain's observation that everybody talks about the weather but nobody does anything about it, hasn't been true for 30 years. It was in the mid1940's that Vincent J. Schaefer first demonstrated how to seed clouds with dry ice to produce precipitation. Since then, innumerable experimenters have found Ways todisperse tog, shrink hailstones and otherwise to defend against unfavorable weather. A start has been made, but scientists are still far from understanding all the forces that determine climatic, changes and certainly far from the ability to control them.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 6 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda of Japan said today that his Chinese equivalent, Huang Hua, had agreed to meet next week to try to break the deadlock in talks on a proposed peace and friendship treaty. Mr. Sonoda said that he would leave for Peking Tuesday and begin three days of talks on Wednesday.

title: TV: Britten's Albert Herring on channel 13

description: PORT SAN LUIS, Calif., Aug 6  Some 2,000 antinuclear protesters demonstrated on the beach near the controversial Diablo Canyon atomic power plant today as platoons of sympathizers invited arrest in incursions onto the plant grounds from both land and sea.

title: Ward, an Energy Saver, Has Electrified the Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I. Chris Ward will get out of bed this morning, shaking the whole floor of his dormitory at Hofstra University. and make readyfor his first National Football League competition. Ward is a 6foot3inch, 270pound rookie from Ohio State, and he will start as the offensive left tackle tonight when the Jets face the Atlanta Falcons in the New Yorkers opening exhibition, at Giants Stadium.

title: Study Finds Some Prevalent Ideas About Welfare Families Incorrect
description: Some assumptions about welfare recipients, memorialized in Congressional testimony and in executive branch studies, have formed conceptual foundations for public policy. Among the more powerful of the assumptions, which are not necessarily consistent, are the notions that welfare recipients are aberrationally unemployed, that they are isolated and unmotivated, that they do not work because they are lazy, and that the men leave home to increase the family's welfare income. A study on the subject was recently completed for the Department of Labor by the Center for Research on the Acts of Man. It was headed by Dr. Samuel Z. Klausner, a University of Pennsylvania sociologist, and suggests that many of the assumptions about welfare recipients are wrong and thus that Federal welfare and employment policies rest on invalid premises.

title: Larry Merchant Ted Corbitt's 100,000 Miles
description: A 5YEAROLD boy in Kansas recently completed a marathon. If he runs about 200'more of them in his lifetime, he'll catch up to Ted Corbin.

title: The Reign of Pope Paul: A Bridge Between Eras
description: Giovanni Battista Montini became the 262d Bishop of Rome on June 21, 1963, and assumed the task of carrying on another man's revolution.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Justice Department has stepped into a pension casenow before the Supreme Court, supporting the International Brotherhood Teamsters and the Labor Department in a friendofthecourt brief arguing that pension funds should not be treated as securities. The case has caused a furor in business, labor and legal circles and could have a profound impact on pension rights. [Page D1].

title: Where to Find Out
description: Ballooning is best in rural areas, far from tall buildings, traffic and hightension wires. But balloonists reside in city apartMents and in the suburbs as well as in the country.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Tactics And Techniques in NBC's Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6  Whether the Born Innocent case proceeds to trial tomorrow or Marvin E. Lewis, the plaintiff's lawyer, makes good on his threat to pack up my briefcase and go home, the last week of pretrial maneuvers has provided some glimpses of highpowered lawyers feeling their way through a case with no real precedents to guide them.

title: Deaths
description: ASTORJames P. Marti,Count of Or. pi, of Barcelona, Spain, on August 4, 1978. His loving son, grandchildren and family request your prayers for his eternal peace in God.

title: Carter's New York Visit Won't Erase His Image as Political Liability
description: President Carter is coming to town tomorrow to sign, amid ceKemonies, the bill providing Federal loait guaran tees to New York City, and local politicians will presumably turn; out en masse for him and the cameras.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, AUGUST 7, 1978

title: Contract for MediCal
description: The Computer Services Corporation said it had received a $129.6 million contract from California to process claims for the state's MediCal program.

title: Trucks in Test Do Best at 55 M.P.H.
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 6 (UPI) It took three days and nearly 900 gallons of No. 2 diesel fuel, but the test is over. Each sides says it won and the other side cheated.

title: Modern Museum Head Hopeful Despite Setback from Court
description: THOUGH a recent ruling by an appellate court found unconstitutional a special law enabling the Museum of Modern Art to build a 92story apartment tower, museum officials are undeterred.

title: Several Families Are Sent Away From Niagara Falls Landfill Site
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 6 dozen or more families were moved from the contaminated Love Canal landfill site to temporary quarters yesterday and today as offers of more permanent homes came in.

title: Junk Phone Calls Bring Demands for F.C.C. Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  Telephone solicitations by automatic dialing machines, often called junk phone calls, have stirred an unusual outpouring of more than 6,000 letters and other communications to the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Group Proposes Tax Incentives To Increase Political Broadcasts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  Hardly anyone is neutral about the use of television by political candidates during an election campaign.

title: ELECTION TO BE HELD
description: ROME, Aug. 6  Pope Paul VI, the 262d occupant of the Throne of St. Peter, died peacefully tonight at the age of 80 after a heart attack in his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Friday reported incorrectly that a New York State judge had upheld the right of the American Institute of Public Accountants to establish a new class of membership. in fact the judge upheld the institute's establishment of a separate division for large acccounting firms on the ground that the new structure did not constitute a separate class of membership.

title: Farmers in Philippines Evicted After Planting Unused Estate Lands
